description: The intent of the Managing across the Lifecycle (MALC) qualification is to give candidates the skills to support an organization’s service delivery by bridging the service lifecycle stages. The qualification demonstrates that candidates have learned the value of one combined service management practice as opposed to separate subject areas. ITIL processes and practices, as learned from the lifecycle and capability streams of the intermediate certificates, are put into a context of delivering this value.

>> And I'm from Iowa, and
believe me, you need to be hoeing.

229
00:12:31.738 --> 00:12:33.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right.

230
00:12:33.360 --> 00:12:34.930
So that's kinda the lay of the land.

231
00:12:34.930 --> 00:12:36.710
That's the lay of the land,
what you expect.

232
00:12:36.710 --> 00:12:39.720
One other big thing is,
you're own self study is important.

233
00:12:39.720 --> 00:12:43.420
You'll see episode files up above,
there's some up above right now.

As you look at your episode files,

There are process charts and

And also help you have in front of you
while you're watching these lectures.

It's a good visual reference,
including the course handbook.

00:12:58.980 --> 00:13:01.060
Which has the same PowerPoint
as going through here.

239
00:13:01.060 --> 00:13:02.960
You can take notes and whatnot.

240
00:13:02.960 --> 00:13:05.392
So I highly encourage you to
download those materials.

241
00:13:05.392 --> 00:13:09.405
And as you get into each episode,
you'll find additional materials for

242
00:13:09.405 --> 00:13:11.570
knowledge checks and exercises.

243
00:13:11.570 --> 00:13:13.100
I highly encourage you to go there.

244
00:13:13.100 --> 00:13:16.144
And as we go through the episodes,
I'll remind you that they're there and

00:13:16.144 --> 00:13:17.316
what the value of those are.

246
00:13:17.316 --> 00:13:21.320
And I look forward to seeing you for

You can watch it again and
again and again.

So again, thanks again Terry.

>> Glad to be.

>> And thank you for watching ITProTV.

You know a good IT Pro is always learning.

WEBVTT

1

2

3

[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.188 --> 00:00:07.952
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.952 --> 00:00:10.672
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:10.672 --> 00:00:15.630
>> Well hello there thank you again for
choosing IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:15.630 --> 00:00:17.670
Helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:17.670 --> 00:00:22.050
I'm your host Zach Memos and
we are continuing on with ITIL Malk.

9
00:00:22.050 --> 00:00:24.720
Lots of episodes in this series
you want to watch them all,

10
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:28.470
bringing us to the information
we need is Terry Decker.

11
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:29.430
>> Hello, Zach.

12
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:29.950
>> Hey, Terry.

13
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:31.580
>> Yep, doing good.

14
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:32.080
>> Good.
>> Yep.

15
00:00:32.080 --> 00:00:35.300
As Zach said, we're gonna move in
to a foundation refresher here for

16
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:36.430
a manager across the life cycle.

17
00:00:36.430 --> 00:00:40.670
This particular episode concerns
the concepts, and just basically

18
00:00:40.670 --> 00:00:45.180
the vocabulary of ITIL is part of every
intermediate course that we offer.

19
00:00:45.180 --> 00:00:49.960
So if it looks and sounds familiar,
it's because it's pretty much identical.

20
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:54.110
At this point, you've gone through more
than one intermediate level course so

21
00:00:54.110 --> 00:00:56.260
I'm going to be a little
bit quicker about this.

22
00:00:56.260 --> 00:00:59.830
Don't let my speed belay
the importance of this.

23
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:02.470
You need to know
the language of ITIL because

24
00:01:02.470 --> 00:01:05.440
if no other reason that's the language
that's gonna be on the exam.

25
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:09.640
One of the blessings of ITIL and one of
the banes of ITIL is it takes words and

26
00:01:09.640 --> 00:01:11.180
gives them specific meaning.

27
00:01:11.180 --> 00:01:14.630
And it's a blessing because we
need communicate consistently so

28
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:18.100
by having a common vocabulary we
can more effectively communicate.

29
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:18.630
Right?

30
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:21.640
I guess the bane part of it is that
they've taken words that already

31
00:01:21.640 --> 00:01:22.830
have meaning.

32
00:01:22.830 --> 00:01:27.520
They take words that we're already using
in our common life, daily life, and

33
00:01:27.520 --> 00:01:28.450
our work life.

34
00:01:28.450 --> 00:01:30.820
And they've given them
their specific meanings.

35
00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:33.820
So, we have to retranslate, or
relearn some of the things.

36
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:39.360
Again, the blessing and the bane,
let's dive in and enjoy them both.

37
00:01:39.360 --> 00:01:40.656
First of all, the life cycle.

38
00:01:40.656 --> 00:01:41.930
As you recall,

39
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:48.170
ITIL divides a service across its
life cycle into five stages, right?

40
00:01:48.170 --> 00:01:51.330
So a life cycle meaning
from birth to death, from

41
00:01:51.330 --> 00:01:55.965
the day you're hired to the day you're
fired, whatever the life cycle might be.

42
00:01:55.965 --> 00:02:00.495
They divide it into five stages strategy,
design, transition, operations and

43
00:02:00.495 --> 00:02:02.265
CSI right.

44
00:02:02.265 --> 00:02:06.235
You have a chart available for
downloaded in episode files

45
00:02:06.235 --> 00:02:10.590
that shows you all these stages with
all the processes underneath them.

46
00:02:10.590 --> 00:02:14.110
I find it very helpful to have that as
a regular touchstone as we're learning

47
00:02:14.110 --> 00:02:19.310
different topics to put the discussion
in the context of the lifecycle,

48
00:02:19.310 --> 00:02:22.750
having that nice visual in front
of you is very helpful, right,

49
00:02:22.750 --> 00:02:24.280
so I encourage you to have that.

50
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:27.640
Download available, or
if you've printed it, even better, and

51
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:29.070
have it at your desktop.

52
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:31.910
So as we talk about these
different processes,

53
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:35.540
we see it in the context
of the entire life cycle.

54
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:38.860
A big part of MALK is going to
be understanding the interaction

55
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:40.430
of these various stages.

56
00:02:40.430 --> 00:02:45.420
Which necessarily means the interaction
among the processes within the stages.

57
00:02:45.420 --> 00:02:49.660
If you're looking at a strategic view
of an organization and you're analyzing

58
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:55.170
the health of your IT service provision,
right, your IT service management.

59
00:02:55.170 --> 00:02:58.250
You're necessarily gonna have
to look across the lifecycle,

60
00:02:58.250 --> 00:03:01.400
thus the name,
managing across the lifecycle.

61
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:06.700
There is a high component of strategic
value To MALK or strategic scope right.

62
00:03:06.700 --> 00:03:10.650
That doesn't mean we're necessarily
looking at service strategy more so

63
00:03:10.650 --> 00:03:12.330
than service operations.

64
00:03:12.330 --> 00:03:16.500
It's we're looking at all these
stages with a strategic view right.

65
00:03:17.910 --> 00:03:20.670
So as we continue on I mean,
good vocabulary here.

66
00:03:20.670 --> 00:03:23.230
What is a service, the very central

67
00:03:23.230 --> 00:03:28.290
concept of service management of course is
a service and knowing what a service is.

68
00:03:28.290 --> 00:03:30.550
The textbook definition is,
as you see there,

69
00:03:30.550 --> 00:03:35.450
a means of delivering value to customers
by facilitating outcomes they want to

70
00:03:35.450 --> 00:03:38.980
achieve without ownership Of cost and
risk.

71
00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:43.410
In other words, as a service provider,
you take the details of cost and

72
00:03:43.410 --> 00:03:48.000
risk away from the customer and
provide service to them.

73
00:03:48.000 --> 00:03:51.790
When you go to a restaurant you
want it to be delivered on time,

74
00:03:51.790 --> 00:03:54.390
you want it to be delivered
at the right temperature.

75
00:03:54.390 --> 00:03:56.630
Right, of course you want
it to taste good as well.

76
00:03:56.630 --> 00:04:01.560
Are you monitoring how
they staff the kitchen,

77
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:04.350
or when they got their
produce order that morning?

78
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:08.820
Are you actually monitoring
how fresh the meat is, no?

79
00:04:08.820 --> 00:04:10.130
You're going to get the service,

80
00:04:10.130 --> 00:04:12.260
you're going to get the food
served at the appropriate times,

81
00:04:12.260 --> 00:04:15.150
and the appropriate temperatures, and
you're going to taste it and say yep.

82
00:04:15.150 --> 00:04:17.500
You delivered service and
I'm gonna pay you for that service.

83
00:04:18.620 --> 00:04:21.800
So the nature of service
delivery is understanding that

84
00:04:21.800 --> 00:04:25.850
you're gonna be delivering value to
that customer, and that they don't

85
00:04:25.850 --> 00:04:29.139
have to worry about all the details of
what it takes to deliver that value.

86
00:04:29.139 --> 00:04:31.552
[CROSSTALK]
>> The golden concept of customer

87
00:04:31.552 --> 00:04:32.870
service value?

88
00:04:32.870 --> 00:04:33.980
>> Absolutely.

89
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:35.800
They're all embodied right there.

90
00:04:35.800 --> 00:04:39.890
The three golden concepts, they will
still serve you on this exam as well.

91
00:04:39.890 --> 00:04:43.970
Understanding that service is being
delivered, not just systems or solutions.

92
00:04:43.970 --> 00:04:45.530
You're delivering service to customers.

93
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:49.760
And you're delivering service so that
they can achieve some sort of outcome.

94
00:04:49.760 --> 00:04:51.760
Through that, they're gonna get value.

95
00:04:51.760 --> 00:04:57.490
Right, so focus on the customer, deliver
them value and you do so through services.

96
00:04:57.490 --> 00:05:02.060
That's the golden triangular
if you will elite them, okay.

97
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:04.480
Okay so what is service management?

98
00:05:04.480 --> 00:05:09.510
Well if a service is a means of
delivering value, service management is

99
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:14.460
kinda like a snake swallowing its own tail
cuz it's kind of a circular reference.

100
00:05:14.460 --> 00:05:19.510
Service management is the ability
to deliver value through services.

101
00:05:19.510 --> 00:05:21.390
Which is a means of
delivering value right.

102
00:05:21.390 --> 00:05:23.820
So it's kinda that's what I mean by
that little circular thing there.

103
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:26.780
>> Cyclical.
>> Yeah cyclical so

104
00:05:26.780 --> 00:05:32.540
service management is really your
capability to manage your services, right?

105
00:05:32.540 --> 00:05:34.210
Deliver your value through services.

106
00:05:34.210 --> 00:05:38.010
Either have a service management
capability, or you don't.

107
00:05:38.010 --> 00:05:39.750
And strictest terms, ATIL,

108
00:05:39.750 --> 00:05:44.920
begins with understanding Service,
right, and not just solutions.

109
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:47.990
So service management is
that set of capabilities or

110
00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:52.640
tools that you have available
to make this successful, right.

111
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:54.980
ITIL describes 26 processes.

112
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:57.580
Through those 26 process you do them well,

113
00:05:57.580 --> 00:05:59.640
chances are you'll be doing
service management well.

114
00:05:59.640 --> 00:06:05.650
That's basically the lay of the land if
you will, the service management, right?

115
00:06:06.900 --> 00:06:11.220
So at the heart of this is making sure you
have a good solid customer relationship.

116
00:06:11.220 --> 00:06:15.860
A big part of service is understanding how
you're delivering value to the customers.

117
00:06:15.860 --> 00:06:18.330
How are you facilitating their outcomes,
right?

118
00:06:18.330 --> 00:06:20.120
That's really what it boils down to.

119
00:06:20.120 --> 00:06:22.560
If you don't know your customer well,

120
00:06:22.560 --> 00:06:25.390
chances are you're not gonna
be as successful, right?

121
00:06:25.390 --> 00:06:28.940
If you're just kinda guessing what they
want or throwing something on the wall and

122
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:30.690
hope it sticks, right?

123
00:06:30.690 --> 00:06:35.130
Rather than taking the approach of
actually determining what the requirements

124
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:39.920
are, what their desired outcomes are,
and matching your IT solutions and

125
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:44.150
services to those outcomes that's the key,
right?

126
00:06:45.770 --> 00:06:49.680
The three types of service providers
again review Type I is internal and

127
00:06:49.680 --> 00:06:52.000
Type II is also internal.

128
00:06:52.000 --> 00:06:55.530
It's just Type I is internal
to the business unit and

129
00:06:55.530 --> 00:06:57.850
type two of shared services.

130
00:06:57.850 --> 00:07:01.960
I worked for years in a shared services
part of the organization where we

131
00:07:01.960 --> 00:07:05.900
were providing services that every
business unit consumed, like e-mail,

132
00:07:05.900 --> 00:07:09.460
and internet portal, and learning
management, and document management.

133
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:11.510
Things that everyone consumed.

134
00:07:11.510 --> 00:07:15.754
But, I also worked in organization had
internal IT departments working for

135
00:07:15.754 --> 00:07:17.488
the specific business areas.

136
00:07:17.488 --> 00:07:23.128
Like there was an RND IT department or
a manufacturing IT department and

137
00:07:23.128 --> 00:07:27.264
those IT providers service
providers they provided

138
00:07:27.264 --> 00:07:32.460
the detailed awareness of
the business In those cases right.

139
00:07:32.460 --> 00:07:36.715
And then type 3 is an external service
provider where you provide services to

140
00:07:36.715 --> 00:07:39.537
customers that are outside
of your organization.

141
00:07:39.537 --> 00:07:42.080
Perhaps for profit even right.

142
00:07:42.080 --> 00:07:46.618
So the nice thing about this particular
scenario is type 1, type 2, type 3,

143
00:07:46.618 --> 00:07:50.688
it' important to make these
distinguishing characteristics known,

144
00:07:50.688 --> 00:07:55.333
right and then understand the differences
between TYPE I, TYPE II and TYPE III.

145
00:07:55.333 --> 00:07:58.932
But in the end, these are really
distinctions without a difference.

146
00:07:58.932 --> 00:08:03.813
And what I mean by that- Is that the
prinicples of ITIL, delivering value to

147
00:08:03.813 --> 00:08:08.410
customers applies equally to all three,
Type I, Type II and Type III.

148
00:08:08.410 --> 00:08:10.917
Now your funding sources
might be different,

149
00:08:10.917 --> 00:08:12.950
the politics might be different.

150
00:08:12.950 --> 00:08:16.420
I totally understand that, and
that's not trivial, that's important.

151
00:08:16.420 --> 00:08:21.930
But at the end of the day, the principles
of ITIL apply equally to all three types.

152
00:08:21.930 --> 00:08:23.620
As you get to the MALC exam,

153
00:08:23.620 --> 00:08:28.640
the case study is an external provider,
they're a financial services.

154
00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:31.250
I'm sorry,
they are a provider of financial services.

155
00:08:31.250 --> 00:08:37.440
They have some external components,
some customer use IT services, right?

156
00:08:37.440 --> 00:08:42.040
They also have internal customers,
and they also have shared services.

157
00:08:42.040 --> 00:08:44.300
So all three are in play
even on the MALC exam.

158
00:08:44.300 --> 00:08:46.350
And yet
we're only talking about one organization.

159
00:08:48.570 --> 00:08:50.050
All right.

160
00:08:50.050 --> 00:08:54.380
Stakeholders, there are four
stakeholder groups.

161
00:08:54.380 --> 00:08:59.100
You see in here, the service providers is,
a customer, a user and suppliers.

162
00:08:59.100 --> 00:09:02.440
The four primary stakeholder
groups are important.

163
00:09:03.960 --> 00:09:09.840
It's neat how ITIL takes and distills
concepts down into digestible bits.

164
00:09:09.840 --> 00:09:12.605
Here, they're simply categorizing
four groups of stakeholders, and

165
00:09:12.605 --> 00:09:14.656
this is the only four you
have to worry about, right.

166
00:09:14.656 --> 00:09:17.470
Now of course,
there's nuances among these stakeholders.

167
00:09:17.470 --> 00:09:22.770
If you're talking to executives at
the supplier organization as opposed

168
00:09:22.770 --> 00:09:27.880
to the suppliers practitioners, this is
a different kind of an interface, right?

169
00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:32.090
So you'll have to manage the details
of stakeholder management as well,

170
00:09:32.090 --> 00:09:35.870
if you're talking to a service owner
within the service organization,

171
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.440
that's different than
talking to a process owner.

172
00:09:38.440 --> 00:09:42.450
So I understand that there's
nuances below these major groups.

173
00:09:42.450 --> 00:09:45.160
But I like the fact that
there's four big ones here,

174
00:09:45.160 --> 00:09:47.800
especially as you're approaching the exam.

175
00:09:47.800 --> 00:09:53.220
In that these four groups need to be
represented in almost all cases, right.

176
00:09:53.220 --> 00:09:55.210
So, if you're evaluating a question.

177
00:09:56.340 --> 00:10:00.770
And you'll see that some of
the stakeholder groups are included, and

178
00:10:00.770 --> 00:10:02.020
others are not.

179
00:10:02.020 --> 00:10:04.660
You might wanna be suspect about
that particular answer, right?

180
00:10:04.660 --> 00:10:08.110
Because, you need to be more
inclusive of all four groups.

181
00:10:08.110 --> 00:10:10.230
Just a takeaway there, okay.

182
00:10:11.240 --> 00:10:12.470
All right and moving forward.

183
00:10:12.470 --> 00:10:15.170
Internal and external services,
this is just flipping the coin.

184
00:10:15.170 --> 00:10:18.180
Earlier we had an external
service provider,

185
00:10:18.180 --> 00:10:21.900
an internal service provider,
well what about the customer side?

186
00:10:21.900 --> 00:10:22.720
Flip the coin a little bit,

187
00:10:22.720 --> 00:10:26.000
you got internal customers,
you have external customers.

188
00:10:26.000 --> 00:10:30.030
And again, it's somewhat of
a distinction without a difference.

189
00:10:30.030 --> 00:10:33.900
You need to deliver value to
customers whether they work for

190
00:10:33.900 --> 00:10:37.970
the same organization as you or
whether you're selling your services for

191
00:10:37.970 --> 00:10:40.200
profit, you need to deliver value.

192
00:10:40.200 --> 00:10:45.500
So these principles apply equally to both
types of services whether it's internal or

193
00:10:45.500 --> 00:10:47.090
external, okay.

194
00:10:48.210 --> 00:10:51.180
And moving forward here you'll
see just some examples.

195
00:10:51.180 --> 00:10:52.730
Here you see an organization.

196
00:10:52.730 --> 00:10:55.820
Let's take the bank for
example, just any given bank.

197
00:10:55.820 --> 00:11:01.560
Enough folks, you don't use a bank,
you're actually a customer of IT services.

198
00:11:01.560 --> 00:11:05.128
If you go to an ATM machine,
you are using an IT service, right.

199
00:11:06.170 --> 00:11:09.240
Something's going on in the background and
ITs making that happen.

200
00:11:09.240 --> 00:11:11.250

Process control is effectively about an
appropriate strategy for your processes.

437
00:24:41.790 --> 00:24:46.350
What are you trying to get done, and
why is it important to you, right.

438
00:24:46.350 --> 00:24:49.510
Is it so important that you need to
have a policy that says thou shalt

439
00:24:49.510 --> 00:24:51.045
follow the process?

440
00:24:51.045 --> 00:24:53.280
So it's one thing to have a process.

441
00:24:54.420 --> 00:24:57.720
It's another thing to make
sure it's followed, right?

442
00:24:57.720 --> 00:25:02.500
So process policy is a way to kind
of give some governance behind

443
00:25:02.500 --> 00:25:08.000
the policy to make sure that it has some
corporate backing, if you will, right?

444
00:25:08.000 --> 00:25:10.150
Now, the process itself,
you've got process control.

445
00:25:10.150 --> 00:25:15.450
And then, in the green bits here,
you got the process activities themselves.

446
00:25:15.450 --> 00:25:18.410
This is where it actually happens, right?

447
00:25:18.410 --> 00:25:20.920
This is where the process gets executed.

448
00:25:20.920 --> 00:25:23.700
And then finally in the blue
bits the people who get it done.

449
00:25:23.700 --> 00:25:27.170
The process enablers,
the ones that actually manage

450
00:25:27.170 --> 00:25:31.210
the process on a day to day basis,
get it done day to day.

451
00:25:31.210 --> 00:25:33.690
So you have to have your
process resources available

452
00:25:33.690 --> 00:25:36.168
including the measure mechanisms etc.

453
00:25:36.168 --> 00:25:38.983
And notice there's feedback
loops among these.

454
00:25:38.983 --> 00:25:44.103
These arrows or double arrows, right,
so it should be a constant source of

455
00:25:44.103 --> 00:25:50.073
feedback among the different elements of
the process model, right, simple as that.

456
00:25:50.073 --> 00:25:52.030
All right.

457
00:25:52.030 --> 00:25:53.420
Now a function.

458
00:25:53.420 --> 00:25:55.050
ITIL describes four functions.

459
00:25:56.480 --> 00:26:00.920
A function is a group of people
with special skills or tools.

460
00:26:00.920 --> 00:26:05.530
You might recall them as application
management and technical management.

461
00:26:05.530 --> 00:26:11.910
We also have the IT operations management
and the service desk, those are the four.

462
00:26:13.280 --> 00:26:16.340
A team of people with groups
with special skills and tools.

463
00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:17.850
Now, this word function,

464
00:26:19.220 --> 00:26:24.120
perhaps is an unfortunate word
because function means so many things.

465
00:26:24.120 --> 00:26:26.610
Function can mean where you
go when you want cake and

466
00:26:26.610 --> 00:26:29.100
ice cream at the end of the celebration.

467
00:26:29.100 --> 00:26:29.860
>> Highly important.

468
00:26:29.860 --> 00:26:30.990
>> That's right, highly important.

469
00:26:30.990 --> 00:26:35.610
A function could be something
within a database structure that

470
00:26:35.610 --> 00:26:39.340
actually repeats something or actually
executes something repeatable, right?

471
00:26:39.340 --> 00:26:42.741
You can go to the function to get
a little chain of events going on.

472
00:26:42.741 --> 00:26:47.398
So function has lots of meanings, right,
and lots of different contexts that IT

473
00:26:47.398 --> 00:26:51.060
happens to use,
including the cake and ice cream one.

474
00:26:51.060 --> 00:26:55.740
But function in ITIL simply means
a group of people with special skills or

475
00:26:55.740 --> 00:26:57.870
tools, right.

476
00:26:57.870 --> 00:27:01.390
So perhaps and
unfortunate use of the function,

477
00:27:01.390 --> 00:27:03.810
maybe functional area would
have been a better word.

478
00:27:03.810 --> 00:27:06.917
I'm not gonna hash the syntax
to this too much, but

479
00:27:06.917 --> 00:27:11.612
you need to understand that when they
use function as part of their language,

480
00:27:11.612 --> 00:27:15.604
they are using function in a very
specific way, related to ITIL.

481
00:27:15.604 --> 00:27:18.882
So just be wary of the word, okay.

482
00:27:18.882 --> 00:27:21.220
So that's just a lay of the land.

483
00:27:21.220 --> 00:27:25.370
That concludes this part of setting
the stage for the language of ITIL,

484
00:27:25.370 --> 00:27:27.340
some key concepts of ITIL.

485
00:27:27.340 --> 00:27:28.430
It's not new to you.

486
00:27:28.430 --> 00:27:31.420
You would have scraped your
knuckles on these concepts

487
00:27:31.420 --> 00:27:34.320
throughout the foundation and
intermediate level courses.

488
00:27:34.320 --> 00:27:35.430
But just setting the table,

489
00:27:35.430 --> 00:27:37.910
we're gonna be using that language
a lot in future episodes.

490
00:27:39.552 --> 00:27:44.100
>> Terry, you did a great job and we're
gonna continue on with more ITIL MALC.

491
00:27:44.100 --> 00:27:49.230
Lots of episodes you can watch and rewatch
again and again and then please do.

492
00:27:50.510 --> 00:27:55.870
Well, thank you for watching ITProTV, and
remember a good IT pro is always learning.

493
00:27:55.870 --> 00:27:56.770
I'm Zach Memos.

494
00:27:56.770 --> 00:27:57.550
>> I'm Terry Decker.

495
00:27:57.550 --> 00:27:58.700
>> And we will see you very soon.

496
00:27:58.700 --> 00:28:03.310
[MUSIC]

497
00:28:03.310 --> 00:28:09.076
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach reinforce the key considerations of customers, value, & service at the heart of ITSM considerations.
episodes.title: Key Concepts of ITIL
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.160
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.160 --> 00:00:06.552
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.552 --> 00:00:08.388
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.388 --> 00:00:12.197
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.197 --> 00:00:16.497
>> Hello again, and thank you for making
the intelligent choice to choose ITProTV,

6
00:00:16.497 --> 00:00:19.600
helping you learn wherever you go
>> I'm our host, Zach Memos.

7
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:23.596
As we continue with ITIL, MALC, and
this is an exciting episode, and

8
00:00:23.596 --> 00:00:28.160
bringing us all the information we need
is Terry Decker, who's right here.

9
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:28.878
That's Terry right there.

10
00:00:28.878 --> 00:00:29.472
>> Hello, Zach.

11
00:00:29.472 --> 00:00:31.032
>> [LAUGH]
>> Happy to be here.

12
00:00:31.032 --> 00:00:34.580
As Zach said, we're gonna continue this
managing across the life cycle course and

13
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:39.550
we have a queued up for
you this time is some key concepts related

14
00:00:39.550 --> 00:00:44.100
to the creation of value through service
strategy, and through service operations.

15
00:00:44.100 --> 00:00:47.320
We'll have a little sprinkling of some
of the other processes in there as well.

16
00:00:47.320 --> 00:00:48.960
So first of all, diving in and

17
00:00:48.960 --> 00:00:52.540
something we reinforced earlier
is value to the business.

18
00:00:52.540 --> 00:00:56.920
Once upon a time, ITIL considered
itself aligned with the business.

19
00:00:56.920 --> 00:01:00.894
Where you knew what they were up to,
and you tried to meet their target.

20
00:01:00.894 --> 00:01:05.800
Circa 2011,
they redesigned ITIL a little bit.

21
00:01:05.800 --> 00:01:09.110
And republished publications, and

22
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:13.850
decided that alignment, as valuable as
that is, should become integration.

23
00:01:13.850 --> 00:01:16.632
So, integrating with a business
is a different prospect.

24
00:01:16.632 --> 00:01:20.740
That means, you're really going to be
that much closer to your customers,

25
00:01:20.740 --> 00:01:25.059
and maybe even in their business a little
bit, right, integrating with them.

26
00:01:25.059 --> 00:01:26.420
Some customers might resist that.

27
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:30.470
So one of the challenges that comes about
as it's played out through this MALC exam

28
00:01:30.470 --> 00:01:35.710
and this MALC experience, managed across
the life cycle, is that, this idea

29
00:01:35.710 --> 00:01:40.610
of getting into the business, in with your
customers, is a challenge worth taking.

30
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:43.290
And, you need to knock down that door,
knock on the door,

31
00:01:43.290 --> 00:01:49.610
knock it down if you need to, early and
often in your relationships, right?

32
00:01:49.610 --> 00:01:51.790
Of course, you're gonna deliver
value through services.

33
00:01:51.790 --> 00:01:55.999
We talked about this in the earlier
episodes, value through services,

34
00:01:55.999 --> 00:01:57.732
not through just solutions.

35
00:01:57.732 --> 00:02:00.710
You can't just throw a solution
out there and hope they like it.

36
00:02:00.710 --> 00:02:03.010
You're gonna have to be
involved in providing service,

37
00:02:03.010 --> 00:02:05.160
not just solutions themselves.

38
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:10.811
Some key concepts here, value is
described, and defined by the customer.

39
00:02:10.811 --> 00:02:12.810
You know the phrase
the customer is always right?

40
00:02:12.810 --> 00:02:16.620
I would challenge that,
know the customer can be wrong.

41
00:02:16.620 --> 00:02:18.430
They can be and you need to educate them.

42
00:02:18.430 --> 00:02:20.310
They could have wrong expectations for

43
00:02:20.310 --> 00:02:24.710
us and
som they could have misguided perceptions.

44
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:27.340
But it's possible you need to
correct some customer behavior.

45
00:02:28.378 --> 00:02:32.160
I'm not gonna paint it in such rosy
pictures that the customer's always right,

46
00:02:32.160 --> 00:02:35.430
but I will say this, if the customer's

47
00:02:35.430 --> 00:02:40.200
perception of value is not tended to,
you will fail, right?

48
00:02:40.200 --> 00:02:45.620
The only opinion that matters when it
comes to value, is the customer's opinion.

49
00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:48.600
When it comes to word value or
delivery of value.

50
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:54.520
If they like it, if they're driving
business outcomes through your services,

51
00:02:54.520 --> 00:02:55.770
they're gonna see the value.

52
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:59.920
If they can't see the value, then you've
become a mysterious cost setter, right?

53
00:02:59.920 --> 00:03:03.140
We're not sure what you do IT,
but you sure cost a lot, right.

54
00:03:03.140 --> 00:03:04.838
You don't wanna be in that position,
right.

55
00:03:04.838 --> 00:03:08.800
You don't wanna be in the position where
you're just a mysterious call center.

56
00:03:08.800 --> 00:03:13.210
You need to viewed by
the customers as a strategic asset

57
00:03:13.210 --> 00:03:16.010
that allows them to get their
job done more effectively.

58
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:17.570
That's where you need to go towards.

59
00:03:17.570 --> 00:03:23.842
So, focusing on what value means to them
is the key component to this, right?

60
00:03:25.989 --> 00:03:28.270
So what is IT trying to get done?

61
00:03:28.270 --> 00:03:29.433
Are really creating the value.

62
00:03:29.433 --> 00:03:33.319
You could do it through warranty,
you can do it through utility, but

63
00:03:33.319 --> 00:03:36.267
really what it comes down
to on the customer side is,

64
00:03:36.267 --> 00:03:40.490
are you able to let them get something
done, the business outcomes is key.

65
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:45.255
As you can see in the upper right
of this particular graphic,

66
00:03:45.255 --> 00:03:49.938
business outcomes is the primary
focus of creating value.

67
00:03:49.938 --> 00:03:54.410
Now it would be nice if that's all we had
to worry about, just business outcomes.

68
00:03:54.410 --> 00:03:59.210
But we also have to be concerned with
their perceptions, or their preferences.

69
00:03:59.210 --> 00:04:03.810
I'll give you a non-IT example
to distinguish the difference

70
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:09.127
between business outcomes and
preferences or perceptions.

71
00:04:09.127 --> 00:04:14.462
Let's say what you've been asked
to do is to design a service that

72
00:04:14.462 --> 00:04:19.811
allows the user to lower the window
of their automobile, right?

73
00:04:19.811 --> 00:04:22.000
Again, a non IT example.

74
00:04:22.000 --> 00:04:24.510
You've been asked to
design such a solution.

75
00:04:24.510 --> 00:04:27.140
So, you go back to the shop.

76
00:04:27.140 --> 00:04:31.821
You researched the regulatory
requirements, the safety requirements,

77
00:04:31.821 --> 00:04:33.609
the cost benefit analysis.

78
00:04:33.609 --> 00:04:37.141
And you come up with what you
think is the perfect solution for

79
00:04:37.141 --> 00:04:40.396
the business outcome of
lowering the window in the car,

80
00:04:40.396 --> 00:04:43.318
and what you delivered is a crank handle,
right?

81
00:04:43.318 --> 00:04:44.274
It works.

82
00:04:44.274 --> 00:04:45.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> The customer says,

83
00:04:45.170 --> 00:04:47.680
I don't want a crank handle, right?

84
00:04:47.680 --> 00:04:48.860
I don't want that.

85
00:04:48.860 --> 00:04:51.910
And you would be silly to say,
what do you mean you don't want it?

86
00:04:51.910 --> 00:04:53.510
It's exactly what you need.

87
00:04:53.510 --> 00:04:57.730
It's cost effective, it didn't cost
nearly as much as an electric window.

88
00:04:57.730 --> 00:04:59.480
If you drive into a lake,

89
00:04:59.480 --> 00:05:02.540
you can still get your window
down if the power goes out.

90
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:05.795
Is so satisfying all of our
safety requirements, right?

91
00:05:05.795 --> 00:05:09.038
There's no real pinch factor
involved here, right?

92
00:05:09.038 --> 00:05:11.880
You're not gonna accidentally roll
the window up on your finger,

93
00:05:11.880 --> 00:05:15.820
your child's finger, chances are, right?

94
00:05:15.820 --> 00:05:17.720
So what are you worried about, customer?

95
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:20.030
Go back and
enjoy your crank handle, right?

96
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:20.912
You can't do that, obviously.

97
00:05:20.912 --> 00:05:25.830
You're gonna have to deliver not just what
they need in terms of business outcomes,

98
00:05:25.830 --> 00:05:30.090
but you're gonna have to satisfy their
preferences and their perceptions.

99
00:05:30.090 --> 00:05:34.810
They may perceive that particular
solution as old, outdated, not effective,

100
00:05:34.810 --> 00:05:37.260
not convenient enough, right.

101
00:05:37.260 --> 00:05:39.680
And then you go back and
you do a push button.

102
00:05:39.680 --> 00:05:42.590
And then they want, don't hold it down,

103
00:05:42.590 --> 00:05:46.060
I just wanna press it once, I want it
to be automatic just with one press.

104
00:05:46.060 --> 00:05:48.960
And I want that one press
to be both up and down.

105
00:05:48.960 --> 00:05:50.770
Right, but what about defense factor?

106
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:52.560
You could hurt your child's fingers.

107
00:05:52.560 --> 00:05:55.255
Well, I want some anti-roll.

108
00:05:55.255 --> 00:05:57.690
If it meets some resistance, I wanna
it to automatically roll back then.

109
00:05:57.690 --> 00:06:01.670
And you get the idea,
how complex this value proposition can be.

110
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:05.750
But if you're not interrogating
the customer about their preferences and

111
00:06:05.750 --> 00:06:10.200
perceptions, and only interrogating
them about the business outcomes,

112
00:06:10.200 --> 00:06:13.480
you could miss out on the true
value proposition that they need.

113
00:06:13.480 --> 00:06:15.580
And again, at the end of the day,

114
00:06:15.580 --> 00:06:20.155
no matter how righteous you might be
in your designing of this solution,

115
00:06:20.155 --> 00:06:25.707
cost effective, safety regulators are off
our back, it's field replaceable units,

116
00:06:25.707 --> 00:06:29.103
this is obviously the best choice for
your customer.

117
00:06:29.103 --> 00:06:31.394
You're not gonna be winning that
argument at the end of the day,

118
00:06:31.394 --> 00:06:34.460
if they have different perceptions and
preferences in mind.

119
00:06:34.460 --> 00:06:39.190
So, as this plays out in an exam as you
are looking at exam considerations,

120
00:06:39.190 --> 00:06:42.660
it will be clear where
the customer wants to go.

121
00:06:42.660 --> 00:06:47.710
Right, and if it's not clear,
then your goal is to make clarity, right,

122
00:06:47.710 --> 00:06:48.560
is to create clarity.

123
00:06:48.560 --> 00:06:52.400
If you're not sure what the customer wants
in terms of perceptions or preferences,

124
00:06:52.400 --> 00:06:56.980
if scenario plays out that way then
you need to interrogate that, right?

125
00:06:56.980 --> 00:07:00.770
You just can't simply consider the
outcomes part of the value proposition.

126
00:07:00.770 --> 00:07:03.690
>> And of course, those interrogations are
very friendly as you make the deep dive

127
00:07:03.690 --> 00:07:06.020
into finding out exactly
what they need and want.

128
00:07:06.020 --> 00:07:06.700
>> Exactly,

129
00:07:06.700 --> 00:07:11.763
I guess interrogation does sound like kind
of a mean where with bright lights and

130
00:07:11.763 --> 00:07:14.535
sweaty palms, and slap [CROSSTALK]
>> [LAUGH]

131
00:07:14.535 --> 00:07:15.669
>> Exactly [LAUGH].

132
00:07:15.669 --> 00:07:18.140
Good on the sign, very good, right.

133
00:07:18.140 --> 00:07:21.770
So again, digging into the perceptions
is gonna be a big part of it.

134
00:07:21.770 --> 00:07:25.510
This is just simply a graphic that
suggests that you talk to them often, and

135
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:29.780
early, and that you have
a net positive result, right?

136
00:07:29.780 --> 00:07:33.008
This graphic just simply shows
that at the end of the day,

137
00:07:33.008 --> 00:07:37.529
you need to be having net positive value
proposition instead of a negative one.

138
00:07:37.529 --> 00:07:42.308
If it's gonna cost $5 million
to deliver this IT service, and

139
00:07:42.308 --> 00:07:44.172
they're paying for it.

140
00:07:44.172 --> 00:07:47.800
And at the end of the day, they get
a return on their investment of only,

141
00:07:47.800 --> 00:07:51.450
200,000, well,
that's not a very good positive.

142
00:07:51.450 --> 00:07:52.977
So it could be money driven, right?

143
00:07:52.977 --> 00:07:54.645
It could be value driven, right?

144
00:07:54.645 --> 00:07:59.061
They may like the idea of a push button
button on the push button window.

145
00:07:59.061 --> 00:08:02.682
They may like that so much,
they're just simply delighted, right?

146
00:08:02.682 --> 00:08:05.972
And they like you more because you
delivered a push button approach.

147
00:08:05.972 --> 00:08:06.603
Right.

148
00:08:06.603 --> 00:08:07.723
Let's take that to IT.

149
00:08:07.723 --> 00:08:11.260
You've automated something it's
taken them five days before.

150
00:08:11.260 --> 00:08:12.500
Right.
Now it's easy,

151
00:08:12.500 --> 00:08:17.530
they push a button and the results
are available within two hours.

152
00:08:17.530 --> 00:08:18.040
Right.

153
00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:19.890
They have to answer a few questions,
right.

154
00:08:19.890 --> 00:08:22.600
So they have a few data
inputs they have to make.

155
00:08:22.600 --> 00:08:25.480
But at the end of the day,
they push a button at the end and

156
00:08:25.480 --> 00:08:29.790
they have that magic report,
ready to go within two hours.

157
00:08:29.790 --> 00:08:33.550
What used to take them manually
five days to get done, by you

158
00:08:33.550 --> 00:08:38.350
know moving paper around and giving it
to a clerk to type it in this format and

159
00:08:38.350 --> 00:08:42.660
reformat it over here then doing a
graphical review and manage sort of thing.

160
00:08:42.660 --> 00:08:46.140
So, if you give them a net positive
because you're saving them time,

161
00:08:46.140 --> 00:08:48.900
saving them money then you're
gonna be able to overvalued.

162
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:50.960
If it's in that negative
obviously you're not.

163
00:08:52.400 --> 00:08:53.598
Right, pretty straightforward.

164
00:08:53.598 --> 00:08:58.610
Now, interesting challenge

165
00:08:58.610 --> 00:09:04.490
how do you position yourself as
a valuable asset to your customers.

166
00:09:04.490 --> 00:09:08.400
ITIL is suggesting that you need to have
basically a skill set within your IT

167
00:09:08.400 --> 00:09:11.360
organization that's a whole

the customers, right, HR applications,

400
00:21:49.450 --> 00:21:53.210
financial management applications,
learning management, document management,

401
00:21:53.210 --> 00:21:56.240
email, Outlook applications.

402
00:21:56.240 --> 00:21:58.760
So you have the application
management people and

403
00:21:58.760 --> 00:22:00.010
the technical management people.

404
00:22:01.730 --> 00:22:05.480
They have different areas of specialty,
but what they have in common is

405
00:22:05.480 --> 00:22:09.250
they know everything there is to
know about their areas of specialty.

406
00:22:09.250 --> 00:22:13.510
They can show up at strategic meetings,
and tactical meetings, design meetings.

407
00:22:13.510 --> 00:22:17.450
They can design tests and
acceptance criteria, right?

408
00:22:17.450 --> 00:22:21.320
They can execute architectural plans.

409
00:22:21.320 --> 00:22:24.500
They can design capacity,
they can design availability.

410
00:22:24.500 --> 00:22:29.140
They can go deep and
wide into their areas of specialty,

411
00:22:29.140 --> 00:22:31.876
right, they just have different areas
of speciality, applications and

412
00:22:31.876 --> 00:22:35.230
infrastructure, or technical management.

413
00:22:35.230 --> 00:22:40.740
Now, distinguishing those two
functions from operations management.

414
00:22:40.740 --> 00:22:43.620
Operations management is
the day-to-day grind of IT,

415
00:22:43.620 --> 00:22:49.190
just handling the executable things that
have to be executed every single day,

416
00:22:49.190 --> 00:22:55.090
backups and restores, printer maintenance,
facilities, wiring clauses, power outages.

417
00:22:55.090 --> 00:22:57.230
Are the diesel generators full?

418
00:22:57.230 --> 00:22:59.330
All those types of things, right?

419
00:22:59.330 --> 00:23:03.320
So managing the day-to-day grind
of IT is IT operations management.

420
00:23:03.320 --> 00:23:06.460
Now, that's not to say
that any given person

421
00:23:06.460 --> 00:23:09.320
couldn't be a member of
all three functions.

422
00:23:10.510 --> 00:23:15.340
In other words, I could have day-to-day
responsibilities, and show up at

423
00:23:15.340 --> 00:23:20.220
a technical meeting, or a tactical
meeting, or a strategic meeting, right?

424
00:23:20.220 --> 00:23:24.770
So again, not an organizational chart,
per se, it's just a way to divide and

425
00:23:24.770 --> 00:23:29.166
conquer the need for
appropriate skills and people.

426
00:23:29.166 --> 00:23:34.230
Operations management,
day-to-day grind, technical and

427
00:23:34.230 --> 00:23:38.630
application management, deep dives, they
just have different areas of specialty,

428
00:23:38.630 --> 00:23:42.800
and, of course, the service desk
that interface with the end users.

429
00:23:44.030 --> 00:23:47.080
All right, that's probably a great
place to stop this particular episode.

430
00:23:47.080 --> 00:23:50.380
We've got a few more basic
concepts to pick up on.

431
00:23:50.380 --> 00:23:53.086
We got a few more minutes to go, but
we're reaching pretty close to the end of

432
00:23:53.086 --> 00:23:54.755
the time there, so
we'll take a break there.

433
00:23:54.755 --> 00:23:56.340
>> Okay, well good.

434
00:23:56.340 --> 00:23:58.620
Well, thank you Jerry,
excellent job as always.

435
00:23:58.620 --> 00:24:02.835
Okay, this is Key Concepts of ITIL,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC.

436
00:24:02.835 --> 00:24:05.692
And I thank you for
watching, and thank you for

437
00:24:05.692 --> 00:24:09.730
watching IT Pro TV, remember,
a good IT pro is always learning.

438
00:24:09.730 --> 00:24:10.580
I'm Zach Memos.

439
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:11.420
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

440
00:24:11.420 --> 00:24:13.856
>> And we will see you very soon.

441
00:24:13.856 --> 00:24:19.865
[MUSIC]

442
00:24:19.865 --> 00:24:23.107
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach continue to reinforce the key considerations of customers, value, & service at the heart of ITSM considerations, look at RACI charts-RACI matrix, Accountable Person compared to Responsible Person, Process Owners, Process Managers, Risk Management, Security Management, and the progression of Knowledge to Wisdom.
episodes.title: Key Concepts of ITIL Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.623
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.623 --> 00:00:06.666
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.666 --> 00:00:08.246
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.246 --> 00:00:11.968
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.968 --> 00:00:14.342
>> Hello again, thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.342 --> 00:00:16.560
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:20.220
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC.

8
00:00:20.220 --> 00:00:21.740
Lots of great episodes in this.

9
00:00:21.740 --> 00:00:25.315
This is part two though
of key concepts of ITIL.

10
00:00:25.315 --> 00:00:28.580
And bringing us all the information
we need is Terry Decker.

11
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:29.990
Terry, good to see you again, sir.

12
00:00:29.990 --> 00:00:31.230
>> Glad to be here as always.

13
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:32.480
>> We're still here on the ITIL island.

14
00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:33.303
>> That's right, and

15
00:00:33.303 --> 00:00:36.360
what we're trying to do is try to
formally build some sandcastles in MALC.

16
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:37.020
>> God, that's fun.

17
00:00:37.020 --> 00:00:39.694
>> Build a perfect little sandcastle
to get our little ducks in a row there.

18
00:00:39.694 --> 00:00:41.760
So yeah, as you mentioned,

19
00:00:41.760 --> 00:00:46.428
we're looking a little bit deeper
at some key concepts of ITIL.

20
00:00:46.428 --> 00:00:50.890
We just got through in the previous
episode talking about the functions,

21
00:00:50.890 --> 00:00:55.480
service desk, IT operations management,
technical management, and

22
00:00:55.480 --> 00:00:56.860
application management.

23
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:59.590
And all these different people
doing all kinds of things.

24
00:00:59.590 --> 00:01:02.530
What can kinda help them out is
if you define their roles and

25
00:01:02.530 --> 00:01:04.700
their responsibilities appropriately.

26
00:01:04.700 --> 00:01:07.990
>> And again it's people,
tools, skills, right?

27
00:01:07.990 --> 00:01:10.810
>> That's right, that's what a function
is, thank you for that, that's right.

28
00:01:10.810 --> 00:01:14.420
A function is a group of people
with special skills or tools.

29
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:19.253
So a very special definition of the word
function is being played out here in ITIL.

30
00:01:19.253 --> 00:01:21.027
So we talked about those functions,

31
00:01:21.027 --> 00:01:23.325
a group of people with all
kinds of things to do.

32
00:01:23.325 --> 00:01:25.845
We need to provide some order to that, and

33
00:01:25.845 --> 00:01:30.250
ITIL comes to the answer to that
question through the use of RACI charts.

34
00:01:30.250 --> 00:01:34.560
So as you look at the graphic here,
a RACI Matrix, right?

35
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:38.030
We've seen these before, we've seen them
in virtually every one of the courses.

36
00:01:38.030 --> 00:01:41.920
And the key rules of thumb here is that,
you only have one accountable for

37
00:01:41.920 --> 00:01:42.790
any given activity.

38
00:01:42.790 --> 00:01:46.050
If you look at the graphic here,
it's kinda small print there.

39
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:49.060
But you've got Activity 1, you have
the director of service management

40
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:52.340
accountable and responsible for
whatever Activity 1 might be.

41
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:55.760
Of course, you'd be naming the specific
activities as you went down through here.

42
00:01:55.760 --> 00:01:57.720
So you see how it's a matrix.

43
00:01:57.720 --> 00:02:00.840
Only one accountable for
any given activity.

44
00:02:00.840 --> 00:02:04.710
Because accountable people,
they make sure things get done.

45
00:02:04.710 --> 00:02:06.450
That's what accountable means here.

46
00:02:06.450 --> 00:02:08.460
They make sure it gets done.

47
00:02:08.460 --> 00:02:10.470
That doesn't mean they do anything.

48
00:02:10.470 --> 00:02:11.700
In fact, it's quite opposite.

49
00:02:11.700 --> 00:02:16.130
Accountable people don't
necessarily write that test case,

50
00:02:16.130 --> 00:02:20.470
or execute that script,
right, or make that approval.

51
00:02:20.470 --> 00:02:23.532
But they are accountable to
make sure those steps are done.

52
00:02:23.532 --> 00:02:27.234
So because accountable people
don't actually do anything, right,

53
00:02:27.234 --> 00:02:31.326
you'd have to have, for any given
activity you'd have to have at least 1 R.

54
00:02:31.326 --> 00:02:34.765
Now that doesn't mean that any
given person, like an example here,

55
00:02:34.765 --> 00:02:38.565
the director of service management is
both accountable and responsible for

56
00:02:38.565 --> 00:02:40.160
whatever Activity 1 is.

57
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:44.210
That's completely legal,
right, totally legitimate.

58
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:46.870
Only one accountable for
any given activity.

59
00:02:46.870 --> 00:02:49.360
And at least one responsible

60
00:02:49.360 --> 00:02:52.260
because accountable people don't
actually do anything, right?

61
00:02:52.260 --> 00:02:53.130
That's some rules of thumb.

62
00:02:53.130 --> 00:02:57.090
So if you're on an exam and
there's an exam environment and

63
00:02:57.090 --> 00:03:00.210
you're evaluating RACI charts,
you might be able to get rid of

64
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:03.470
the zero answer right away by just
looking for the violation of those rules.

65
00:03:03.470 --> 00:03:05.530
Without diving into the details,

66
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.320
you can just look at how many
A's does any given line have?

67
00:03:09.320 --> 00:03:13.900
And if one of the lines has more than
one A, that can't be the five answer.

68
00:03:13.900 --> 00:03:15.200
So just stop considering it.

69
00:03:15.200 --> 00:03:16.750
It's gonna be wrong.

70
00:03:16.750 --> 00:03:18.450
So sometimes just
following the rules without

71
00:03:18.450 --> 00:03:19.798
the details can help you out there, right?

72
00:03:21.270 --> 00:03:23.160
The way I remember this about accountable,

73
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:27.600
I learned it very specifically
in first aid training.

74
00:03:27.600 --> 00:03:30.590
If you come up on a victim and
you're gonna be administering first aid,

75
00:03:30.590 --> 00:03:33.768
you don't just shout out,
someone call 911.

76
00:03:33.768 --> 00:03:38.100
You point to someone and
say you, call 911.

77
00:03:38.100 --> 00:03:41.048
So you were accountable in
assigning the responsibility, but

78
00:03:41.048 --> 00:03:43.335
you were very clear in your assignment,
right?

79
00:03:43.335 --> 00:03:44.950
You gave it to a specific person.

80
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:46.110
>> Delegation of duties.

81
00:03:46.110 --> 00:03:46.860
>> Exactly.

82
00:03:46.860 --> 00:03:51.180
And it's transparent delegation,
we know who's on-point for this, right?

83
00:03:51.180 --> 00:03:52.900
We know who's supposed to be doing it.

84
00:03:52.900 --> 00:03:57.850
If I am the service level manager,
and I look down the column, and

85
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:01.910
I see an R next to three
different activities.

86
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:05.440
And I know that everyone else is seeing
an R next to those three activities.

87
00:04:05.440 --> 00:04:07.990
I know those are the people expecting
me to get those things done as well.

88
00:04:07.990 --> 00:04:10.500
So not only is it transparent, and

89
00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:14.390
a way to kind of divide
the activities among various people.

90
00:04:14.390 --> 00:04:17.120
It's in its transparency
also even motivating,

91
00:04:17.120 --> 00:04:19.566
everyone knows what they're
supposed to be doing.

92
00:04:19.566 --> 00:04:21.910
So if we're meeting once a week or

93
00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:27.100
once a month on these activities and
my name is next to three different Rs,

94
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:31.210
I'm expected next month to
review on my particular actions.

95
00:04:31.210 --> 00:04:35.460
I'm gonna be more reliable perhaps
because we've made this transparent.

96
00:04:35.460 --> 00:04:39.321
It's also a way if you heavily dose
someone up with a bunch of Rs,

97
00:04:39.321 --> 00:04:43.912
once you play this out, say wow,
you've got a lot of responsibility here.

98
00:04:43.912 --> 00:04:46.073
Should we divide that up a little bit?

99
00:04:46.073 --> 00:04:51.310
That's also a way you can kinda
pass around the pain, if you will.

100
00:04:51.310 --> 00:04:54.090
Now another key reminder
here about accountable and

101
00:04:54.090 --> 00:04:55.900
responsible as plays out in ITIL.

102
00:04:57.170 --> 00:05:00.750
You might be asked to discern
the accountability and

103
00:05:00.750 --> 00:05:05.220
responsibility of a process owner or
a process manager.

104
00:05:05.220 --> 00:05:09.270
Generally speaking, a process owner
is accountable for things and

105
00:05:09.270 --> 00:05:11.370
a manager is responsible for things.

106
00:05:11.370 --> 00:05:13.980
A manager is managing
the day to day things.

107
00:05:13.980 --> 00:05:17.310
Now if the RACI chart is
getting into the details

108
00:05:17.310 --> 00:05:20.010
of the difference between
a process owner and

109
00:05:20.010 --> 00:05:24.660
a process manager, then certainly process
owners have responsibilities too.

110
00:05:24.660 --> 00:05:27.895
But if it's at a high level, you'll find
the process owner is probably gonna be

111
00:05:27.895 --> 00:05:29.540
more accountable than responsible.

112
00:05:29.540 --> 00:05:32.480
Just a little tell-tale sign here.

113
00:05:33.770 --> 00:05:37.480
So dividing and
conquering the various activities, and

114
00:05:37.480 --> 00:05:43.530
transparently displaying them through
RACI Matrices is an ITIL best practice.

115
00:05:43.530 --> 00:05:47.341
The way this plays out
on exams is more often,

116
00:05:47.341 --> 00:05:50.350
you get to evaluate a RACI Matrix and

117
00:05:50.350 --> 00:05:55.384
determine which one is the best
division of effort, okay?

118
00:05:55.384 --> 00:05:57.260
Now, Risk Management.

119
00:05:57.260 --> 00:06:02.120
Now ITIL itself is not a formal
risk management discipline.

120
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:07.360
So a deep dive into risk management
themes is not what this is about.

121
00:06:07.360 --> 00:06:11.560
Understanding that risk is part of
delivering IT services, of course,

122
00:06:11.560 --> 00:06:12.420
is important.

123
00:06:12.420 --> 00:06:14.280
If you wanna deliver
high value IT services,

124
00:06:14.280 --> 00:06:17.030
you need to understand risk
management at a fundamental level.

125
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:17.960
You really do.

126
00:06:17.960 --> 00:06:23.330
If you want a deeper dive into this, you
can certainly go to the institute there.

127
00:06:23.330 --> 00:06:27.980
MoR is a registered trademark of
the same people that bring you ITIL.

128
00:06:27.980 --> 00:06:30.780
They have a discipline for
formal risk management.

129
00:06:30.780 --> 00:06:32.811
I wanna keep this simple.

130
00:06:32.811 --> 00:06:37.268
Risk management is one
part identification.

131
00:06:37.268 --> 00:06:39.200
That is the significant
part of risk management.

132
00:06:40.270 --> 00:06:44.880
And in the identification, you're
also assessing the likelihood of this

133
00:06:44.880 --> 00:06:49.260
risk happening, the probability and
the impact if it does.

134
00:06:49.260 --> 00:06:54.330
So it's one part identification which
includes the assessment of that risk,

135
00:06:54.330 --> 00:06:56.850
how likely is it happening and
what's the impact if it does?

136
00:06:57.960 --> 00:07:02.690
And it's also a second part mitigation,
if you will.

137
00:07:02.690 --> 00:07:04.760
So you can't mitigate what
you haven't identified.

138
00:07:05.770 --> 00:07:07.240
So let me just make that even simpler.

139
00:07:08.570 --> 00:07:11.900
Having a registry of your risks,
knowing them and

140
00:07:11.900 --> 00:07:16.512
transparently displaying them,
this is a risk, is very valuable.

141
00:07:16.512 --> 00:07:19.173
It's not eyes wide shut,
it's eyes wide open, right?

142
00:07:20.230 --> 00:07:24.350
You are looking at the risks
transparently for all to see, and

143
00:07:24.350 --> 00:07:26.320
some of them are gonna be acceptable.

144
00:07:26.320 --> 00:07:28.410
And even if they are really,
really risky and

145
00:07:28.410 --> 00:07:32.220
the impact is really high,
you might have to accept that risk.

146
00:07:32.220 --> 00:07:36.550
But at least you won't be blindsided if
that risk actually becomes reality, and

147
00:07:36.550 --> 00:07:38.970
you have to deal with it later on, okay?

148
00:07:38.970 --> 00:07:44.250
So the part about risk management that's
almost as important as the mitigation

149
00:07:44.250 --> 00:07:46.530
is the actual eyes-open identification.

150
00:07:46.530 --> 00:07:49.390
You know where you're going and
what you're trying to do.

151
00:07:49.390 --> 00:07:55.610
In the ITIL scheme of things, all 26
processes have an effect of reducing risk.

152
00:07:55.610 --> 00:07:57.720
By this I mean at a very high level,

153
00:07:57.720 --> 00:08:01.150
in the absence of an instant
management process, for instance.

154
00:08:01.150 --> 00:08:05.118
You're risking a defective way to interact
with end users when they call and

155
00:08:05.118 --> 00:08:05.992
have a problem.

156
00:08:05.992 --> 00:08:11.039
In the absence of availability management,
you're risking the chance of

157
00:08:11.039 --> 00:08:16.015
having applications that fall over
all the time, as an example, right?

158
00:08:16.015 --> 00:08:20.613
So all of the processes have at
least some aspect of risk management

159
00:08:20.613 --> 00:08:22.101
involved with them.

160
00:08:22.101 --> 00:08:23.778
But among all the processes,

161
00:08:23.778 --> 00:08:27.410
there are two processes that
directly affect risk management.

162
00:08:27.410 --> 00:08:30.700
They have risk management
as a very specific focus.

163
00:08:30.700 --> 00:08:33.830
That's continuity management and
security management.

164
00:08:33.830 --> 00:08:37.438
Both of those processes happen to play
in heavily with that kind of focus,

165
00:08:37.438 --> 00:08:38.029
all right?

166
00:08:39.330 --> 00:08:40.801
Now Knowledge Management.

167
00:08:44.550 --> 00:08:48.996
Having a culture of sharing
knowledge is important,

168
00:08:48.996 --> 00:08:53.540
and I have worked in organizations
of various sizes and

169
00:08:53.540 --> 00:08:57.920
various complexities over
my years of experience.

170
00:08:57.920 --> 00:09:02.060
Some were really good and had a really
good culture of sharing knowledge.

171
00:09:02.060 --> 00:09:06.050
And I've worked in other ones
where knowledge was the power and

172
00:09:06.050 --> 00:09:07.360
the politics of things.

173
00:09:07.360 --> 00:09:10.150
I'm not gonna tell you,
I know this, you don't, right?

174
00:09:10.150 --> 00:09:11.759
I've also worked in that kind of culture.

175
00:09:11.759 --> 00:09:16.165
Obviously, I think it's obviously, the one
that shares knowledge more readily,

176
00:09:16.165 --> 00:09:19.964
is gonna be more successful than
the one that holds it too close, right?

177
00:09:19.964 --> 00:09:23.382
Give you an example, and again,
this is not an ITIL recommendation, but

178
00:09:23.382 --> 00:09:26.527
it is consulting with an organization
that actually had a goal, and

179
00:09:26.527 --> 00:09:29.581
I'm not saying this is one you
should aspire to, I'm not at all.

180
00:09:29.581 --> 00:09:35.123
But they had a goal that 100% of
the calls to their service desk,

181
00:09:35.123 --> 00:09:39.120
100% would be resolved
by the service desk.

182
00:09:40.420 --> 00:09:42.600
Now again, I am not saying
that is a worthy aspiration,

183
00:09:42.600 --> 00:09:45.610
I am not suggesting that ITIL
is not suggesting that either.

184
00:09:45.610 --> 00:09:47.068
But I want you to consider that goal.

185
00:09:47.068 --> 00:09:52.660
100% of calls to the service desk
are resolved by the service desk.

186
00:09:53.670 --> 00:09:57.684
What does that mean for knowledge sharing?

187
00:09:57.684 --> 00:10:02.963
Whose behavior, regarding knowledge
management, needs to change?

188
00:10:02.963 --> 00:10:06.020
Well, certainly the service
desk needs to get smarter.

189
00:10:06.020 --> 00:10:07.630
Their behavior's gonna change.

190
00:10:07.630 --> 00:10:10.160
Maybe your job descriptions,

maybe HR has to rework the job

00:10:13.230 --> 00:10:17.370
to attract the type of talent that's gonna

193
00:10:17.370 --> 00:10:20.200
But what about the backend,

194
00:10:20.200 --> 00:10:23.860
How is their behavior changing to enable

00:10:23.860 --> 00:10:28.370
such a worthy goal or
unworthy goal for that matter, right?

196
00:10:28.370 --> 00:10:32.690
So again, knowledge sharing is what
that particular goal had in mind, right?

197
00:10:32.690 --> 00:10:33.860
So maybe it was aspirational.

198
00:10:33.860 --> 00:10:35.180
Maybe they'll never get there.

199
00:10:35.180 --> 00:10:38.130
But they were trying to
motivate an organization toward

200
00:10:38.130 --> 00:10:42.260
giving up knowledge and making it
more readily accessible to others.

201
00:10:42.260 --> 00:10:46.620
Again, this is an example of an
environment that could be highly sharing,

202
00:10:46.620 --> 00:10:49.040
versus one that kind of
keeps things closer.

203
00:10:50.750 --> 00:10:53.130
Knowledge management, ultimately-
>> Good example, Terry.

204
00:10:53.130 --> 00:10:54.010
>> Good.
>> Very nice.

205
00:10:54.010 --> 00:10:58.540
>> Good, so another example, or really
what knowledge management is trying to do,

206
00:10:58.540 --> 00:11:05.340
is move data, raw data toward wisdom and
the steps in between, right?

207
00:11:05.340 --> 00:11:08.047
So a knowledge management system,
as it will,

208
00:11:08.047 --> 00:11:11.498
I think if you look up the word
system in a more generic sense,

209
00:11:11.498 --> 00:11:15.784
you'll find lots of things moving
together toward a common goal, right?

210
00:11:15.784 --> 00:11:20.040
I think IT, we often think of system
as something that you go out and buy.

211
00:11:20.040 --> 00:11:22.610
I'm gonna go buy a configuration
management system.

212
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:25.741
I wanna configure it and it's gonna work
well for configuration management, right?

213
00:11:25.741 --> 00:11:28.130
You go out and
buy something that helps you do it.

214
00:11:28.130 --> 00:11:30.911
When you consider
Service Knowledge Management System,

215
00:11:30.911 --> 00:11:34.610
I think you're considering something
that's more classic in definition.

216
00:11:34.610 --> 00:11:37.430
A lot of things working
together toward a common goal.

217
00:11:37.430 --> 00:11:41.280
And the common goal is to
transform data into information,

218
00:11:41.280 --> 00:11:45.130
information into knowledge,
and knowledge into wisdom,

219
00:11:45.130 --> 00:11:48.720
graphically shown here
this transformation.

220
00:11:48.720 --> 00:11:53.324
So the closer you get to wisdom, now
eventually systems aren't gonna play out.

221
00:11:53.324 --> 00:11:54.999
People are gonna have to be involved.

222
00:11:54.999 --> 00:11:58.257
It's a human endeavor to
convert knowledge into wisdom.

223
00:11:58.257 --> 00:12:00.060
It's not in computer IT.

224
00:12:00.060 --> 00:12:03.666
I mean, as close as we get to artificial
intelligence, we still are involving

225
00:12:03.666 --> 00:12:07.069
humans quite a bit in this transformation
between knowledge and wisdom.

226
00:12:07.069 --> 00:12:09.710
>> And wisdom is knowledge in action, yes?

227
00:12:09.710 --> 00:12:11.570
>> Good call, absolutely, good call.

228
00:12:11.570 --> 00:12:13.030
I like that,
I'm gonna quote you on that one.

229
00:12:13.030 --> 00:12:14.503
>> Thank you.
>> That's not copyrighted or anything?

230
00:12:14.503 --> 00:12:16.082
>> I think I got it from
a guy named Solomon.

231
00:12:16.082 --> 00:12:16.995
I don't know.
[LAUGH]

232
00:12:16.995 --> 00:12:18.731
>> Okay, Solomon maybe said that,

233
00:12:18.731 --> 00:12:20.346
all right, wise man as he was.

234
00:12:20.346 --> 00:12:22.080
It is wisdom in action.

235
00:12:22.080 --> 00:12:26.174
Absolutely, it's making informed decisions
based on all the knowledge you have, and

236
00:12:26.174 --> 00:12:27.230
it's cyclical too.

237
00:12:27.230 --> 00:12:30.420
And it's even a spiral, if you will,
you get better at this, right?

238
00:12:30.420 --> 00:12:32.065
So transforming data and

239
00:12:32.065 --> 00:12:37.167
information to knowledge into wisdom
is a big part of knowledge management.

240
00:12:37.167 --> 00:12:41.879
Now again, I'm gonna look at this
rather big little example here.

241
00:12:41.879 --> 00:12:44.321
Big, little,
[LAUGH] this little example of-

242
00:12:44.321 --> 00:12:44.904
>> Little big books.

243
00:12:44.904 --> 00:12:45.719
>> Yeah, little big books.

244
00:12:47.350 --> 00:12:52.690
A Service Knowledge Management System
would be hard to put on a single page.

245
00:12:52.690 --> 00:12:57.635
Imagine the data required, all the data
you've collected in the IT organization.

246
00:12:57.635 --> 00:13:02.110
Imagine all the documents that are there
with information inside them, right?

247
00:13:02.110 --> 00:13:06.926
And then imagine presenting that
information in a way that imparts

248
00:13:06.926 --> 00:13:07.875
knowledge.

249
00:13:07.875 --> 00:13:10.574
I mean, this is not a trivial matter,
right, and

250
00:13:10.574 --> 00:13:13.613
there's not gonna be a picture
that does justice to it.

251
00:13:13.613 --> 00:13:16.182
If you go to the example here,
you have a CMDB and

252
00:13:16.182 --> 00:13:18.635
perhaps multiple of them
here in the bottom.

253
00:13:18.635 --> 00:13:20.918
Let me get my pointer here.

254
00:13:22.422 --> 00:13:26.420
You got the CMDB,
configuration management database.

255
00:13:26.420 --> 00:13:30.490
You might have multiples of those,
and they form a single CMS

256
00:13:30.490 --> 00:13:33.290
across the enterprise,
configuration management system.

257
00:13:33.290 --> 00:13:38.611
I often describe the CMS as a big
boat with lots of containers on it,

258
00:13:38.611 --> 00:13:42.231
and the containers being the CMDBs, right?

259
00:13:42.231 --> 00:13:45.910
Well, if that analogy were to hold forth,
if a CMS is a boat,

260
00:13:45.910 --> 00:13:50.672
and the CMDBs are the multiple containers
on that one single boat, then SKMS,

261
00:13:50.672 --> 00:13:54.085
the Service Knowledge Management System
is the ocean.

262
00:13:54.085 --> 00:13:58.298
Cuz there's so many other things out
there, there's other boats of information,

263
00:13:58.298 --> 00:13:59.855
there's other data sources.

264
00:13:59.855 --> 00:14:04.005
You have HR data, you have performance
data, you have financial data,

265
00:14:04.005 --> 00:14:07.611
you have change data,
you have incident data, problem data,

266
00:14:07.611 --> 00:14:11.782
availability management plans,
you have capacity management plans.

267
00:14:11.782 --> 00:14:15.670
So it's a flood, I mean,
an ocean of information.

268
00:14:15.670 --> 00:14:19.800
Knowledge management as a system,
again, in a classic sense,

269
00:14:19.800 --> 00:14:25.640
a lot of different things working together
is a tough boat to row if you will.

270
00:14:25.640 --> 00:14:28.950
It's a tough one, right,
also very important.

271
00:14:28.950 --> 00:14:32.200
So a big part of strategizing for

272
00:14:32.200 --> 00:14:37.670
managing across a life cycle
is enabling knowledge sharing.

273
00:14:37.670 --> 00:14:42.220
Enabling the presentation of
information for more rapid and

274
00:14:42.220 --> 00:14:44.200
accurate decision making, wisdom.

275
00:14:45.300 --> 00:14:49.030
So as you're looking at
the landscape of service management,

276
00:14:49.030 --> 00:14:52.030
you are necessarily looking at
the landscape of knowledge.

277
00:14:52.030 --> 00:14:56.950
And how can you spread it,
and more effectively

278
00:14:56.950 --> 00:15:01.810
liberate it from the data and
information that underlies it.

279
00:15:01.810 --> 00:15:02.520
So to do that,

280
00:15:02.520 --> 00:15:05.380
you're really trying to come up with
a knowledge management strategy.

281
00:15:05.380 --> 00:15:08.640
What data's important to us,
what information's important to us?

282
00:15:08.640 --> 00:15:11.850
How perishable is it,
how long do we have to hang on to it?

283
00:15:11.850 --> 00:15:13.570
Who are the appropriate audiences?

284
00:15:13.570 --> 00:15:16.230
Are we talking about
training vehicles here?

285
00:15:16.230 --> 00:15:19.307
Are we talking about
presentation vehicles?

286
00:15:19.307 --> 00:15:20.779
All of the above.

287
00:15:20.779 --> 00:15:25.335
There's not one size fits all in any
given organization, that's for sure.

288
00:15:25.335 --> 00:15:26.665
Not a trivial matter,

289
00:15:26.665 --> 00:15:31.385
something definitely worth considering
at a holistic strategic view.

290
00:15:31.385 --> 00:15:36.024
How are we managing our data assets
is really what this comes down to?

291
00:15:36.024 --> 00:15:39.100
And of course, that could play
out the knowledge transfer.

292
00:15:39.100 --> 00:15:41.030
Knowledge transfer dealing with training.

293
00:15:41.030 --> 00:15:42.440
Go take a course, right?

294
00:15:42.440 --> 00:15:46.630
A known error database is knowledge
transfer from the problem management team

295
00:15:46.630 --> 00:15:48.130
to the incident management team.

296
00:15:48.130 --> 00:15:51.172
You might remember the known error
database from service operations.

297
00:15:51.172 --> 00:15:53.385
We'll have another look at
that a little bit later on.

298
00:15:53.385 --> 00:15:58.141
But again service knowledge being
transferred to other people could be

299
00:15:58.141 --> 00:15:59.973
through formal training.

300
00:15:59.973 --> 00:16:03.010
It could be through formal vehicles.

301
00:16:03.010 --> 00:16:05.570
We go to this website for that,
we go to that website for

302
00:16:05.570 --> 00:16:07.230
this, those types of things.

303
00:16:07.230 --> 00:16:11.522
A map of where information is could be
an important deliverable of the service

304
00:16:11.522 --> 00:16:12.782
knowledge strategy.

305
00:16:14.888 --> 00:16:18.180
Of course, it feeds into CSI.

306
00:16:19.200 --> 00:16:24.410
If you think about how good a service is
performing or how poorly a service is

307
00:16:24.410 --> 00:16:29.850
performing, underneath that performance
assessment are customer opinions,

308
00:16:29.850 --> 00:16:34.400
perhaps, survey results, process results.

309
00:16:34.400 --> 00:16:36.510
How are your processes performing?

310
00:16:36.510 --> 00:16:39.033
That's data,
that's knowledge you're gaining.

311
00:16:39.033 --> 00:16:43.776
An effective knowledge management
regime will feed your continual service

312
00:16:43.776 --> 00:16:45.193
improvement regime.

313
00:16:45.193 --> 00:16:47.443
You won't be moving forward blindly.

314
00:16:47.443 --> 00:16:51.556
You'll be moving forward with good data,
good information and good knowledge so

315
00:16:51.556 --> 00:16:55.150

on what should be improved.

316
00:16:55.150 --> 00:16:58.540
So let me sum this whole thing up

317
00:17:00.530 --> 00:17:05.300
If you, at a strategic level, consider
IT service management capabilities

318
00:17:05.300 --> 00:17:09.170

that's what ITIL invites you to do.

319
00:17:10.940 --> 00:17:15.690
IT service management becomes a strategic
asset, managing across a life cycle.

320
00:17:15.690 --> 00:17:19.890
This particular course material,
the exam and back at the office

321
00:17:19.890 --> 00:17:23.330
is inviting you to look at IT service
management as a strategic asset.

322
00:17:24.550 --> 00:17:28.700
The reason why you wanna
consider it a strategic asset is

323
00:17:28.700 --> 00:17:33.280
because you want to improve your position
as it relates to your customers.

324
00:17:33.280 --> 00:17:37.710
You wanna become that strategic
asset that they rely on to

325
00:17:37.710 --> 00:17:38.990
achieve their business outcomes.

326
00:17:40.240 --> 00:17:42.940
Mapping where you are now

327
00:17:42.940 --> 00:17:46.329
to where you wanna be is mapping
an improvement strategy.

328
00:17:47.560 --> 00:17:49.000
Knowledge management is
gonna be key to that.

329
00:17:50.380 --> 00:17:51.360
That's that.

00:17:51.360 --> 00:17:52.020
>> Excellent.

>> Yeah.
>> Once again, and

I'm Zach Memos.

00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:28.470

the message, communication and

stakeholders are both important.

00:00:54.780 --> 00:00:56.650
As you might guess,

Relationship Management, is alive and

00:01:09.740 --> 00:01:13.100
well throughout each
stage of the life cycle.

00:01:13.100 --> 00:01:18.030
Again, we've touched on this before, in
previous intermediate classes perhaps, but

24
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:20.580
the reinforcement here is how you take

25
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:24.020
a strategic view at communication
in stakeholder management.

26
00:01:24.020 --> 00:01:28.980
And certainly BRM is involved at the
earliest stage of the strategic review.

27
00:01:28.980 --> 00:01:33.940
It's in the service strategy where you
are discerning customers needs and

28
00:01:33.940 --> 00:01:37.400
customer requirements, and
you're trying to sell them, perhaps.

29
00:01:37.400 --> 00:01:42.210
This marketing mindset is often going to
be delivered through the eyes of BRM if

30
00:01:43.310 --> 00:01:43.960
you will.

31
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:49.710
While BRM is born in server's strategy,
it's alive and well throughout the stages.

32
00:01:49.710 --> 00:01:53.140
This important stage in service strategy
is ascertaining just what is the business

00:01:53.140 --> 00:01:58.220
trying to accomplish, and what IT services
can be brought to bear to help them

00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:00.550
reach those business outcomes, right.

35
00:02:00.550 --> 00:02:05.330
So then moving forward then from
strategy onto service design,

36
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:07.080
the next stage of the life cycle.

37
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:10.270
BRM is also alive there trying to

38
00:02:10.270 --> 00:02:13.730
bridge the gap between the high
level requirements and

39
00:02:13.730 --> 00:02:17.700
the service level requirements that
must be designed into the service.

40
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:20.990
Perhaps, we need to schedule
what success looks like,

41
00:02:20.990 --> 00:02:22.720
or ascertain what success looks like.

42
00:02:22.720 --> 00:02:26.880
What measurements are going to be
brought to bear that show the success of

43
00:02:26.880 --> 00:02:27.706
the service?

44
00:02:27.706 --> 00:02:33.400
BRM can be there as the liason between
these IT people and the business people,

45
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:39.437
trying to discern just what we should be
measuring, how we should look at success,

46
00:02:39.437 --> 00:02:44.120
what are the service acceptance
criteria actually going to be.

47
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:45.340
So BRM is going to help you there.

48
00:02:45.340 --> 00:02:48.620
And then moving in to transition,
BRM is alive and

49
00:02:48.620 --> 00:02:52.330
well because it's in service
transition that we're validating,

50
00:02:52.330 --> 00:02:55.050
that we're satisfying
the service acceptance criteria.

51
00:02:55.050 --> 00:02:59.650
Whatever we decided to measure,
whatever we determined was going to, what

52
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:03.920
success was going to look like is going to
be validated here in service transition.

53
00:03:03.920 --> 00:03:06.090
So BRM is there if things go awry,

54
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:10.210
BRM is there if things are going well,
BRM is there, right?

55
00:03:10.210 --> 00:03:14.990
Now its just,
the way to look at this is as a process,

56
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:18.380
business relationship management is
on-going throughout all the stages.

57
00:03:18.380 --> 00:03:21.420
I don't want you to necessarily
think of this as a person,

58
00:03:21.420 --> 00:03:25.700
that there is a person necessarily
responsible all the way through here.

59
00:03:25.700 --> 00:03:29.500
That's not necessarily the way to look
at how the process is playing out.

60
00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:33.830
But then again it could be a given person,
this kinda care and

61
00:03:33.830 --> 00:03:37.170
feeding this relationship
all the way through, right.

62
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:41.070
Certainly when you get into operations,
as you get into service of operations,

63
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.300
you gonna be concerned about
the customer satisfaction.

64
00:03:44.300 --> 00:03:48.700
So way back up in strategy
you discern the requirements.

65
00:03:48.700 --> 00:03:52.600
You, through design make sure that service
acceptance criteria was acceptable to both

66
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:55.600
sides, IT and the customer.

67
00:03:55.600 --> 00:04:00.300
In service transition, you verify, or
validate, that acceptance criteria's been

68
00:04:00.300 --> 00:04:05.680
met, but actually the validation is
going to be coming in operations, right.

69
00:04:05.680 --> 00:04:08.240
It's not until you get
the service operation

70
00:04:08.240 --> 00:04:10.790
that you actually deliver
the value that's intended.

71
00:04:10.790 --> 00:04:14.710
So, if you promised that this new IT
service was going to help the customer

72
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:19.160
sell more widgets, or find more oil,
or find it more quickly.

73
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:23.210
Whatever your service was promising,
is that being delivered?

74
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:27.110
That won't be delivered until
the service is actually operational, so

75
00:04:27.110 --> 00:04:28.740
BRM is right there.

76
00:04:28.740 --> 00:04:33.510
So if sales remain stagnant, and
oil takes just as long to find as before,

77
00:04:33.510 --> 00:04:35.830
you're probably going to hear
from the customers a little bit.

78
00:04:35.830 --> 00:04:37.560
BRM's gonna be there with
their ears open a little bit.

79
00:04:37.560 --> 00:04:38.730
How's it going?

80
00:04:38.730 --> 00:04:41.890
Are we helping you sell more widgets or
