That's what design is trying to answer.

312
00:18:08.570 --> 00:18:11.420
So along the way, you're gonna
be communicating these things.

313
00:18:11.420 --> 00:18:15.909
And communicating this through service
transition is a big piece of it.

314
00:18:15.909 --> 00:18:19.869
So you've made some strategic
decisions with the customer involved,

315
00:18:19.869 --> 00:18:23.920
you've made some design decisions
with the customer involved.

316
00:18:23.920 --> 00:18:29.010
And now you're gonna recommit with
the customers and other stakeholders, not

317
00:18:29.010 --> 00:18:33.410
just the customer stakeholders, a way to
validate the design is actually effective.

318
00:18:34.670 --> 00:18:38.900
So you might get involved in user
acceptance testing, the customers that is.

319
00:18:38.900 --> 00:18:42.132
You might get the availability managers,
an IT group,

320
00:18:42.132 --> 00:18:46.060
available to test for availability or
capacity or security.

321
00:18:46.060 --> 00:18:50.170
You may have some security compliance
sign off or check off as part of

322
00:18:50.170 --> 00:18:54.480
the transition to make sure everything is
right on the security side of things, etc.

323
00:18:54.480 --> 00:18:56.010
Are the suppliers ready to go?

324
00:18:56.010 --> 00:18:56.980
Are the contracts signed?

325
00:18:58.180 --> 00:18:59.030
Are they ready to perform?

326
00:18:59.030 --> 00:19:01.600
Has training been performed or executed?

327
00:19:01.600 --> 00:19:04.030
Has knowledge been transferred
to the right people?

328
00:19:04.030 --> 00:19:05.820
Is the service desk ready?

329
00:19:05.820 --> 00:19:08.580
These things are going on, lots of
different stakeholders with lots of

330
00:19:08.580 --> 00:19:11.820
different stakes in the game,
and service transition,

331
00:19:11.820 --> 00:19:14.200
you're bringing them all together,
you're bringing them to life.

332
00:19:14.200 --> 00:19:17.200
So that they're validated and acceptable.

333
00:19:17.200 --> 00:19:19.660
Service accept this criteria has been met.

334
00:19:19.660 --> 00:19:24.500
And then, of course, you bring it to,
through transition, through workshops,

335
00:19:24.500 --> 00:19:26.820
through training organization,
newsletters.

336
00:19:26.820 --> 00:19:29.650
Organizational meetings, lots of things.

337
00:19:30.650 --> 00:19:33.120
Lots of ways of communicating,
always in play.

338
00:19:33.120 --> 00:19:36.250
So consider the media is
the message sometimes.

339
00:19:36.250 --> 00:19:37.680
Is it a great big global meaning?

340
00:19:37.680 --> 00:19:39.310
Everyone's there at the same time.

341
00:19:39.310 --> 00:19:41.540
Is it sub team meetings?

342
00:19:41.540 --> 00:19:43.270
Is it face to face training?

343
00:19:43.270 --> 00:19:46.140
Is is something you say,
hey go take this module online.

344
00:19:46.140 --> 00:19:47.795
Let me know when you've completed it.

345
00:19:47.795 --> 00:19:51.956
Depending on what kind of knowledge you're
trying to impart or how important it is,

346
00:19:51.956 --> 00:19:55.415
you might have different points of
validation for that training or for

347
00:19:55.415 --> 00:19:56.778
that knowledge transfer.

348
00:19:56.778 --> 00:19:58.875
Again, no magic elixir here.

349
00:19:58.875 --> 00:20:01.650
Just look at it broadly and
cover the bases.

350
00:20:04.310 --> 00:20:07.710
In this particular diagram,
what you're trying to move, you can see,

351
00:20:07.710 --> 00:20:11.420
from current state to the predicted state.

352
00:20:11.420 --> 00:20:14.970
So, we expected certain
things to be in place.

353
00:20:14.970 --> 00:20:16.270
Did we get there?

354
00:20:16.270 --> 00:20:21.830
You could look at it as a before,
after, a change evaluation.

355
00:20:21.830 --> 00:20:24.090
Where it says,
here's what we expect to get.

356
00:20:24.090 --> 00:20:26.800
And then after the change is implemented
you say, did we actually get it?

357
00:20:26.800 --> 00:20:29.990
So there's various ways
to skin this cat but

358
00:20:29.990 --> 00:20:34.150
the overarching importance of this is
you communicate all the way through.

359
00:20:34.150 --> 00:20:38.120
You know what success looks like and
then you ask yourself, did we reach it?

360
00:20:39.300 --> 00:20:42.195
And this happens, not just in transition,

361
00:20:42.195 --> 00:20:46.669
it happens in operations, too,
but you continue to move forward.

362
00:20:49.280 --> 00:20:52.630
All communication must have an intended
purpose or a resulted action.

363
00:20:52.630 --> 00:20:56.450
Let me put this another way,
don't communicate just because.

364
00:20:56.450 --> 00:20:58.735
Communicate with purpose.

365
00:20:58.735 --> 00:21:03.357
And you communicate with purpose
with the audience in mind.

366
00:21:03.357 --> 00:21:06.315
So make it real to the audience
you are sending to.

367
00:21:06.315 --> 00:21:07.925
If action is requested or

368
00:21:07.925 --> 00:21:12.175
required at the end of the communication,
be explicit about what action.

369
00:21:12.175 --> 00:21:15.565
If it's just an FYI,
actually be explicit about that.

370
00:21:15.565 --> 00:21:18.005
This is for information,
no action is required.

371
00:21:19.285 --> 00:21:23.570
It just helps with the communication
by setting expectations,

372
00:21:23.570 --> 00:21:27.820
what's the person, the recipient of
your message supposed to do with it?

373
00:21:27.820 --> 00:21:30.750
Are they supposed to do something
meaningful, in terms of action?

374
00:21:30.750 --> 00:21:33.510
Are they supposed to follow the way for
a future meeting?

375
00:21:33.510 --> 00:21:36.928
Are they supposed to go out and
evaluate something?

376
00:21:36.928 --> 00:21:44.575
So, be clear about the intended purpose
of the particular communication.

377
00:21:47.408 --> 00:21:48.510
How many ways?

378
00:21:48.510 --> 00:21:52.360
You can send them things, you can have
meetings, that's a means of communication,

379
00:21:52.360 --> 00:21:53.860
getting together.

380
00:21:53.860 --> 00:21:55.850
The frequency of the meetings
can also be part of it.

381
00:21:55.850 --> 00:22:00.830
It can also be part of the message, we're
gonna meet everyday until this is fixed,

382
00:22:00.830 --> 00:22:04.350
is a different message than saying,
how about we meet next month and

383
00:22:04.350 --> 00:22:05.190
see how you guys are doing?

384
00:22:06.370 --> 00:22:09.220
Even the frequency of the meetings
can be communicating something.

385
00:22:10.380 --> 00:22:11.860
So I don't wanna wait til
the end of the month.

386
00:22:12.920 --> 00:22:16.460
I wanna meet every day or every week
until we get this thing resolved.

387
00:22:16.460 --> 00:22:17.910
As an example,

388
00:22:17.910 --> 00:22:23.380
the frequency of meetings could also
be part of the communication message.

389
00:22:23.380 --> 00:22:26.780
The medium itself,
is it simply an email or is it a meeting?

390
00:22:26.780 --> 00:22:31.707
Comparing a message being sent to a
meeting, getting people in the same room,

391
00:22:31.707 --> 00:22:34.779
whether it's a virtual room or
a physical room.

392
00:22:34.779 --> 00:22:38.209
Is a different thing than
just sending out an email.

393
00:22:40.639 --> 00:22:44.480
So, coming up with all these various
means or all these stakeholders,

394
00:22:44.480 --> 00:22:48.576
stakeholder map and trying to move them,
suggests that you should actually

395
00:22:48.576 --> 00:22:52.670
be methodical about your
communication strategy and your plan.

396
00:22:52.670 --> 00:22:54.792
Write down what it is you plan to do.

397
00:22:54.792 --> 00:22:58.162
We're gonna meet with the customer
stakeholders once a month.

398
00:22:58.162 --> 00:23:00.582
We're gonna meet with
the design people once a week.

399
00:23:00.582 --> 00:23:03.080
We're gonna meet with
the testers once a week.

400
00:23:03.080 --> 00:23:08.350
We're going to meet with the service
desk once a week, however that might be.

401
00:23:08.350 --> 00:23:11.020
It may start off once a month
with the service desk.

402
00:23:11.020 --> 00:23:13.670
As you get closer to operations
maybe you're meeting every day

403
00:23:13.670 --> 00:23:14.520
with the service desk.

404
00:23:16.130 --> 00:23:18.600
Understanding the frequency
of communication and

405
00:23:18.600 --> 00:23:22.270
the stakeholders, is going to help
drive the strategy and this plan.

406
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:27.133
The media, the way you present
the information is one consideration.

407
00:23:27.133 --> 00:23:29.680
How often you can do it, is another.

408
00:23:29.680 --> 00:23:31.780
And remember, it's not one size fits all.

409
00:23:33.130 --> 00:23:38.053
One blanket statement to all audiences is
effective for some types of communication.

410
00:23:38.053 --> 00:23:41.215
It's disruptive for
other types of communication,

411
00:23:41.215 --> 00:23:45.655
where you need to get very specific to
the actions that need to be required.

412
00:23:45.655 --> 00:23:49.401
So no real magic, somewhat, common sense.

413
00:23:49.401 --> 00:23:52.140
As you take this operationally
back at the office,

414
00:23:52.140 --> 00:23:55.082
having a discipline of
planning your communication.

415
00:23:55.082 --> 00:23:57.521
Is better than just kind of winging it,
right.

416
00:23:57.521 --> 00:24:00.729
And it starts with understanding
your stakeholders, and

417
00:24:00.729 --> 00:24:05.384
understanding what messages need to be
delivered, how often, and to whom, okay?

418
00:24:05.384 --> 00:24:06.303
>> Great.

419
00:24:06.303 --> 00:24:08.070
>> So coming up with a plan, then.

420
00:24:08.070 --> 00:24:12.850
The strategies, the big picture, the plan
is the very specific deliverables.

421
00:24:12.850 --> 00:24:17.830
And once you've done one or
two of these, it becomes almost rote.

422
00:24:17.830 --> 00:24:21.500
You understand your stakeholders better,
you can reuse the plans

423
00:24:21.500 --> 00:24:26.080
from one big project to another,
and just tweak the differences.

424
00:24:26.080 --> 00:24:31.050
It really can be done in a rather
repetitive way, so just get good at it.

425
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:35.470
ITIL is not a communications planning
best practice, it's not intended to be.

426
00:24:35.470 --> 00:24:41.239
But that said, ITIL certain recognizes
the importance of effective communication.

427
00:24:41.239 --> 00:24:46.791
All right, Key exam factors,

428
00:24:46.791 --> 00:24:51.620
so this is really for,I t also helps
you in operational context too.

429
00:24:51.620 --> 00:24:55.660
But as we finish up this particular topic,
key exam factors for

430
00:24:55.660 --> 00:25:00.720
communication is look for,
in the exam,I n the scenario or

431
00:25:00.720 --> 00:25:03.550
within the question,
or within the answers.

432
00:25:03.550 --> 00:25:06.071
And ask the question,
is the communication two-way?

433
00:25:06.071 --> 00:25:10.186
In other words, is there ability to get
feedback from the stakeholder you're

434
00:25:10.186 --> 00:25:13.192
communicating with,
is that built into your planning?

435
00:25:13.192 --> 00:25:16.999
Because communication
should be bidirectional,

436
00:25:16.999 --> 00:25:20.015
not just broadcast and hope they get it.

437
00:25:20.015 --> 00:25:21.945
The feedback could be simple,
it could be simple,

438
00:25:21.945 --> 00:25:25.362
did you get it,
did you understand it, right?

439
00:25:25.362 --> 00:25:26.859
Do you know you have action to do, right?

440
00:25:28.082 --> 00:25:29.772
And of course, the ultimate feedback,

441
00:25:29.772 --> 00:25:32.882
if there's action to be done,
is that the action is completed.

442
00:25:32.882 --> 00:25:34.632
That's why it needs to be two-way.

443
00:25:34.632 --> 00:25:38.348
But even if it's really just informational
only, you want to make sure that they can

444
00:25:38.348 --> 00:25:41.282
feedback to you whether they go it or
not, right?

445
00:25:41.282 --> 00:25:45.102
If they choose not to respond,
you can selectively say, okay,

446
00:25:45.102 --> 00:25:47.952
well they must have understood it,
all right?

447
00:25:47.952 --> 00:25:51.433
Or you could be more proactive and say,
I want to make sure they understand it.

448
00:25:51.433 --> 00:25:54.550
And I'm going to send it again to
them next month, that same message.

449
00:25:55.620 --> 00:25:58.670
Is communication tailored appropriately?

450
00:25:58.670 --> 00:26:00.030
Another good question,

451
00:26:00.030 --> 00:26:06.220
does it meet the stakeholder that
you're trying to target, right?

452
00:26:06.220 --> 00:26:08.770
A business leader's not
going to be too concerned

453
00:26:08.770 --> 00:26:12.650
about the details of how you
manage a test case in UAT.

454
00:26:12.650 --> 00:26:15.880
They wanna know, did UAT pass, right?

455
00:26:15.880 --> 00:26:20.670
Not necessarily the nuances of
the failures of user acceptance testing.

456
00:26:20.670 --> 00:26:25.277
So when you send out the email
regarding the failed attempt at user

457
00:26:25.277 --> 00:26:27.300
acceptance testing, UAT.

458
00:26:27.300 --> 00:26:32.126
When you're sending out that email,
you're gonna send a different email to

459
00:26:32.126 --> 00:26:36.950
the project team, up, than you would
from the project team, down, right,

460
00:26:36.950 --> 00:26:39.540
to the practitioners down below.

461
00:26:39.540 --> 00:26:42.490
So make sure you got the right
audience in mind, and

462
00:26:42.490 --> 00:26:45.880
you're communicating at the right time,
right, further action, etc.

463
00:26:48.520 --> 00:26:54.710
Is communication constant, all right, is
it frequent enough, is it always in play?

464
00:26:54.710 --> 00:26:59.980
This plays back to the two-way part, as
well as communicating at the right time.

465
00:26:59.980 --> 00:27:01.873
Always have the channels open, so

466
00:27:01.873 --> 00:27:05.019
that's one way that communication
is always constant.

467
00:27:05.019 --> 00:27:09.554
But realize that repeating a message
is not necessarily a bad thing.

468
00:27:09.554 --> 00:27:12.668
Especially if time has passed since
the last one, and milestones,

469
00:27:12.668 --> 00:27:15.560
more importantly,
have passed since the last one.

470
00:27:15.560 --> 00:27:18.780
You're getting closer to your targets,
right?

471
00:27:18.780 --> 00:27:22.360
So the message could be right today,
but does not resonate later,

472
00:27:22.360 --> 00:27:25.310
so make sure you you tweak the message
as you go through, as well.

473
00:27:26.390 --> 00:27:27.970
And is communication inclusive?

474
00:27:27.970 --> 00:27:31.130
Now, earlier when I mentioned that
communication should be tailored for

475
00:27:31.130 --> 00:27:35.010
the right audience,
your communication plan

476
00:27:35.010 --> 00:27:37.993
should holistically cover all
your stakeholders, right?

477
00:27:39.720 --> 00:27:42.930
The four major groups that we've talked
about before, the service provider,

478
00:27:42.930 --> 00:27:47.112
the customer, the user, the suppliers, and
all the subtexts underneath those, right?

479
00:27:48.510 --> 00:27:53.021
As you come up with your stakeholder
plan and your communication plan,

480
00:27:53.021 --> 00:27:55.810
are you including the broad scope, right?

481
00:27:58.160 --> 00:28:01.280
A very easy thing academically,
when you're taking a test,

482
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:05.040
that is, is if the questions and

483
00:28:05.040 --> 00:28:08.461
the answers somehow exclude the customer,
it cannot be the right answer, all right.

484
00:28:09.740 --> 00:28:13.362
If you somehow leave out a key
stakeholder, whether it's the customer or

485
00:28:13.362 --> 00:28:16.285
not, certainly a customer
always should be involved, but

486
00:28:16.285 --> 00:28:18.926
it could be that you leave
out some key stakeholders.

487
00:28:18.926 --> 00:28:23.301
And it's explicit, it'll say, don't
invite them, right, don't invite them,

488
00:28:23.301 --> 00:28:25.090
just work within your team.

489
00:28:25.090 --> 00:28:28.725
That's a red flag,
on the ITIL exam, that's a red flag.

490
00:28:28.725 --> 00:28:31.362
I understand why we kinda limit
the message sometimes, and

491
00:28:31.362 --> 00:28:33.113
we invite fewer people to the meeting.

492
00:28:33.113 --> 00:28:36.029
Because the more people you invite,
the harder the meeting is,

493
00:28:36.029 --> 00:28:37.540
to work through an agenda.

494
00:28:37.540 --> 00:28:41.940
I get that challenge, and
the dynamic of the business.

495
00:28:41.940 --> 00:28:44.210
But ITIL,
while they recognize that challenge,

496
00:28:44.210 --> 00:28:47.520
don't want you to ignore
the importance of inclusion.

497
00:28:47.520 --> 00:28:50.560
So it's better to have them in
the meeting, and work through their

498
00:28:50.560 --> 00:28:54.830
objections, than it would be to face those
objections later, when success is gonna be

499
00:28:54.830 --> 00:28:58.410
more critical, all right, so-
>> Great.

500
00:28:58.410 --> 00:29:01.230
>> Yeah, that's pretty much
the subject matter related to this.

501
00:29:01.230 --> 00:29:05.059
I would like to draw your attention
to this slide, though, there is

502
00:29:05.059 --> 00:29:09.640
an exercise available, it's available
to you just up here, in Episode Files.

503
00:29:09.640 --> 00:29:13.741
And it's a practice, a little exercise
that walks you through some of the steps,

504
00:29:13.741 --> 00:29:15.954
and some of the things we've talked about.

505
00:29:15.954 --> 00:29:21.418
And this particular one is called Generic
Roles, which gives you a foundational

506
00:29:21.418 --> 00:29:26.410
aspect to the roles of service owner,
process owner, process manager.

507
00:29:26.410 --> 00:29:30.260
Business relationship manager versus
business relationship process owner, and

508
00:29:30.260 --> 00:29:31.710
those types of things.

509
00:29:31.710 --> 00:29:36.020
And gives you the basis for
understanding how a RACI chart

510
00:29:36.020 --> 00:29:40.090
might flesh out for
those generic roles, as you go through.

511
00:29:40.090 --> 00:29:42.290
So don't forget
the importance of self-study,

512
00:29:42.290 --> 00:29:46.920
exercises are available up there, sample
paper, practices are available up there.

513
00:29:46.920 --> 00:29:50.570
Dive in, and please join the forum,
ask questions here at ITProTV.

514
00:29:50.570 --> 00:29:54.327
Other experts,
of other peers that are taking the course.

515
00:29:54.327 --> 00:29:58.472
And if you have any darkness,
dark areas, I should say?

516
00:29:58.472 --> 00:30:01.880
Bring them to the forum,
we can shine light.

517
00:30:01.880 --> 00:30:02.380
>> Awesome.
>> All right.

518
00:30:02.380 --> 00:30:02.884
>> Great job,

519
00:30:02.884 --> 00:30:06.678
communication/stakeholder management.
And I wanna communicate to you, Terry,

520
00:30:06.678 --> 00:30:09.263
that you're doing an amazing job as usual,
thank you so

521
00:30:09.263 --> 00:30:10.300
very much.
>> Great.

522
00:30:10.300 --> 00:30:11.170
>> And thank you for

523
00:30:11.170 --> 00:30:16.340
watching ITProTV, and remember,
a good IT pro is always learning.

524
00:30:16.340 --> 00:30:16.951
I'm Zach Memos.

525
00:30:16.951 --> 00:30:17.696
>> I'm Terry Decker.

526
00:30:17.696 --> 00:30:20.007
>> We'll see you very soon.

527
00:30:20.007 --> 00:30:26.011
[MUSIC]

528
00:30:26.011 --> 00:30:29.620
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

I'm just gonna highlight it here,

253
00:12:37.863 --> 00:12:42.490
is that service design actually answers
the question, what does success look like?

254
00:12:42.490 --> 00:12:44.450
It's called here service
acceptance criteria.

255
00:12:45.940 --> 00:12:49.140
It's within the service acceptance
criteria, very key deliverable.

256
00:12:49.140 --> 00:12:52.710
At service design,
you are saying what success looks like.

257
00:12:53.940 --> 00:12:55.200
This is not a trivial matter.

258
00:12:55.200 --> 00:12:58.480
Now, you can have service
acceptance criteria for a system.

259
00:12:58.480 --> 00:13:01.660
And that could be system
integration passes,

260
00:13:01.660 --> 00:13:06.490
user acceptance testing passes,
performance test pass.

261
00:13:06.490 --> 00:13:08.550
And then step away from it, right.

262
00:13:08.550 --> 00:13:11.105
You've handled a bit of the utility,
you've handled a bit of the warranty and

263
00:13:11.105 --> 00:13:15.020
you're accepting that this
system is ready, right.

264
00:13:15.020 --> 00:13:18.910
Service acceptance criteria is
a little bit broader than just system

265
00:13:18.910 --> 00:13:19.850
acceptance criteria.

266
00:13:19.850 --> 00:13:24.090
Remember that, the difference between
a system and a service is many fold,

267
00:13:24.090 --> 00:13:26.170
there's lots of things to consider there.

268
00:13:26.170 --> 00:13:30.630
Service acceptance could include,
we have the capacity at the service desk,

269
00:13:30.630 --> 00:13:34.330
enough people with the right
knowledge to support this service.

270
00:13:34.330 --> 00:13:39.170
If the service requires headsets, you
know, you're introducing a new service,

271
00:13:39.170 --> 00:13:41.747
but the users are actually gonna
have headsets to use the service.

272
00:13:41.747 --> 00:13:44.040
Have you got enough headsets ordered?

273
00:13:44.040 --> 00:13:48.140
I mean it could be logistics like that,
not just does the system work, but

274
00:13:48.140 --> 00:13:52.960
have we've got all these other processes
and fulfillment needs taken care of.

275
00:13:52.960 --> 00:13:56.720
So in service design,
you're asking all those questions.

276
00:13:56.720 --> 00:14:02.310
And coming up with a checklist of things
that must be put in place to consider

277
00:14:02.310 --> 00:14:04.330
this service acceptable.

278
00:14:04.330 --> 00:14:09.670
Sure, passes integration testing,
passes UAT, passes performance testing.

279
00:14:09.670 --> 00:14:12.000
Those can still be in
service acceptance criteria.

280
00:14:12.000 --> 00:14:16.240
In addition to that, we have enough
headsets, training has been accomplished.

281
00:14:16.240 --> 00:14:18.255
The users have been trained, right?

282
00:14:18.255 --> 00:14:23.250
And the test results have been posted
etc., those types of things, right.

283
00:14:23.250 --> 00:14:24.960
Again, notice this is happening,

284
00:14:24.960 --> 00:14:28.170
the exceptions criteria is
happening at service design.

285
00:14:28.170 --> 00:14:29.510
Very early.

286
00:14:29.510 --> 00:14:32.790
The reason I highlight that is
one of the things you might

287
00:14:32.790 --> 00:14:34.240
find in an academic setting.

288
00:14:34.240 --> 00:14:36.460
I think you could also
find it back at work.

289
00:14:36.460 --> 00:14:40.190
Is that you get down the line
a little bit then you realized

00:14:41.450 --> 00:14:43.970
you know what we should

291
00:14:43.970 --> 00:14:45.780
Really to prove this is gonna work but

00:14:45.780 --> 00:14:48.260
a performance test is
gonna cost you 10 grand.

293
00:14:48.260 --> 00:14:49.410
Where's the 10 grand coming from?

294
00:14:49.410 --> 00:14:53.290
They approved this project six months ago,
why are you asking for 10 grand now?

295
00:14:53.290 --> 00:14:54.000
Right?

296
00:14:54.000 --> 00:14:57.940
So again, that's why you get
these stages involved earlier

00:14:57.940 --> 00:14:59.020

298
00:14:59.020 --> 00:14:59.780
How much money's coming?

299
00:14:59.780 --> 00:15:03.880
But it's also why you design success in,
instead of waiting for

00:15:03.880 --> 00:15:06.106
later to discover what you might need.

301
00:15:06.106 --> 00:15:07.220
Okay.

302
00:15:07.220 --> 00:15:08.207
All right.

303
00:15:08.207 --> 00:15:10.260
>> Grief.

304
00:15:10.260 --> 00:15:12.860
>> So again, looking at the thing

305
00:15:12.860 --> 00:15:19.050
Business capability is almost as
important as your own capability.

306
00:15:20.290 --> 00:15:23.740
As an example, when I was still a

00:15:23.740 --> 00:15:27.690
they were introducing a new technology,
basically MRI.

308
00:15:27.690 --> 00:15:32.950
I'll simplify this cuz I don't know
the geophysics, physical nature of this.

309
00:15:32.950 --> 00:15:38.660
But basically, instead of having to drill
down and bring up samples and do essays in

00:15:38.660 --> 00:15:44.880
a lab, basically out in the field or ship
it to someone and they do it remotely.

311
00:15:44.880 --> 00:15:46.190
>> Like a ground MRI, right?.

312
00:15:46.190 --> 00:15:48.770
>> Basically like that, yeah.

313
00:15:48.770 --> 00:15:53.902
So, a new technology is driven by
technology and IT service, if you will,

00:15:53.902 --> 00:15:59.289
to streamline the discovery of potential
oil deposits is this idea like a MRI.

315
00:15:59.289 --> 00:16:01.980
A magnetic resonance of the Earth, right.

00:16:01.980 --> 00:16:03.120
Pretty cool, right?

317
00:16:03.120 --> 00:16:06.440
Now, it's one thing to have
this technological advancement.

00:16:06.440 --> 00:16:07.839
In that field.
It's another thing to purchase

00:16:07.839 --> 00:16:09.995
the appropriate hardware and
software to make it happen.

00:16:09.995 --> 00:16:13.456

00:16:13.456 --> 00:16:15.490
do that in a streamlined way.

322
00:16:15.490 --> 00:16:20.130
To provide a support model for
the instrumentation, sure, IT can do that.

323
00:16:20.130 --> 00:16:23.360
IT could test it,
make sure it works, etc., but

324
00:16:23.360 --> 00:16:26.470
what if your geophysicists
don't know how to use it?

325
00:16:26.470 --> 00:16:31.090
Right, they're still expecting a core
sample and their assay tubes and

00:16:31.090 --> 00:16:32.230
everything else.

327
00:16:32.230 --> 00:16:35.640
So if your geophysicists aren't
ready to move on with the service,

328
00:16:35.640 --> 00:16:38.010
that service is likely to fail, right?

329
00:16:38.010 --> 00:16:39.820
So when you see how they did it here,

330
00:16:39.820 --> 00:16:42.270
what's the business capability and
maturity?

331
00:16:42.270 --> 00:16:45.370
You might not think it's your business
at all to worry about the business'

332
00:16:45.370 --> 00:16:47.150
capabilities, but in fact, it is.

333
00:16:47.150 --> 00:16:49.710
What you're trying to do,
as an IT service provider,

334
00:16:49.710 --> 00:16:54.280
is link your assets with their
assets up in a synergetic way.

335
00:16:54.280 --> 00:16:56.010
If you don't know what
they're trying to do,

336
00:16:56.010 --> 00:16:58.370
then you're gonna be losing
on that proposition.

337
00:16:58.370 --> 00:17:01.270
If you know what they're trying to do, but
you don't know that they know how to do

338
00:17:01.270 --> 00:17:04.390
it, you're gonna be losing
on that proposition as well.

339
00:17:04.390 --> 00:17:05.690
So business capacity,

340
00:17:05.690 --> 00:17:10.610
business maturity, is also a concern
when you consider design elements.

341
00:17:10.610 --> 00:17:13.340
That happens to all fall under
capacity management, by the way.

342
00:17:13.340 --> 00:17:18.090
Capacity management is component capacity,
service capacity,

343
00:17:18.090 --> 00:17:20.330
as well as business capacity.

344
00:17:20.330 --> 00:17:24.410
So judging the capabilities of your
business is effectively judging

345
00:17:24.410 --> 00:17:26.960
their capacity to use your service, right.

346
00:17:26.960 --> 00:17:28.780
And if they're unable to use your service,

347
00:17:28.780 --> 00:17:31.260
it doesn't matter how well
you've designed your service.

348
00:17:31.260 --> 00:17:34.020
If they're unable to use it,
that service is gonna fail.

349
00:17:34.020 --> 00:17:38.120
So again service design is in play here,
very holistic, right?

350
00:17:38.120 --> 00:17:40.498
Again, I'm not trying to
teach you new things,

351
00:17:40.498 --> 00:17:44.397
these things would have been borne out
in your intermediate-level learning.

352
00:17:44.397 --> 00:17:48.159
What I'm trying to orient you toward
is this holistic view, looking across,

353
00:17:48.159 --> 00:17:52.070
managing across a life cycle, cuz you
can see how these things integrate.

354
00:17:52.070 --> 00:17:53.536
So the focus on integration is key.

355
00:17:53.536 --> 00:17:56.347
>> 5,000-foot view.

356
00:17:56.347 --> 00:17:59.623
>> Exactly, give or take 10 or 20,000
feet, give or take 10 or 20,000 feet and

357
00:17:59.623 --> 00:18:01.014
sometimes they'll appreciate that.

358
00:18:01.014 --> 00:18:02.205
>> [LAUGH]
>> In fact,

359
00:18:02.205 --> 00:18:06.591
one of the challenges of the intermediate
level exams, and the MALC exam,

360
00:18:06.591 --> 00:18:11.280
is zeroing in on details, and then
coming back out to the 5,000 foot view.

361
00:18:11.280 --> 00:18:14.780
Zeroing in and coming back, cuz you
gotta pay attention to the details, or

362
00:18:14.780 --> 00:18:16.450
you'll miss an important factor, right?

363
00:18:16.450 --> 00:18:19.940
And I think, by the way,
isn't that true in real life, too?

364
00:18:19.940 --> 00:18:23.820
Back at the operations,
back at the office,

365
00:18:23.820 --> 00:18:26.470
paying attention to details
is a necessary evil.

366
00:18:26.470 --> 00:18:29.445
And keeping the eye on the big
picture is also a necessary evil.

367
00:18:29.445 --> 00:18:33.500
Well, management across the life cycle
requires both looking at the details, and

368
00:18:33.500 --> 00:18:34.320
zooming back out.

369
00:18:34.320 --> 00:18:35.150
>> Checks and balances.

370
00:18:35.150 --> 00:18:36.290
>> Checks and balances, yeah.

371
00:18:36.290 --> 00:18:38.063
>> Along the way.

372
00:18:38.063 --> 00:18:41.681
>> So
to sum up here then on this integration.

373
00:18:41.681 --> 00:18:46.072
This is a wonderful graphic of
how service design is in play,

374
00:18:46.072 --> 00:18:50.270
and some of the constraints
we're operating on.

375
00:18:50.270 --> 00:18:54.190
If you were to pause this
episode if you have time and

376
00:18:54.190 --> 00:18:58.435
study this graphic, you'll have
some good grist for the mill here.

377
00:18:58.435 --> 00:19:02.120
Let's have a look here,
notice this project team,

378
00:19:02.120 --> 00:19:03.395
it's even highlighted in red here?

379
00:19:03.395 --> 00:19:07.920
ITIL does not present itself
as a best practice for

380
00:19:07.920 --> 00:19:12.460
project management, doesn't pretend to
be a project management best practice.

381
00:19:13.930 --> 00:19:18.865
However, you can't successfully
implement or bring in new services, or

382
00:19:18.865 --> 00:19:23.820
a major change to a service, without
having some project discipline in play.

383
00:19:23.820 --> 00:19:27.652
So, this is not just a nod to
the importance of project management,

384
00:19:27.652 --> 00:19:31.031
it's absolutely shaking hands
with project management.

385
00:19:31.031 --> 00:19:34.620
There is a process within service
design called design coordination.

386
00:19:34.620 --> 00:19:39.036
And design coordination is
the process that is the nice,

387
00:19:39.036 --> 00:19:43.460
thorough handshake with
project management.

388
00:19:43.460 --> 00:19:46.380
There's also one in service transition,
it's called transition planning and

389
00:19:46.380 --> 00:19:50.120
support, that also is a handshake
with project management.

390
00:19:50.120 --> 00:19:53.180
So present this in this way.

391
00:19:53.180 --> 00:19:58.674
If project management and service
management are to be linked together?

392
00:19:58.674 --> 00:19:59.874
In the ITIL framework,

393
00:19:59.874 --> 00:20:03.680
they would be linked together
through those two processes.

394
00:20:03.680 --> 00:20:05.150
I'll put that yet another way.

395
00:20:05.150 --> 00:20:10.580
If you're a project manager for
an organization that has a mature

396
00:20:10.580 --> 00:20:14.820
ITIL adoption, you've adopted ITIL and
you're very mature in it.

397
00:20:14.820 --> 00:20:18.600
And you have a design coordination
process, and a transition planning and

398
00:20:18.600 --> 00:20:20.270
support process.

399
00:20:20.270 --> 00:20:24.195
If you're a project manager in that
kind of organization, you are very

400
00:20:24.195 --> 00:20:28.930
well-versed on the deliverables of those
two processes, what their outputs are.

401
00:20:28.930 --> 00:20:33.570
Because those two processes, what design
coordination does for service design,

402
00:20:33.570 --> 00:20:37.970
is the same thing transition planning and
support does for service transition.

403
00:20:37.970 --> 00:20:41.610
They shepherd the resources
within that stage,

404
00:20:41.610 --> 00:20:45.564
to make sure they're operating in
a cohesive way, in an efficient way,

405
00:20:45.564 --> 00:20:49.390
in cost-effective ways,
in time-effective ways.

406
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:53.990
In other words, they're managing the
resources, coordinating the resources, so

407
00:20:53.990 --> 00:20:57.950

on budget.

408
00:20:57.950 --> 00:21:00.150
Does that sound like project management?

409
00:21:00.150 --> 00:21:02.339
In fact, it is very much
the principles of project management.

410
00:21:02.339 --> 00:21:06.281
Deliver on time, on budget,
given your resource constraints,

411
00:21:06.281 --> 00:21:08.727
given your time and money constraints.

412
00:21:08.727 --> 00:21:12.940
And making those things come together

413
00:21:12.940 --> 00:21:20.330

ITIL merge at those two processes,

414
00:21:20.330 --> 00:21:23.540
design coordination and
transition planning and support.

00:21:23.540 --> 00:21:25.680
That's the handshake you're looking for.

416
00:21:25.680 --> 00:21:29.580
On the exam, as well as back at the
office, getting your project management

00:21:29.580 --> 00:21:33.670

starts with those two processes.

00:21:34.960 --> 00:21:37.121

interact with each other,

00:21:41.659 --> 00:21:45.679

00:21:45.679 --> 00:21:48.140

261
00:14:51.040 --> 00:14:54.630
responsibilities of a service
owner are well defined,

262
00:14:54.630 --> 00:14:56.990
there's obviously points
of interaction among those.

263
00:14:56.990 --> 00:15:01.580
Where these particular roles and these
particular people become practitioners of

264
00:15:01.580 --> 00:15:07.420
this big umbrella called business
relationship management, a big one.

265
00:15:07.420 --> 00:15:09.302
So I don't think I could overstate.

266
00:15:09.302 --> 00:15:10.968
This is a probably a limited list,

267
00:15:10.968 --> 00:15:15.171
therefore BRM certainly interacts with
these other processes, without a question.

268
00:15:15.171 --> 00:15:19.840
They see the spider web areas going out
and touching lots of different things.

269
00:15:19.840 --> 00:15:24.890
It'd be hard for me to limit BRM cuz it
would be involved at just about any level.

270
00:15:24.890 --> 00:15:31.500
If the customers are upset with change
management because they're always late, or

271
00:15:31.500 --> 00:15:35.520
they might deliver on time, but when they
deliver something, it's always broken.

272
00:15:35.520 --> 00:15:39.963
So the business could be very upset
with our change management process.

273
00:15:39.963 --> 00:15:41.960
Therefore, you could put
change management up here.

274
00:15:43.030 --> 00:15:45.930
You could look at put BRM and
change management

275
00:15:45.930 --> 00:15:49.210
in the same list to say they talk
to each other, they certainly can.

276
00:15:49.210 --> 00:15:53.902
So because BRM is more of an umbrella and
because it's really more like a spider web

277
00:15:53.902 --> 00:15:57.710
that gets out into everything,
I don't want you to think that this

278
00:15:57.710 --> 00:16:01.669
particular process is anywhere
close to being monolithic.

279
00:16:01.669 --> 00:16:06.095
It is not, there is not one practitioner
and one best way to do this.

280
00:16:07.460 --> 00:16:12.709
So when you're considering how you're
trying to capture the value of BRM,

281
00:16:12.709 --> 00:16:18.121
what is the value of BRM as related to
SLM, or as related to demand management,

282
00:16:18.121 --> 00:16:21.170
or as relates to availability management?

283
00:16:21.170 --> 00:16:24.977
BRM gives you a structured approach,
a structured set of activities.

284
00:16:24.977 --> 00:16:27.190
That's what a process is.

285
00:16:27.190 --> 00:16:30.342
It gives you a structured
set of activities toward

286
00:16:30.342 --> 00:16:32.297
a specific business outcome.

287
00:16:32.297 --> 00:16:37.159
Or a specific deliverable, in this case,
that outcome is effective manager of

288
00:16:37.159 --> 00:16:41.090
customer expectations and
value propositions, straight up.

289
00:16:42.160 --> 00:16:44.530
That's it with the service
strategy processes.

290
00:16:44.530 --> 00:16:45.800
>> Wonderful.
>> That's what we got, yep.

291
00:16:45.800 --> 00:16:48.000
>> Yeah, any kind of a wrap up on this or?

292
00:16:48.000 --> 00:16:48.912
>> No, actually not this time.

293
00:16:48.912 --> 00:16:49.655
>> Perfect.

294
00:16:49.655 --> 00:16:51.451
>> There's no specific
exercise related to this.

295
00:16:51.451 --> 00:16:55.070
You'll certainly find this tested
through the sample papers.

296
00:16:55.070 --> 00:16:57.480
You'll find this reinforced
in the sample papers, so,

297
00:16:57.480 --> 00:17:01.730
as I mentioned before, the importance of
those sample papers cannot be overstated.

298
00:17:01.730 --> 00:17:04.920
Make sure you take some practice exams
before you get out there to the real exam.

299
00:17:04.920 --> 00:17:09.000
And you'll get to hone your skills
on those particular topics there.

300
00:17:09.000 --> 00:17:12.580
>> Well, there you have it,
ITIL MALC service strategy processes.

301
00:17:12.580 --> 00:17:13.870
Great job as usual, Terry.

302
00:17:13.870 --> 00:17:15.550
Thanks very much.

303
00:17:15.550 --> 00:17:19.270
And there's so
much more in the ITIL MALC series.

304
00:17:19.270 --> 00:17:21.876
Hey, thank you for watching ITProTV.

305
00:17:21.876 --> 00:17:24.480
A good IT pro is always learning.

306
00:17:24.480 --> 00:17:25.190
I'm Zach Memos.

307
00:17:25.190 --> 00:17:26.025
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

308
00:17:26.025 --> 00:17:28.560
>> And we'll see you very soon.

309
00:17:28.560 --> 00:17:34.738
[MUSIC]

310
00:17:34.738 --> 00:17:37.811
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of SD processes.
episodes.title: Service Design Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.320 --> 00:00:00.913
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.913 --> 00:00:02.778
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.778 --> 00:00:06.829
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.829 --> 00:00:08.270
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.270 --> 00:00:10.610
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.210 --> 00:00:13.240
>> Hello again,

7
00:00:13.240 --> 00:00:18.230
thank you for choosing ITProTV,
helping you to learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:18.230 --> 00:00:21.620
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as continue on with ITIL MALC,

9
00:00:21.620 --> 00:00:26.100
and this look is gonna be
service design processes.

10
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:31.080
And giving us all the information we need,
is Terry Decker, right over here.

11
00:00:31.080 --> 00:00:31.790
>> Thanks, Zach.

12
00:00:31.790 --> 00:00:35.060
And as Zach mentioned, we're gonna be
looking at the service design processes.

13
00:00:35.060 --> 00:00:36.370
These processes,

14
00:00:36.370 --> 00:00:41.410
as we did with service strategy in
a previous episode are they have value.

15
00:00:41.410 --> 00:00:45.740
And in the absence of a given process,
you could be missing that value.

16
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:50.570
That's the value proposition,
if you will, of IT service management.

17
00:00:50.570 --> 00:00:52.230
ITIL defines 26 processes,

18
00:00:52.230 --> 00:00:56.950
suggesting that these 26 processes,
if done well, will deliver value.

19
00:00:56.950 --> 00:00:59.000
So, what if that value is missing, right?

20
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:02.770
What are the symptoms
of that value missing?

21
00:01:02.770 --> 00:01:05.460
So as we go through this lecture,
I would like for

22
00:01:05.460 --> 00:01:10.930
you to be thinking or re-energizing your
awareness of the value of these processes.

23
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:12.234
This won't be the first time that
you've been exposed to them.

24
00:01:12.234 --> 00:01:15.540
I know you got a little bit of them in,
certainly in foundation course, and

25
00:01:15.540 --> 00:01:17.903
you would've touched some
of them at a deeper level,

26
00:01:17.903 --> 00:01:19.919
and the intermediate path if you've taken.

27
00:01:19.919 --> 00:01:24.311
But what we're focusing on here and
we're trying to refocus on the value

28
00:01:24.311 --> 00:01:28.775
proposition, is because when your
trying to manage across a life cycle,

29
00:01:28.775 --> 00:01:31.350
you could get lost in the trees, right.

30
00:01:31.350 --> 00:01:33.370
You're not necessarily see the forest.

31
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:39.270
So what we're trying to do at managing
across a life cycle, is get you keen

32
00:01:39.270 --> 00:01:44.155
on finding where value is missing
in this process model called ITIL.

33
00:01:44.155 --> 00:01:49.100
So if there is a particular weakness
suggested in a scenario on the exam,

34
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:50.680
if there's a particular weakness,
actually,

35
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:55.590
in the case study, there's something is
shown to be a little bit of a shortfall.

36
00:01:55.590 --> 00:01:57.430
You don't have this process formalized, or

37
00:01:57.430 --> 00:01:59.840
you don't have this
process formalized yet.

38
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:02.099
That might play out in a scenario,
it might play out in the case study.

39
00:02:02.099 --> 00:02:06.554
But if this is not formalized,
you can kinda be keening in on, or

40
00:02:06.554 --> 00:02:12.580
zeroing in on, is there gonna be
a manifestation of that being missing?

41
00:02:12.580 --> 00:02:15.890
And that's gonna be is the value missing,
right?

42
00:02:15.890 --> 00:02:19.060
So understanding what these
processes do is one thing.

43
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:22.390
Understanding why that's
important is another.

44
00:02:22.390 --> 00:02:24.620
And when you consider
managing across a life cycle,

45
00:02:24.620 --> 00:02:28.280
it's as important enough to
know why as it is to how.

46
00:02:28.280 --> 00:02:29.740
So let's take a look at the why's here.

47
00:02:29.740 --> 00:02:30.410
>> Awesome.

48
00:02:30.410 --> 00:02:33.720
>> All right, there are eight
processes in service design.

49
00:02:33.720 --> 00:02:35.760
I'm gonna fast forward
this really quickly,

50
00:02:35.760 --> 00:02:37.800
cuz many of these are located here.

51
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:41.340
Design coordination, I'll go back and pick
up some of the pieces here in a second.

52
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:45.970
But design coordination, among the others
that are in service design are service

53
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:50.520
level management, supplier management,
availability, capacity, and

54
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:52.750
IT service continuity management.

55
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:55.510
So, a bunch of warranty processes here,
right.

56
00:02:57.510 --> 00:03:00.380
The one missing is security management.

57
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:01.721
It also could be in play, right?

58
00:03:03.114 --> 00:03:08.540
So these are within service design.

59
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:13.110
Notice these other process integration,
as you go around the bend, right.

60
00:03:13.110 --> 00:03:15.420
So design coordination, obviously,

61
00:03:15.420 --> 00:03:22.070
intends to have conversations outside
of service design, to be successful.

62
00:03:22.070 --> 00:03:25.720
This is reinforcing what we've talked
about earlier, as these stages don't

63
00:03:25.720 --> 00:03:29.230
interact in a vacuum, I mean,
they don't exist in a vacuum.

64
00:03:29.230 --> 00:03:30.740
They interact with each other, and

65
00:03:30.740 --> 00:03:34.390
to be successful, they have to know
what the other ones are doing.

66
00:03:34.390 --> 00:03:37.400
When you're trying to successfully
manage across a life cycle,

67
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:41.610
you're often gonna be looking at
the interactions among these stages, and

68
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:44.390
the interactions among these processes.

69
00:03:44.390 --> 00:03:46.710
So what about design coordination?

70
00:03:46.710 --> 00:03:47.517
Going back up a step here.

71
00:03:47.517 --> 00:03:51.970
Design coordination delivers
value to business because it is

72
00:03:51.970 --> 00:03:54.882
the process that effectively governs,

73
00:03:54.882 --> 00:04:01.310
that intends to effectively govern
the entire stage called service design.

74
00:04:01.310 --> 00:04:04.690
So if you understand what service
design is trying to accomplish,

75
00:04:04.690 --> 00:04:09.470
you'll find that design coordination is
at the fulcrum of that value proposition.

76
00:04:09.470 --> 00:04:11.530
It's the one that delivers things.

77
00:04:11.530 --> 00:04:13.490
So what is service design trying to do?

78
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:17.040
It's trying to answer all
the questions that need to be answered

79
00:04:17.040 --> 00:04:21.155
to eventually successfully
bring a service to life.

80
00:04:21.155 --> 00:04:25.715
Not a system to life,
not a solution to life, but a service.

81
00:04:25.715 --> 00:04:27.835
Which means,
all the trappings of a service,

82
00:04:27.835 --> 00:04:31.422
including processes,
technology for sure, right?

83
00:04:31.422 --> 00:04:33.802
The people, are they trained,
are they ready to go?

84
00:04:33.802 --> 00:04:36.542
Are suppliers on board, right?

85
00:04:36.542 --> 00:04:39.212
Are we affecting the right
organizational structures?

86
00:04:39.212 --> 00:04:43.361
Or, are the organizations gonna interface
with each other effectively, right?

87
00:04:43.361 --> 00:04:45.631
Do we have metrics in place?

88
00:04:45.631 --> 00:04:47.781
What does success look like?

89
00:04:47.781 --> 00:04:50.481
What is the service acceptance criteria?

90
00:04:50.481 --> 00:04:55.151
Answering all the questions before
you write that first bit of code, or

91
00:04:55.151 --> 00:04:57.040
purchase that first server.

92
00:04:57.040 --> 00:05:00.420
Or design that first
availability management plan.

93
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:03.980
You're trying to answer the questions,
what are we trying to get done here?

94
00:05:03.980 --> 00:05:07.010
So design coordination,
not only answers these questions

95
00:05:07.010 --> 00:05:11.350
through the other seven processes in
service design, it makes sure those other

96
00:05:11.350 --> 00:05:16.560
seven processes within service design are
done well, at sufficient level of quality.

97
00:05:16.560 --> 00:05:21.490
That they're done efficiently and
effectively, on time and on budget.

98
00:05:21.490 --> 00:05:24.710
And coordinating all the resources,
managing the workflow.

99
00:05:24.710 --> 00:05:27.560
There is a high component
of project management

100
00:05:28.670 --> 00:05:31.440
expectations within design coordination.

101
00:05:31.440 --> 00:05:35.610
And it's gonna be the handshake with your
project management office, for sure, okay?

102
00:05:36.780 --> 00:05:38.980
In the absence of design and coordination,

103
00:05:38.980 --> 00:05:42.050
could you still be doing availability
management, continuity management,

104
00:05:42.050 --> 00:05:45.750
capacity management, supplier management,
service level management?

105
00:05:45.750 --> 00:05:50.190
Absolutely, you could be effectively
doing those other processes and

106
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:52.020
not have designed coordination, but

107
00:05:52.020 --> 00:05:55.520
what you'd be missing is the handshake
with project management.

108
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:57.600
The coordination of those seven things,

109
00:05:57.600 --> 00:06:00.660
the interaction of those seven
things that are going on.

110
00:06:00.660 --> 00:06:03.500
The appropriate cost justifications and

111
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:07.420
improvement across the life cycle
stage called service design.

112
00:06:07.420 --> 00:06:12.167
So in the absence of design coordination,
the value you'd be missing would

113
00:06:12.167 --> 00:06:15.357
be a holistic approach to
all design activities and

114
00:06:15.357 --> 00:06:18.791
holistic approach to improving them all,
all right.

115
00:06:18.791 --> 00:06:20.170
>> Very good.

116
00:06:20.170 --> 00:06:21.160
>> That's design coordination.

117
00:06:21.160 --> 00:06:22.370
>> Yeah.

118
00:06:22.370 --> 00:06:25.690
>> Another process within service design,
service catalog management.

119
00:06:25.690 --> 00:06:29.430
You'll recall that service catalog
management is responsible for

120
00:06:29.430 --> 00:06:31.130
maintaining the service catalog.

121
00:06:31.130 --> 00:06:34.600
This listing of all your
operational services,

122
00:06:34.600 --> 00:06:36.420
the ones that are currently active.

123
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:40.316
And keeping up with details of
those operational services, and

124
00:06:40.316 --> 00:06:45.164
providing the appropriate views of
the services to be appropriate audiences.

125
00:06:45.164 --> 00:06:48.840
That's what service service
catalog management purpose is.

126
00:06:48.840 --> 00:06:50.630
But what's the value of it?

127
00:06:50.630 --> 00:06:54.701
Right, why have a listing
of your existing services.

128
00:06:54.701 --> 00:06:58.237
Right, let me put it in another way.

129
00:06:58.237 --> 00:07:01.645
If you want to adopt
IT service management,

130
00:07:01.645 --> 00:07:05.155
you need to identify
what your services are.

131
00:07:07.779 --> 00:07:13.110
In the absence of service definition,
you can't manage services.

132
00:07:13.110 --> 00:07:16.900
You're chasing solutions,
you're chasing phantoms,right,

133
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:19.725
you're chasing something
that's not service-oriented.

134
00:07:19.725 --> 00:07:22.730
You're just chasing
technology around the bend.

135
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:27.088
Right, service management
requires services to be defined.

136
00:07:28.876 --> 00:07:30.955
Once defined, they need to be reposited,

137
00:07:30.955 --> 00:07:34.830
they need to be in a place where we
can see them and talk about them.

138
00:07:34.830 --> 00:07:36.790
That's what the catalog is.

139
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:40.830
If you've never began this sort
of catalog management process,

140
00:07:40.830 --> 00:07:44.430
then the first stage is having
a conversation about what a service is.

141
00:07:44.430 --> 00:07:47.300
Making sure you get a common
understanding across your organization

142
00:07:47.300 --> 00:07:48.870
what a service is.

143
00:07:48.870 --> 00:07:53.320
And I say this operationally speaking,
this also could play out on the exam,

144
00:07:53.320 --> 00:07:55.316
right, academically speaking.

145
00:07:55.316 --> 00:08:00.244
In the absence of a service catalog, how
do you articulate what services you have?

146
00:08:00.244 --> 00:08:04.577
How do you begin to have a conversation
about services without listing what

147
00:08:04.577 --> 00:08:05.826
services you offer.

148
00:08:05.826 --> 00:08:09.932
So the service catalog is providing
value by providing a single point of

149
00:08:09.932 --> 00:08:12.960
truth about your existing services.

150
00:08:12.960 --> 00:08:18.820
And with that you could then launch into
your ideas about service management.

151
00:08:18.820 --> 00:08:19.910
It's kind of a predicate step.

152
00:08:19.910 --> 00:08:22.940
Now this doesn't have to be complicated,
let me put it another way.

153
00:08:22.940 --> 00:08:25.420
Eventually it can become quite complex.

154
00:08:25.420 --> 00:08:28.740
In fact, building out your
catalog with multiple views for

155
00:08:28.740 --> 00:08:32.220
all your different kinds of customers,
could be a data model challenge.

156
00:08:32.220 --> 00:08:35.660
How are we going to put this data in a,
is it gonna be a spreadsheet?

157
00:08:35.660 --> 00:08:37.100
A SharePoint list?

158
00:08:37.100 --> 00:08:38.530
Does it need to be a relational database?

159
00:08:38.530 --> 00:08:40.380
You'll eventually get to
that kind of conversation.

160
00:08:40.380 --> 00:08:43.600
Itell is not trying to ask
you to solve the data model

161
00:08:43.600 --> 00:08:45.860
challenge of service catalog, I promise.

162
00:08:45.860 --> 00:08:49.610
On the exam you're not going to be asked,
work out the date model for

163
00:08:49.610 --> 00:08:50.452
your service catalog.

164
00:08:50.452 --> 00:08:52.150
You don't have to go there.

165
00:08:53.220 --> 00:08:57.140
Operationally speaking, if I were to
challenge you to go back to work, and

166
00:08:57.140 --> 00:09:01.810
begin to create a catalog, I wouldn't
get out my relational database guru,

167
00:09:01.810 --> 00:09:03.920
or talk to a database engineer.

168
00:09:03.920 --> 00:09:05.560
I'd talk to people in the business.

169
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:10.190
I would talk to the practitioners
in your architectural group and

170
00:09:10.190 --> 00:09:14.130
your application group,
to find out how are these things consumed.

171
00:09:14.130 --> 00:09:16.310
Who is responsible or accountable?

172
00:09:16.310 --> 00:09:17.760
For that application.

173
00:09:17.760 --> 00:09:20.800
Who is responsible and
accountable for that infrastructure.

174
00:09:20.800 --> 00:09:23.882
And you start building some
consensus over, well that's a thing.

175
00:09:23.882 --> 00:09:24.510
Right?

176
00:09:24.510 --> 00:09:28.640
Jimmy's responsible for servers,
Mary is responsible for

177
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:30.510
learning management applications.

178
00:09:30.510 --> 00:09:33.098
Why don't we come up with a service
called learning management and

179
00:09:33.098 --> 00:09:34.850
get Mary the service owner.

180
00:09:34.850 --> 00:09:39.140
Why don't we come up with a server or
a service called server services.

181
00:09:39.140 --> 00:09:44.180
And let Jimmy be the owner of that,
you start developing these things, right?

182
00:09:44.180 --> 00:09:49.030
Have those kind of conversations and maybe
this is an Excel spreadsheet at first.

183
00:09:49.030 --> 00:09:51.800
Right?
That is a very good starting point.

184
00:09:51.800 --> 00:09:54.940
Don't worry about the data
model on the exam.

185
00:09:54.940 --> 00:09:58.640
And don't get lost in the data
model back at the office.
