00:23:20.735 --> 00:23:24.365
Just that I think XP was the big
culprit there, Windows XP.

424
00:23:24.365 --> 00:23:28.005
And a pretty big hit for

425
00:23:28.005 --> 00:23:30.965
that particular software on that
particular operating system.

426
00:23:30.965 --> 00:23:33.145
Corrupting data, bringing down systems,

427
00:23:33.145 --> 00:23:38.175
and effectively bringing down
services in a major way, right?

428
00:23:38.175 --> 00:23:42.535
So that type of thing is what information
security management is all about,

429
00:23:42.535 --> 00:23:47.910
keeping your systems protected from
viruses, protected from attacks, right?

430
00:23:47.910 --> 00:23:51.034
Making sure the right people
have access to resources and

431
00:23:51.034 --> 00:23:52.928
the wrong people don't, right?

432
00:23:52.928 --> 00:23:57.898
And to be able to effectively
manage the identities of people so

433
00:23:57.898 --> 00:24:02.984
that you can effectively manage
repudiation, etc., right?

434
00:24:02.984 --> 00:24:06.489
So security management,
in the absence of security management,

435
00:24:06.489 --> 00:24:08.751
you're gonna be Subjected to such risks.

436
00:24:08.751 --> 00:24:11.189
Security management is trying
to hole up those risks,

437
00:24:11.189 --> 00:24:14.114
secure those things against attack,
pretty straightforward.

438
00:24:14.114 --> 00:24:15.221
>> Mm-hm.

439
00:24:15.221 --> 00:24:15.922
>> All right.

440
00:24:17.634 --> 00:24:19.758
Finally, Supplier Management.

441
00:24:19.758 --> 00:24:25.035
Dealing with your suppliers is a separate
discipline in ITIL's framework,

442
00:24:25.035 --> 00:24:27.310
and I think it makes sense.

443
00:24:27.310 --> 00:24:31.102
Not only do supplier managers have to
navigate through their own bureaucracy of

444
00:24:31.102 --> 00:24:34.738
your own organization for procurement and
perhaps legal considerations.

445
00:24:34.738 --> 00:24:37.380
So you have to deal with
these internal processes.

446
00:24:37.380 --> 00:24:41.840
You also have to deal with
the intricacies of a third party

447
00:24:41.840 --> 00:24:43.645
outside your organization.

448
00:24:43.645 --> 00:24:46.665
If you're trying to motivate someone
within your organization, you

449
00:24:46.665 --> 00:24:51.885
have the cultural dynamic of, if you don't
do this I'm gonna tell your supervisor.

450
00:24:51.885 --> 00:24:55.015
And you could be disciplined,
ultimately could be fired, all right?

451
00:24:56.395 --> 00:24:59.843
With suppliers, the relationship
is not cultural, it's legal,

452
00:24:59.843 --> 00:25:01.424
you have a contract with them.

453
00:25:01.424 --> 00:25:05.377
Now I'm not saying you don't develop
cultural synergies, you should, right?

454
00:25:05.377 --> 00:25:09.027
But ultimately, at the end of the day,
what governs the relationship between you

455
00:25:09.027 --> 00:25:13.427
and your supplier is a legal agreement,
all right?

456
00:25:13.427 --> 00:25:17.147
They may operate on a improvement
cycle that's different than yours,

457
00:25:17.147 --> 00:25:21.650
they may demand money for improvement,

458
00:25:21.650 --> 00:25:25.590
where you kind of expect improvement
inside, etc., ongoing improvement.

459
00:25:25.590 --> 00:25:29.200
So managing the supplier
is a separate discipline.

460
00:25:29.200 --> 00:25:33.920
In the absence of Supplier Management, you
might have a lot of misalignment between

461
00:25:33.920 --> 00:25:38.900
the effectiveness of your suppliers as it
relates to your business outcomes, right?

462
00:25:38.900 --> 00:25:43.457
You may have been promising the business
that you can resolve incidents and

463
00:25:43.457 --> 00:25:48.087
outages within four hours and your
supplier thinks they have all day because

464
00:25:48.087 --> 00:25:51.504
they recategorize the severity
different than you do.

465
00:25:51.504 --> 00:25:55.697
And so all of a sudden you have a supplier
that's making your service fail and you

466
00:25:55.697 --> 00:26:00.570
have an explanation to your customer, why
didn't you deliver this within four hours?

467
00:26:00.570 --> 00:26:04.480
It's taken two days to get my
service back, that's unacceptable.

468
00:26:04.480 --> 00:26:06.140
Back to the supplier again.

469
00:26:06.140 --> 00:26:07.760
So in the absence of Supplier Management,

470
00:26:07.760 --> 00:26:10.940
you could be spending more
money than you need to, right?

471
00:26:10.940 --> 00:26:14.570
You're not synergizing the competitive
efforts among your different suppliers.

472
00:26:14.570 --> 00:26:17.040
You might have a very complex,

473
00:26:17.040 --> 00:26:19.690
you might have a lot more
suppliers that you need to manage,

474
00:26:19.690 --> 00:26:24.800
you might have 100 different suppliers
supplying the same type of service.

475
00:26:24.800 --> 00:26:27.420
And therefore not getting
the economies of scale and

476
00:26:27.420 --> 00:26:31.130
quality that you could engender with
a supply management discipline.

477
00:26:31.130 --> 00:26:34.410
You might be making poor decisions
about whether to outsource something or

478
00:26:34.410 --> 00:26:35.910
keep it in house.

479
00:26:35.910 --> 00:26:40.097
So Supplier Management becomes the focal
point for supplier decisions and

480
00:26:40.097 --> 00:26:44.019
provides a repeatable process for
ongoing management of suppliers,

481
00:26:44.019 --> 00:26:46.427
that's the big value proposition there.

482
00:26:46.427 --> 00:26:49.011
Obtaining value for money, more value for

483
00:26:49.011 --> 00:26:54.130
less money eventually is what Supplier
Management can deliver for you, all right?

484
00:26:54.130 --> 00:26:55.154
>> Makes sense.

485
00:26:55.154 --> 00:26:58.784
>> Yep, that's it for
the Service Design processes,

486
00:26:58.784 --> 00:27:02.426
as we look at these processes and
the value therein.

487
00:27:02.426 --> 00:27:03.525
That's it.

488
00:27:03.525 --> 00:27:08.370
>> Perfect, well, ITIL Service Design
processes and that concludes this episode.

489
00:27:08.370 --> 00:27:12.160
And there is a lot of episodes
in the ITIL MALC library, so

490
00:27:12.160 --> 00:27:14.230
make sure you catch every
single one of them.

491
00:27:14.230 --> 00:27:16.105
Terry, once again, marvelous,
marvelous information.

492
00:27:16.105 --> 00:27:17.940
Anything else you wanna wrap up with or
no?

493
00:27:17.940 --> 00:27:19.830
>> That's it for the supply,
we're gonna come back and

494
00:27:19.830 --> 00:27:21.728
we'll take a look at
Service Transition processes.

495
00:27:21.728 --> 00:27:24.444
>> Okay, well, thank you for
watching ITProTV and

496
00:27:24.444 --> 00:27:26.837
remember a good IT pro is always learning.

497
00:27:26.837 --> 00:27:27.653
I'm Zach Memos.

498
00:27:27.653 --> 00:27:28.475
>> I'm Terry Decker.

499
00:27:28.475 --> 00:27:31.244
>> And we shall see you very soon.

500
00:27:31.244 --> 00:27:37.344
[MUSIC]

501
00:27:37.344 --> 00:27:40.563
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of the ST processes.
episodes.title: Service Transition Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.519
Welcome to ITproTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.519 --> 00:00:06.767
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.767 --> 00:00:08.618
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.618 --> 00:00:12.380
>> You're watching ITproTV.

5
00:00:12.380 --> 00:00:14.958
>> Hello again and thank you for
joining us at ITPROTV,

6
00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.839
helping you to learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.839 --> 00:00:20.150
I am your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC and

8
00:00:20.150 --> 00:00:23.190
we are looking at service
transition processes.

9
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:25.196
With our very own Terry Decker.

10
00:00:25.196 --> 00:00:27.030
Terry, let's get on
that ITIL island again.

11
00:00:27.030 --> 00:00:28.130
>> Yeah, thank you very much Zach.

12
00:00:28.130 --> 00:00:29.400
>> Yeah.
>> Welcome back to the island.

13
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:30.410
>> Yes, indeed.

14
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:34.140
As Zach mentioned, we're gonna be diving
into the service transition processes.

15
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:36.300
And as we've done for
the service strategy, and

16
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:38.100
the service design processes.

17
00:00:38.100 --> 00:00:42.610
We're going to be focusing on the value
propositions each of the processes makes.

18
00:00:42.610 --> 00:00:46.830
Understanding the value that
the process brings to the mix

19
00:00:46.830 --> 00:00:51.130
is a great way to understand how you can
manage across the life cycle of a service.

20
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:54.530
The operationally speaking when
you get back to the office

21
00:00:54.530 --> 00:00:57.210
looking at where you have failings.

22
00:00:57.210 --> 00:00:59.750
You can look at those failings or
those short comings and

23
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:02.700
say, what process will sure that up?

24
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:06.580
Understanding the value proposition
of these processes helps you

25
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:10.980
identify where your improvements can come
through the processes themselves and

26
00:01:10.980 --> 00:01:12.930
the best practice framework.

27
00:01:12.930 --> 00:01:15.778
Academically speaking, on the exam,
the same type of thing.

28
00:01:15.778 --> 00:01:19.200
You'll see shortcomings either
described in the case study or

29
00:01:19.200 --> 00:01:23.860
described in the scenario and highlighted
in the answers to the questions.

30
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:26.230
Will be those opportunities for
improvement.

31
00:01:26.230 --> 00:01:30.120
Picking the right answer will often be
based on your understanding of the value

32
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:32.870
proposition these processes bring.

33
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:35.590
So let's dive in to
the service transition.

34
00:01:35.590 --> 00:01:39.100
You'll see here, we'll start with
the mother hen if you will transition

35
00:01:39.100 --> 00:01:41.640
planning and support and the value it has.

36
00:01:41.640 --> 00:01:46.170
Just as design coordination shepherds
all the resources of service design,

37
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:47.120
transition planning and

38
00:01:47.120 --> 00:01:51.540
support is the process that shepherds all
the resources within service transition.

39
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:54.640
And by shepherding,
I mean that there arrive on time,

40
00:01:54.640 --> 00:01:58.980
that they arrive with good quality and
that you continually get better.

41
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:03.640
And if you continually get better you
will be able to take on more work, right?

42
00:02:03.640 --> 00:02:06.750
As you can see by the first bullet here,
effective transition planning and

43
00:02:06.750 --> 00:02:10.880
support can significantly improve
a service provider's ability

44
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:15.560
to handle high volumes of change and
releases for their customers.

45
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:17.950
So, if you get good at this,
you can increase scale,

46
00:02:17.950 --> 00:02:22.180
you can increase volume, and therefore
satisfy your customers more quickly and

47
00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:24.910
more thoroughly through
the transition phase.

48
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:30.169
So you can't overstate that, can overstate
that should I say, transition planning and

49
00:02:30.169 --> 00:02:34.660
support is going to make service
transition as a whole more effective.

50
00:02:34.660 --> 00:02:39.520
And because of that, the business can gain
value through higher volume of change and

51
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.550
higher quality of change, all right?

52
00:02:42.550 --> 00:02:46.620
So speaking to change,
the process called Change Management.

53
00:02:46.620 --> 00:02:51.320
A very authoritative process within
the service transition framework

54
00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:54.580
is the Change Management
process that assesses change

55
00:02:54.580 --> 00:02:56.680
in terms of risk and benefit.

56
00:02:56.680 --> 00:02:59.680
And makes sure that
beneficial changes happen.

57
00:02:59.680 --> 00:03:02.220
And not so
beneficial when it's don't, right?

58
00:03:02.220 --> 00:03:05.000
So what's the governing
aspect of transition?

59
00:03:05.000 --> 00:03:08.000
Allowing things to happen or nixing them?

60
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:10.090
Not allowing authorization.

61
00:03:10.090 --> 00:03:13.150
So change management is
highly accountable for

62
00:03:13.150 --> 00:03:17.190
the quality of introducing
change into the environment.

63
00:03:17.190 --> 00:03:18.340
Highly accountable.

64
00:03:18.340 --> 00:03:21.920
A little bit later, we'll talk about
release deployment management.

65
00:03:21.920 --> 00:03:24.800
Release and deployment management
is highly responsible.

66
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:28.560
They make sure things get
done well on time, etc..

67
00:03:28.560 --> 00:03:32.520
Change management authorizes
those things to happen.

68
00:03:32.520 --> 00:03:34.310
It's the gatekeeper, if you will.

69
00:03:34.310 --> 00:03:38.770
Good gatekeeping means good things happen
and all bad things get to stay out.

70
00:03:38.770 --> 00:03:43.520
That's what change management
is primarily for, right?

71
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:46.280
As you look here, you change management
interfaces with other processes.

72
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:47.350
You'll see that certainly,

73
00:03:47.350 --> 00:03:50.590
you're gonna interface with
the Configuration Management System,

74
00:03:50.590 --> 00:03:52.820
or the CMBBS and underneath that.

75
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:56.620
The configuration management system
is gonna be the repository for

76
00:03:56.620 --> 00:04:00.560
all your assets that you care about it,
that you care about.

77
00:04:00.560 --> 00:04:03.670
And that you want to keep
under change control.

78
00:04:03.670 --> 00:04:08.010
So when you want to create a change
record and have a historical record for

79
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:13.685
when changes happen to your key assets,
your configurable items.

80
00:04:13.685 --> 00:04:16.796
You will store the picker
information within the CMS.

81
00:04:16.796 --> 00:04:19.465
Which is a great place for it, right?

82
00:04:19.465 --> 00:04:22.610
And also note that this sort of
graphic shows that you're showing it.

83
00:04:22.610 --> 00:04:25.160
Across the life cycle of any given change.

84
00:04:25.160 --> 00:04:26.780
You know when it was approved.

85
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:29.290
You know when it has been tested.

86
00:04:29.290 --> 00:04:31.610
You know when it has been deployed, etc..

87
00:04:31.610 --> 00:04:34.210
So all these different items
can come play in there.

88
00:04:34.210 --> 00:04:36.610
So service asset configuration management,

89
00:04:36.610 --> 00:04:41.900
enabling the CMS is obviously a key point
of interface between change management.

90
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:45.930
And the rest of the CI's that
youre keeping under control.

91
00:04:47.250 --> 00:04:51.380
Which is a good Segway to SACM, Service
Asset and Configuration Management.

92
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:59.748
My goodness, the value of SACM is
almost equal to its complexity.

93
00:04:59.748 --> 00:05:01.830
[LAUGH] What I mean by that is,
by gosh it's complex.

94
00:05:03.210 --> 00:05:06.030
What is a CI, is what service asset and

95
00:05:06.030 --> 00:05:08.280
configuration management
is first answering.

96
00:05:08.280 --> 00:05:10.860
What do we care about
keeping under control?

97
00:05:10.860 --> 00:05:13.720
SACM is determining what we care about?

98
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:15.470
Do we care about servers?

99
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:17.318
When they change,
do we gonna keep them under control?

100
00:05:17.318 --> 00:05:22.040
We probably would say yes, do we wanna
keep changes to databases under control?

101
00:05:22.040 --> 00:05:23.280
We care about databases,

102
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:27.780
that's a CI, let's make sure changes for
databases are under control.

103
00:05:27.780 --> 00:05:29.200
Do we care about network switches?

104
00:05:29.200 --> 00:05:32.698
Do we care about other components
in the infrastructure?

105
00:05:32.698 --> 00:05:36.700
The answer might be yes, we want those
things under control, let's identify and

106
00:05:36.700 --> 00:05:38.040
let's put it into the CMS.

107
00:05:38.040 --> 00:05:43.368
That's gonna be unique identifier, let's
track the attributes of those things and

108
00:05:43.368 --> 00:05:46.780
make sure that we keep them
up to date ongoing, right?

109
00:05:46.780 --> 00:05:49.678
So if you have a small organization with.

110
00:05:49.678 --> 00:05:53.906
A couple of dozen servers and
a couple of dozen databases perhaps and

111
00:05:53.906 --> 00:05:56.940
a couple web accelerators here and there.

112
00:05:56.940 --> 00:05:59.020
And a pipeline to the world.

113
00:05:59.020 --> 00:06:02.956
Then that CMS challenge is not
nearly as big as operating for

114
00:06:02.956 --> 00:06:07.762
a multinational with 3,000 servers and
multiple links to all kinds

115
00:06:07.762 --> 00:06:11.877
of interfaces throughout
the interwebs if you well, etc..

116
00:06:11.877 --> 00:06:15.432
So, the complexity of this
obviously depends on the size of

117
00:06:15.432 --> 00:06:17.700
complexity organization.

118
00:06:17.700 --> 00:06:23.100
But even for small organizations,
keeping this data current and

119
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:25.510
accurate is a difficult challenge.

120
00:06:25.510 --> 00:06:27.040
You have to have good discipline.

121
00:06:27.040 --> 00:06:30.670
And with the bad data could
come some bad decisions.

122
00:06:30.670 --> 00:06:31.440
As an example,

123
00:06:31.440 --> 00:06:37.210
these relationships among these different
components can help you troubleshooting.

124
00:06:37.210 --> 00:06:41.830
So if you don't keep that data current,
you might be troubleshooting a server

125
00:06:41.830 --> 00:06:44.560
that's not even in the service
chain anymore, right?

126
00:06:44.560 --> 00:06:47.450
Or if you don't keep it current,

127
00:06:47.450 --> 00:06:50.170
you may be working on the wrong server for
that matter.

128
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:53.370
You may be trying to update a server
that's already been updated.

129
00:06:53.370 --> 00:06:57.820
So you can waste effort,
you can misuse your time,

130
00:06:57.820 --> 00:06:59.900
if you will, if you don't have good data.

131
00:06:59.900 --> 00:07:01.950
So even in smaller organizations,

132
00:07:01.950 --> 00:07:06.678
maintaining accurate data ongoing
is a tough challenge for SACM.

133
00:07:06.678 --> 00:07:09.410
SACM gonna identify the CIs and

134
00:07:09.410 --> 00:07:14.410
hope to govern the ongoing maintenance of
all the attributes related to the CIs.

135
00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:17.570
And also show you
the relationship among the CIs,

136
00:07:17.570 --> 00:07:20.880
which is not a trivial matter sometimes.

137
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:24.310
Any given component
could serve 20 services,

138
00:07:24.310 --> 00:07:26.720
depending on where it is
in the infrastructure.

139
00:07:26.720 --> 00:07:28.712
That could be a complex
structure to try to show.

140
00:07:28.712 --> 00:07:31.877
And it may have interdependencies
on three other components you need,

141
00:07:31.877 --> 00:07:32.730
also need to show.

142
00:07:33.920 --> 00:07:36.360
Sometimes they're interdependent.

143
00:07:36.360 --> 00:07:39.905
They rely on each other and
work in some sort of fail over fashion.

144
00:07:39.905 --> 00:07:41.152
How do you show that kind of relationship?

145
00:07:41.152 --> 00:07:44.985
You get the idea that it's not
necessarily a trivial matter.

146
00:07:44.985 --> 00:07:47.805
The value though cannot be overstated.

147
00:07:47.805 --> 00:07:53.325
The value of having awareness over your
CIs, and keeping them under control.

148
00:07:53.325 --> 00:07:55.715
Because it helps so many other processes.

149
00:07:55.715 --> 00:07:59.105
It helps financial management, it helps
change management, troubleshooting and

150
00:07:59.105 --> 00:08:00.275
problem management.

151
00:08:00.275 --> 00:08:02.575
Doing root cause analysis for instance.

152
00:08:02.575 --> 00:08:07.740
It can help with the analysis of
capacity planning, capacity fulfillment,

153
00:08:07.740 --> 00:08:09.290
it can serve with that.

154
00:08:09.290 --> 00:08:13.500
It can help with demand management
situations, all sorts of things.

155
00:08:13.500 --> 00:08:18.585
Having good data about all
your CIs can form the baseline

156
00:08:18.585 --> 00:08:22.415
of good information management across
all the stages of a life cycle.

157
00:08:22.415 --> 00:08:23.685
SACM is pretty darn important, right?

158
00:08:25.155 --> 00:08:27.945
>> So SACM should be right
there at the forefront almost?

159
00:08:27.945 --> 00:08:30.465
>> Absolutely, it's probably
one of the foundational ones.

160
00:08:30.465 --> 00:08:31.390
Getting it right.

161
00:08:31.390 --> 00:08:32.230
In the absence of it.

162
00:08:32.230 --> 00:08:35.200
You'll continue to stub your toe,
basically.

163
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:37.980
Now, release and deployment,
close related to change management.

164
00:08:37.980 --> 00:08:41.630
In that change management
authorizes things to happen.

165
00:08:41.630 --> 00:08:43.580
Release and deployment gets them done.

166
00:08:43.580 --> 00:08:48.796
So, for instance, change management
authorizes the planning of a release.

167
00:08:48.796 --> 00:08:51.246
So that you can get it
scheduled correctly and

168
00:08:51.246 --> 00:08:55.610
understand the complexities both
technically and organizationally.

169
00:08:55.610 --> 00:08:57.130
Is there a big training component?

170
00:08:57.130 --> 00:08:59.320
Is there a little training component?

171
00:08:59.320 --> 00:09:01.640
Is there lots of technology
that needs to be coordinated?

172
00:09:01.640 --> 00:09:05.210
Do we have to coordinate across
multiple service providers.

173
00:09:05.210 --> 00:09:07.580
We got the server team,
the database team and

174
00:09:07.580 --> 00:09:11.060
the web services team, all have to
come together on a given weekend.

175
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:12.500
How can you get those things coordinated?

176
00:09:12.500 --> 00:09:17.850
So, the complexity on the technology side,
the complexity on the organizational side,

177
00:09:17.850 --> 00:09:21.720
the training requirements are all
part of the planning stage.

178
00:09:21.720 --> 00:09:25.400
Change management could authorize
the due diligence to plan it out, and

179
00:09:25.400 --> 00:09:29.550
then later on authorize the building and

180
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:32.050
testing which release and
deployment management does.

181
00:09:32.050 --> 00:09:33.400
They actually build the components,

182
00:09:33.400 --> 00:09:37.110
they build the training plan, they build
the test plan, they execute the tests.

183
00:09:37.110 --> 00:09:39.900
They make sure that those
things are in play, right.

184
00:09:41.260 --> 00:09:45.610
Ultimately, the change management will
authorize the deployment saying, yup,

185
00:09:45.610 --> 00:09:46.580
you did all the testing.

186
00:09:46.580 --> 00:09:49.620
We agree with all of that, we now
authorize releasing deployment management

187
00:09:49.620 --> 00:09:54.260
as a process to go ahead and deploy
this into the production environment.

188
00:09:54.260 --> 00:09:57.020
And then, there's some sort of
follow-through at the other side.

189
00:09:57.020 --> 00:10:01.960
In the absence of a regimented
approach to these specific activities

190
00:10:01.960 --> 00:10:05.281
of approve a planning, building, testing,

191
00:10:05.281 --> 00:10:09.724
deployment, and closure in
the absence of a methodical way.

192
00:10:09.724 --> 00:10:12.127
You're just kind of swimming
along inefficiently.

193
00:10:12.127 --> 00:10:16.079
Having a release and deploy management
as a disciplined process will help you

194
00:10:16.079 --> 00:10:20.297
streamline the deployment of your releases
and govern them effectively, okay.

195
00:10:24.230 --> 00:10:25.720
Now, Service Validation and Testing.

196
00:10:25.720 --> 00:10:29.350
I just mentioned that one of the steps
of releasing deployment management is

197
00:10:29.350 --> 00:10:31.156
building and testing.

198
00:10:31.156 --> 00:10:36.010
And Service Validation and Testing as
a separate process is a relatively new

199
00:10:36.010 --> 00:10:41.500
addition to ITL, brought to life
in 2011 as part of the updates.

200
00:10:41.500 --> 00:10:46.100
And Service Validation and
Testing is seen as

201
00:10:46.100 --> 00:10:50.600
a specific process unique to
the challenges of validation and testing.

202
00:10:50.600 --> 00:10:55.140
Now notice the word Service Validation and
Testing.

203
00:10:55.140 --> 00:10:59.270
We're not talking necessarily
only about solutions or systems.

204
00:10:59.270 --> 00:11:02.990
Certainly you'll do UAT,
you'll do system integration testing, UAT,

205
00:11:02.990 --> 00:11:04.680
user acceptance testing.

206
00:11:04.680 --> 00:11:06.530
System integration testing perhaps,

207
00:11:06.530 --> 00:11:09.520
perhaps you'll do load testing or
performance testing.

208
00:11:09.520 --> 00:11:13.010
You can test technology
absolutely its in the scope

209
00:11:13.010 --> 00:11:14.820
of Service Validation and Testing.

210
00:11:14.820 --> 00:11:20.670
But remember service validation, or
service, is something bigger than system.

211
00:11:20.670 --> 00:11:25.020
So whatever your service acceptance
criteria turns out to be which is

212
00:11:25.020 --> 00:11:26.990
decided and service design.

213
00:11:26.990 --> 00:11:29.610
Service Validation and
Testing is going to meet,

214
00:11:29.610 --> 00:11:33.420
make sure that service accepts
this criteria has been met.

215
00:11:33.420 --> 00:11:36.264
Which again could include all
this test that are passed,

216
00:11:36.264 --> 00:11:37.933
this technology test or passed.

217
00:11:37.933 --> 00:11:41.880
But also can include things like
training has been completed.

218
00:11:41.880 --> 00:11:45.650
So how would you validate the training
has been completed is it a scouts honor?

219
00:11:45.650 --> 00:11:47.600
Which could be, totally appropriate.

220
00:11:47.600 --> 00:11:50.450
They said they took the training so
you checked the box, right?

221
00:11:50.450 --> 00:11:52.060
You asked them, did you have the training?

222
00:11:52.060 --> 00:11:53.970
Yes, box checked.

223
00:11:53.970 --> 00:11:56.210
That could be your point of validation.

224
00:11:56.210 --> 00:11:58.280
Or is it more thorough than that?

225
00:11:58.280 --> 00:12:00.310
Do you actually give them a test?

226
00:12:00.310 --> 00:12:01.760
Say okay, you said you took the training.

227
00:12:01.760 --> 00:12:04.540
He's a quiz, show me you know
what you're talking about here?

228
00:12:04.540 --> 00:12:07.690
So you walk them through the steps for
instance.

229
00:12:07.690 --> 00:12:12.830
In my own experience we used to validate
the training of the service desk for

230
00:12:12.830 --> 00:12:16.630
instance by calling him up and
saying here is the scenario.

231
00:12:16.630 --> 00:12:19.790
Simulating a call saying,
here's what we have.

232
00:12:19.790 --> 00:12:21.200
What do you do, right?

233
00:12:21.200 --> 00:12:24.000
And can they follow the right
script of troubleshooting?

234
00:12:24.000 --> 00:12:27.020
Can they find the right answer or
the right workaround, etc.?

235
00:12:27.020 --> 00:12:28.740
We'd actually walk them through the paces.

236
00:12:28.740 --> 00:12:30.520
So, yes they had training, but

237
00:12:30.520 --> 00:12:33.010
then we would validate that
that training was effective.

238
00:12:33.010 --> 00:12:35.730
By pushing them through
a little exercise if you will.

239
00:12:35.730 --> 00:12:40.260
So again, Service Validation and Testing
goes beyond system validation and testing.

240
00:12:40.260 --> 00:12:43.380
And it's all within the scope
of this process called

241
00:12:43.380 --> 00:12:44.860
Service Validation and Testing.

242
00:12:44.860 --> 00:12:48.930
Now, in the absence of this
what's the value being missed?

243
00:12:48.930 --> 00:12:52.560
I mean I have a feeling that if
you've been in IT long at all.

244
00:12:52.560 --> 00:12:57.180
You've seen effective testing, and
you've seen ineffective testing.

245
00:12:57.180 --> 00:13:02.920
So iTool is simply presenting this as
a key discipline so that you don't

246
00:13:02.920 --> 00:13:08.210
fall into the pit of bad testing, or
the manifestations of bad testing.

247
00:13:08.210 --> 00:13:12.960
If you deliver something that tested out
perfectly In the test environment, and

248
00:13:12.960 --> 00:13:15.580
then you launched it in the production and
it falls over the first day,

249
00:13:15.580 --> 00:13:18.030
and you're troubleshooting
all kinds of things.

250
00:13:18.030 --> 00:13:20.340
Then obviously your testing
wasn't robust enough,

251
00:13:20.340 --> 00:13:23.455
you didn't manage the environments
well enough, etc..

252
00:13:23.455 --> 00:13:26.165
So whatever the cause of bad testing,

253
00:13:26.165 --> 00:13:29.975
or good testing Service Validation and
Testing, as a process,

254
00:13:29.975 --> 00:13:34.485
is gonna be the discipline that you
need to make sure that's well governed.

255
00:13:34.485 --> 00:13:36.625
As this shows up on the exam,

256
00:13:36.625 --> 00:13:41.600
it's gonna be the kind of situation
where there'll be proof of bad testing.

257
00:13:41.600 --> 00:13:44.790
Or there'll be proof of ineffective
environmental management or

258
00:13:44.790 --> 00:13:48.110
there'll be proof of no testing.

259
00:13:48.110 --> 00:13:49.520
That sort of thing.

260
00:13:49.520 --> 00:13:53.410
And in the absence of those, you're gonna
manifest those things in certain problems.

261
00:13:53.410 --> 00:13:54.476
How would you fix that?

262
00:13:54.476 --> 00:13:58.917
Maybe do some analysis on how chronic the
problem is and consider the adoption of

263
00:13:58.917 --> 00:14:03.220
a service and validation and
testing receipt as an example.

264
00:14:03.220 --> 00:14:03.720
All right.

265
00:14:03.720 --> 00:14:04.220
>> Awesome.

266
00:14:06.700 --> 00:14:08.140
>> Now change evaluation.

267
00:14:09.840 --> 00:14:11.358
Interesting, interesting, history.

268
00:14:11.358 --> 00:14:12.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now

269
00:14:14.020 --> 00:14:18.590
change management is the process
that evaluates changes.

270
00:14:19.810 --> 00:14:24.879
But you can formalize change evaluation to
be its own separate process, and therefore

271
00:14:24.879 --> 00:14:29.680
feed the change management process with
a good evaluation of the change, right?

272
00:14:29.680 --> 00:14:37.900
Just as release and deployment management
has a step called build and test.

273
00:14:37.900 --> 00:14:39.020
Testing tends to be so

274
00:14:39.020 --> 00:14:43.850
nuanced that you have a separate process
called Service Validation and Testing.

275
00:14:43.850 --> 00:14:48.880
So again, change evaluation can
precede the approval of a change.

276
00:14:50.180 --> 00:14:55.070
It also can come after the implementation
of a change to make sure

277
00:14:55.070 --> 00:15:00.510
that the value that was sought Is
actually the value being delivered.

278
00:15:00.510 --> 00:15:03.800
So consider the change of
evaluation s of formal process

279
00:15:03.800 --> 00:15:06.680
to predict what value should be given.

280
00:15:06.680 --> 00:15:10.045
And therefore, feed the decision
whether or not to approve a change.

281
00:15:10.045 --> 00:15:14.850
Change evaluation can also be brought
after a change is implemented

282
00:15:14.850 --> 00:15:17.560
to evaluate whether the change
delivered the appropriate value.

283
00:15:18.710 --> 00:15:19.577
Now, what's value?

284
00:15:19.577 --> 00:15:21.860
We talked about this before.

285
00:15:21.860 --> 00:15:25.920
The only arbitrary value that really
makes any difference is the business.

286
00:15:25.920 --> 00:15:32.380
So if you've promised that a change you're
making is going to improve availability.

287
00:15:32.380 --> 00:15:37.280
Or it's going to allow them to
resolve tickets more quickly or

288
00:15:37.280 --> 00:15:40.880
reduce the volume of incidents
that you're receiving.

289
00:15:40.880 --> 00:15:44.280
If the change is promising to reduce those
volumes or increase the availability,

290
00:15:44.280 --> 00:15:48.290
whatever they might be, then you want
to evaluate it post defacto, right?

291
00:15:48.290 --> 00:15:51.560
After you've launched it or
brought the change about,

292
00:15:51.560 --> 00:15:55.870
you might wanna evaluate to see
did we achieve that value, right?

293
00:15:55.870 --> 00:15:57.030
Or you are just kind of guessing.

294
00:15:57.030 --> 00:15:58.040
We think this might work.

295
00:15:58.040 --> 00:16:03.305
So you try this and you find out
the availability actually went down.

296
00:16:03.305 --> 00:16:09.234
A formal change evaluation will give you
the data the objective view of whether or

297
00:16:09.234 --> 00:16:14.070
not the value you are seeking
is actually delivered.

298
00:16:14.070 --> 00:16:17.250
Now, does that mean you
evaluate every single change?

299
00:16:17.250 --> 00:16:18.450
Not necessarily.

300
00:16:18.450 --> 00:16:20.630
I mean formally,
evaluate every single change,

301
00:16:20.630 --> 00:16:25.140
yes, you evaluate all changes
at some level of rigor.

302
00:16:26.260 --> 00:16:31.810
Not all changes would require a full
formal change evaluation process.

303
00:16:31.810 --> 00:16:34.920
That's what your governance models
will take care of, which ones do,

304
00:16:34.920 --> 00:16:36.410
which ones don't.

305
00:16:36.410 --> 00:16:40.440
But having a formal regime to
evaluate the effectives of change

306
00:16:40.440 --> 00:16:44.580
is an important value you can add through
the change evaluation process, okay?

307
00:16:46.470 --> 00:16:49.850
Now, circling back around to
something we've talked about already,

308
00:16:49.850 --> 00:16:50.650
knowledge management.

309
00:16:50.650 --> 00:16:54.170
It's one of those transition processes
that happens to show up in transition.

310
00:16:54.170 --> 00:16:57.810
But we've also seen where knowledge
management is absolutely in play

311
00:16:57.810 --> 00:17:02.290
at every single stage of the life cycle,
every time, all the time.

312
00:17:02.290 --> 00:17:05.550
Knowledge management is data,
it's information.

313
00:17:05.550 --> 00:17:08.890
It's becoming knowledge of some
sort of presentation layer

314
00:17:08.890 --> 00:17:13.500
of this information to make it
possible to discern knowledge.

315
00:17:13.500 --> 00:17:16.610
And then hopefully, enable wise decisions.

316
00:17:16.610 --> 00:17:20.670
Now, wisdom is not in
the domain of just one stage.

317
00:17:20.670 --> 00:17:23.748
You need to be wise across
all the stages of life cycle.

318
00:17:23.748 --> 00:17:28.329
So to call out knowledge management
is a service transaction process is

319
00:17:28.329 --> 00:17:29.635
really a misnomer.

320
00:17:29.635 --> 00:17:33.203
It happens to be born there in the book
called service transaction but

321
00:17:33.203 --> 00:17:37.800
knowledge management is something we do
whether we have a formal process or not.

322
00:17:37.800 --> 00:17:40.860
We have to share information
among ourselves.

323
00:17:40.860 --> 00:17:46.000
Formalizing knowledge management builds
the culture of knowledge sharing.

324
00:17:46.000 --> 00:17:50.600
And that's the primary value it delivers,
a holistic approach

325
00:17:50.600 --> 00:17:55.140
to how information is shared, across
the organization and across all stages.

326
00:17:55.140 --> 00:17:57.640
That's the value proposition
of knowledge management.

327
00:17:58.950 --> 00:17:59.450
All right.

328
00:18:01.080 --> 00:18:04.264
That's the service transition
process is in a nutshell.

329
00:18:04.264 --> 00:18:06.320
>> Wow okay, well we did that.

330
00:18:06.320 --> 00:18:08.900
ITIL MALC service transition processes.

331
00:18:08.900 --> 00:18:09.880
Thank you for watching this.

332
00:18:09.880 --> 00:18:14.090
There's a whole bunch of
episodes in the ITIL MALC series.

333
00:18:14.090 --> 00:18:15.800
Make sure you watch
every single on of them.

334
00:18:15.800 --> 00:18:16.860
Terry, thanks again.

335
00:18:16.860 --> 00:18:17.507
You're amazing.

336
00:18:17.507 --> 00:18:19.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's just amazing.

337
00:18:19.560 --> 00:18:21.710
And thank you for watching ITPROTV.

338
00:18:22.880 --> 00:18:25.880
Remember, a good ITPro is always learning.

339
00:18:25.880 --> 00:18:26.670
I'm Zach Memos.

340
00:18:26.670 --> 00:18:27.460
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

341
00:18:27.460 --> 00:18:31.090
>> We shall see you very soon.

342
00:18:31.090 --> 00:18:36.739
[MUSIC]

343
00:18:36.739 --> 00:18:38.675
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

I want to, as we did with the Everest.

So I to want to frame the context of this,

re energizing the value proposition for

Understanding what these processes do.

Of course, it's important, understanding

more important as you consider

So that's going to help you operationally,

understanding the value

If you need to sell the idea to someone,

00:01:03.880 --> 00:01:06.250
like, why to we need
the availability management process?

25
00:01:06.250 --> 00:01:08.790
Or why do we need a portfolio
management process?

26
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:13.150
The reason why is because some
value can be delivered from them.

27
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:16.110
ITIL didn't make this stuff up,
they did a lot of research.

28
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:17.570
And as we look at service operations,

29
00:01:17.570 --> 00:01:20.820
looking at those five processes
within service operations.

30
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:24.080
Again, look to reenergize
your understanding of

31
00:01:24.080 --> 00:01:28.220
why these processes exist,
not just what do they do.

32
00:01:28.220 --> 00:01:28.720
Right?
So

33
00:01:28.720 --> 00:01:30.190
first of all,
let's have a look at event management.

34
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:33.790
You recall that event management is

35
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:38.600
the process that manages those things
that can automatically be detected.

36
00:01:38.600 --> 00:01:42.105
So the detection of an event is automated

37
00:01:42.105 --> 00:01:47.480
that can in itself lead to
the automation of a response.

38
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:50.840
So if you automatically detect an event,
you have a basis for

39
00:01:50.840 --> 00:01:52.830
automating your response to the event.

40
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:55.650
And therefore, you could keep
incidents from even happening.

41
00:01:55.650 --> 00:02:00.664
Right, so if as an example
an intrusion detection system for

42
00:02:00.664 --> 00:02:06.770
security measures is a very
elaborate event management system.

43
00:02:06.770 --> 00:02:09.080
If it has algorithms working within it so

44
00:02:09.080 --> 00:02:14.170
that it can understand the behavior
on the network and perceive or

45
00:02:14.170 --> 00:02:19.370
detect, I should say, anomalous
activity that could be suspicious.

46
00:02:19.370 --> 00:02:22.590
And it could automate
the response to suppress it or

47
00:02:22.590 --> 00:02:24.980
to limit its effects, as an example.

48
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:29.750
So the value of management really
is borne on the early detection.

49
00:02:29.750 --> 00:02:30.960
Right.
And therefore,

50
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:36.240
the prevention of significant
incidents happening.

51
00:02:36.240 --> 00:02:38.854
Okay.
So as we decided on service design is

52
00:02:38.854 --> 00:02:43.601
involved in event management as

the business value that it brings.

00:16:11.480 --> 00:16:14.410
So you're going to talk about
the purpose and activities involved.

290
00:16:14.410 --> 00:16:17.070
But ultimately,
you're going to have to highlight why.

291
00:16:17.070 --> 00:16:20.890
This process exists,
not just what does it do, all right?

292
00:16:20.890 --> 00:16:21.740
That's that, Zack.

293
00:16:21.740 --> 00:16:22.690
>> Excellent job, Jerry.

294
00:16:22.690 --> 00:16:24.470
Service operation processes.

295
00:16:24.470 --> 00:16:25.860
This is ITIL MALC.

296
00:16:25.860 --> 00:16:27.900
So many episodes in this series.

297
00:16:27.900 --> 00:16:28.470
Watch them all.

298
00:16:28.470 --> 00:16:30.210
You'll be glad you did.

299
00:16:30.210 --> 00:16:33.040
And thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

300
00:16:33.040 --> 00:16:35.950
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

301
00:16:35.950 --> 00:16:36.903
I'm Zack.

302
00:16:36.903 --> 00:16:37.856
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

303
00:16:37.856 --> 00:16:38.995
>> We'll see you soon.

304
00:16:40.528 --> 00:16:45.857
[MUSIC]

305
00:16:45.857 --> 00:16:48.711
Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach explain why 'CSI' should be positioned throughout all stages of the lifecycle.
episodes.title: Universal Value of CSI
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.780
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.780 --> 00:00:08.355
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.355 --> 00:00:12.055
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.055 --> 00:00:14.968
>> Hello, and thank you again for
joining us on ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.968 --> 00:00:17.380
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.380 --> 00:00:21.680
I'm Zach Memos, your host for
ITIL MALC as we continue with this series.

7
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:25.295
Right now,
we're looking at universal value of CSI.

8
00:00:25.295 --> 00:00:29.430
And bringing us all the information
we need is Terry Decker.

9
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:31.555
>> Thanks Zach,
happy to be here as always.

10
00:00:31.555 --> 00:00:32.890
>> Glad to have you again.

11
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:36.360
>> And as Zach said, we're gonna be
talking about the universal value of CSI,

12
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:37.900
which is kinda interesting.

13
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:42.108
We talked about in these previous
episodes, the service strategy processes,

14
00:00:42.108 --> 00:00:43.812
the service design processes.

15
00:00:43.812 --> 00:00:45.790
And it was always plural, processes.

16
00:00:45.790 --> 00:00:48.800
And when we get to CSI,
there's only one process,

17
00:00:48.800 --> 00:00:51.670
the seven step improvement process.

18
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:57.349
The simplicity of discussing CSI
belies its importance, it really does.

19
00:00:57.349 --> 00:01:02.516
Cuz it is a fairly simple approach,
it's fairly simple to teach.

20
00:01:02.516 --> 00:01:05.632
It's even fairly intuitive
to actually implement.

21
00:01:05.632 --> 00:01:09.039
The challenge is finding
the right improvements and

22
00:01:09.039 --> 00:01:14.005
working on the right ones at the right
time and seeing them through, right?

23
00:01:14.005 --> 00:01:17.066
That's where the challenge really comes,
but conceptually and

24
00:01:17.066 --> 00:01:19.828
academically, it's fairly straightforward.

25
00:01:19.828 --> 00:01:22.043
Now, if you'll look here at the slide,

26
00:01:22.043 --> 00:01:25.575
one of the value statements of
seven step improvement process.

27
00:01:25.575 --> 00:01:29.971
That you ensure current and
future business requirements can be met,

28
00:01:29.971 --> 00:01:31.630
that's fairly generic.

29
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:34.415
You're able to improve services
without spending more money,

30
00:01:34.415 --> 00:01:36.077
that's another way to look at it too.

31
00:01:36.077 --> 00:01:42.302
To continually improve services
without spending more money, right?

32
00:01:42.302 --> 00:01:46.480
So that's the trick and
that's the real value that CSI brings.

33
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:53.764
Now, as we look here, CSI is certainly,
it's a stage, it has its own book.

34
00:01:53.764 --> 00:01:56.855
And ITIL has described the five
stages of the life cycle.

35
00:01:56.855 --> 00:02:01.138
Service strategy, design,
transition, operation, and CSI.

36
00:02:01.138 --> 00:02:04.538
It gets its own book,
it's even called a stage, but

37
00:02:04.538 --> 00:02:07.880
a stage seems to follow
some chronological order.

38
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:10.930
Certainly, you come up with a strategy
before you design something.

39
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:13.840
And you design something
before you transition it, and

40
00:02:13.840 --> 00:02:16.899
you transition it and
it becomes live in operation.

41
00:02:18.330 --> 00:02:20.695
So I like the fact that it's own book,
it's certainly appropriate.

42
00:02:20.695 --> 00:02:24.520
The fact that it's called a stage is
somewhat of a misnomer because it's

43
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:25.520
always open.

44
00:02:25.520 --> 00:02:29.803
It's always open for business,
it should just be the way you work, right?

45
00:02:29.803 --> 00:02:34.970
So CSI is not necessarily a stage
because it's always there.

46
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:37.289
And, as we've described
on the screen here,

47
00:02:37.289 --> 00:02:39.912
the CSI is certainly involved
in service strategy.

48
00:02:39.912 --> 00:02:44.340
And service design and
service transition and service operations.

49
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:49.023
It's there for all of them,
trying to improve all of them, right?

50
00:02:49.023 --> 00:02:52.295
It could be for instance,
a CSI initiative,

51
00:02:52.295 --> 00:02:57.130
like an improvement initiative
could be a strategic initiative.

52
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:03.080
If you hope to improve the quality
of a service that requires

53
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:08.150
a major upgrade to the platform and
the softwares being used by the client.

54
00:03:08.150 --> 00:03:12.960
You're getting away from mainframe and
W terminals perhaps to an intuitive

55
00:03:12.960 --> 00:03:16.670
web interface,
a major change to the front end.

56
00:03:16.670 --> 00:03:18.820
As well as a major change to the back end,

57
00:03:18.820 --> 00:03:21.510
that could be your strategic
direction you're making, right?

58
00:03:21.510 --> 00:03:23.280
Well, this could have
been born out of CSI,

59
00:03:23.280 --> 00:03:27.700
you could have done lots of customer
surveys and seen the results.

60
00:03:27.700 --> 00:03:31.850
And gotten a lot of customer feedback
that says, this is not working very well,

61
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:33.990
it's too hard to use, not very intuitive.

62
00:03:33.990 --> 00:03:36.081
Could we have a web interface instead?

63
00:03:36.081 --> 00:03:40.430
Right, so CSI could feed strategy,
certainly could.

64
00:03:40.430 --> 00:03:44.954
Certainly CSI could be there to help
with design in transition operations.

65
00:03:44.954 --> 00:03:50.435
Have you ever operated or had to
operate a service or an application or

66
00:03:50.435 --> 00:03:54.511
a system, if you will,
that wasn't fully baked?

67
00:03:54.511 --> 00:03:59.210
You got it and
it was clunky, it fell over.

68
00:03:59.210 --> 00:04:02.557
And you discovered needs for
improvement, and the needs for

69
00:04:02.557 --> 00:04:07.090
improvement actually could have been
forestalled up in service design, right?

70
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:12.885
Service design as its value proposition is
to make sure there's no remediation work,

71
00:04:12.885 --> 00:04:15.535
as little remediation work as possible.

72
00:04:15.535 --> 00:04:18.610
Well, if you're always remediating
things here in service operation then

73
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:21.750
maybe what you gotta go
improve is service design.

74
00:04:21.750 --> 00:04:25.520
So CSI can certainly motivate improvements
to the service design process and

75
00:04:25.520 --> 00:04:27.032
of course, with transition.

76
00:04:27.032 --> 00:04:31.379
I mean, I can cite all kinds of examples
here but a common one, at least I

77
00:04:31.379 --> 00:04:36.720
experienced was where we bring something
new into the operational environment.

78
00:04:36.720 --> 00:04:39.465
And it breaks and someone says,
well, did you test it?

79
00:04:39.465 --> 00:04:40.889
And I said yep, we tested it.

80
00:04:40.889 --> 00:04:43.802
And you go back and
look in the environments and

81
00:04:43.802 --> 00:04:48.358
you realize you tested it on a test
environment that wasn't a reasonable

82
00:04:48.358 --> 00:04:51.362
enough replica of
the operation environment.

83
00:04:51.362 --> 00:04:55.035
So the test was not really that valid,
it worked in the test environment,

84
00:04:55.035 --> 00:04:57.150
why doesn't it work in operations?

85
00:04:57.150 --> 00:05:00.090
Well, because operations or a production
environment has all these other

86
00:05:00.090 --> 00:05:02.980
configurations that conflict
with that particular code.

87
00:05:04.010 --> 00:05:08.538
Again, we have a successful
pass in transition but

88
00:05:08.538 --> 00:05:13.499
it failed when we actually
brought it into operations.

89
00:05:13.499 --> 00:05:16.999
CSI can look at that kind of data and
say, well, what's up with our testing and

90
00:05:16.999 --> 00:05:18.340
validation regime?

91
00:05:18.340 --> 00:05:19.294
Let's improve it, right?

92
00:05:19.294 --> 00:05:21.024
And of course, day to day operations.

93
00:05:21.024 --> 00:05:25.948
If your service desk is resolving
incidents at a pretty strong clip but

94
00:05:25.948 --> 00:05:30.390
not meeting the targets in
the service level agreement.

95
00:05:30.390 --> 00:05:36.010
For instance, they're supposed to resolve
80% of the tickets within two hours and

96
00:05:36.010 --> 00:05:39.300
they're only resolving about 60%
of the tickets within two hours.

97
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:40.972
That's operational data you're getting,
right?

98
00:05:40.972 --> 00:05:44.580
What could you do to help improve that,
right?

99
00:05:44.580 --> 00:05:46.430
Reduce the incidents perhaps,

100
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:49.400
get better at troubleshooting,
have a better known error database.

101
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:53.390
Wherever the cookie crumbs may lie,
follow them through

102
00:05:53.390 --> 00:05:58.630
a methodical CSI process and you can
improve day to day operations as well.

103
00:05:58.630 --> 00:06:03.480
So again, to reinforce this idea, I like
the fact that CSI gets its own book, and

104
00:06:03.480 --> 00:06:04.850
if you wanna call it a stage.

105
00:06:04.850 --> 00:06:10.030
That's all right too, but actually, it
should be embedded into everything we do.

106
00:06:10.030 --> 00:06:12.580
It just becomes the way we work,
all right?

107
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:17.800
Now here's some examples as it plays out
as it relates to some specific processes.

108
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:22.354
Now you'll recall that the seven step
process has, and here's four of them,

109
00:06:22.354 --> 00:06:25.942
gather and process, analyze,
present and use the data, and

110
00:06:25.942 --> 00:06:27.894
implementing the improvement.

111
00:06:27.894 --> 00:06:32.524
So there's four of them,
what we're missing are the three steps

112
00:06:32.524 --> 00:06:37.080
related to the actual defining
what we are going to measure.

113
00:06:37.080 --> 00:06:41.313
What data we're gonna get, I should say,
defining the data we're gonna get.

114
00:06:41.313 --> 00:06:44.613
And how does that relate to the business,
so the overall vision or

115
00:06:44.613 --> 00:06:46.360
the strategy of the improvement?

116
00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:52.050
So gathering and processing are actually
a couple of different steps there,

117
00:06:52.050 --> 00:06:56.160
service level management involved
in the gathering and processing.

118
00:06:56.160 --> 00:06:58.610
Service level management
has one of its jobs,

119
00:06:58.610 --> 00:07:00.880
is to make sure you're gathering data.

120
00:07:00.880 --> 00:07:04.910
The example I just mentioned
that there's a target for

121
00:07:04.910 --> 00:07:07.830
80% of the tickets to be
resolved within two hours.

122
00:07:07.830 --> 00:07:11.930
You're only resolving 60% that's
coming from service level management,

123
00:07:11.930 --> 00:07:14.610
you have the target that came
from service level management.

124
00:07:14.610 --> 00:07:18.520
You also have the ongoing monitoring,
that came from service level management.

125
00:07:18.520 --> 00:07:23.470
And you have the reporting, we're only
getting 60%, so you get the idea there.

126
00:07:23.470 --> 00:07:27.220
Now, not to belabor this point too much,
but

127
00:07:27.220 --> 00:07:32.680
each process has the effectiveness
of being measured.

128
00:07:32.680 --> 00:07:37.532
That's one of the ITIL principles is that
each process has a characteristic of being

129
00:07:37.532 --> 00:07:38.360
measurable.

130
00:07:38.360 --> 00:07:41.370
The implication is, there,
is that you're measuring it.

131
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:45.480
If you are measuring a process,
whatever the process might be,

132
00:07:45.480 --> 00:07:49.181
you get data that can point
to improvement opportunities.

133
00:07:49.181 --> 00:07:54.023
So again, availability management,
if you've promised 99% availability and

134
00:07:54.023 --> 00:07:57.980
you're only delivering 98%, ding, ding,
ding, you have an opportunity for

135
00:07:57.980 --> 00:07:59.148
improvement, right?

136
00:07:59.148 --> 00:08:00.320
So really,

137
00:08:00.320 --> 00:08:04.190
I'm just repeating the same thing as I go
through all of these different processes.

138
00:08:04.190 --> 00:08:06.356
How can these processes be measured?

139
00:08:06.356 --> 00:08:07.718
If they are measured,

140
00:08:07.718 --> 00:08:12.020
you have a dataset on which you
can brace improvement ideas on.

141
00:08:12.020 --> 00:08:15.030
That's really what this points to, so
again, we could look at any one of these.

142
00:08:15.030 --> 00:08:18.020
I used incident management
as one of the ideas.

143
00:08:18.020 --> 00:08:22.690
Financial management,
things cost a lot, let's reduce cost.

144
00:08:22.690 --> 00:08:24.690
That's a measurement, right?

145
00:08:24.690 --> 00:08:28.482
How much does it cost to
resolve a four-hour outage?

146
00:08:28.482 --> 00:08:31.590
Is there a cost associated with
that that we can point to?

147
00:08:31.590 --> 00:08:34.355
So we have an availability
management figure,

148
00:08:34.355 --> 00:08:38.610
99% is our target,
we're only getting 98% there, right?

149
00:08:38.610 --> 00:08:40.900
But what's that actually cost?

150
00:08:40.900 --> 00:08:42.818
Well, then now you have a linkup
to financial management.

151
00:08:42.818 --> 00:08:45.906
Could you come up with a cost basis for
outages and

152
00:08:45.906 --> 00:08:48.930
therefore improve on
the money side of things?

153
00:08:50.110 --> 00:08:54.290
So really, all this points to is
an ability to measure your processes and

154
00:08:54.290 --> 00:08:57.940
based on those measurements,
come up with ideas for improvement.

155
00:08:57.940 --> 00:08:59.120
>> Checks and balances.

156
00:08:59.120 --> 00:09:03.480
>> Absolutely, now as you see as we depart
a little bit, down near the bottom here,

157
00:09:03.480 --> 00:09:08.370
we've got Problem management is there for
the analysis in presenting and using.

158
00:09:08.370 --> 00:09:12.820
I like this a lot, problem management
is a very deliberative process.

159
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:16.020
By deliberation it means,
it finds the root cause,

160
00:09:16.020 --> 00:09:19.900
it does the really deep dive
into the analysis of things.

161
00:09:19.900 --> 00:09:22.469
And provides a way forward for
getting rid of it,

162
00:09:22.469 --> 00:09:24.611
that's what problem management does.

163
00:09:24.611 --> 00:09:28.358
So here it is in the seven step
improvement process heavily involved in

164
00:09:28.358 --> 00:09:31.978
analysis and making recommendations
through the presentation and

165
00:09:31.978 --> 00:09:33.767
using of that analysis, right?

166
00:09:33.767 --> 00:09:34.708
So it makes sense there.

167
00:09:34.708 --> 00:09:36.215
>> Mm-hm, okay.

168
00:09:36.215 --> 00:09:39.190
>> And of course, change management,
looking at the bottom here.

169
00:09:39.190 --> 00:09:41.430
Change management is also in play and

170
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:43.880
that's where you actually
make your improvement.

171
00:09:43.880 --> 00:09:47.726
So if you have an idea to change
something, to improve availability

172
00:09:47.726 --> 00:09:52.524
from 98% to 99% or to improve incident
resolution time from 60% to 80%.

173
00:09:52.524 --> 00:09:56.263
You're gonna come up with an idea,
maybe you're changing a process,

174
00:09:56.263 --> 00:10:00.930
maybe you're changing a tool set,
maybe you're doing some extra training.

175
00:10:00.930 --> 00:10:05.040
Those changes, that activity
are governed by change management.

176
00:10:05.040 --> 00:10:10.160
So change management is the one that
can actually get the improvement idea

177
00:10:10.160 --> 00:10:13.505
on the ground and
ready to go through service transition.

178
00:10:13.505 --> 00:10:17.515
>> Okay, I see what you mean by CSI
throughout the entire lifecycle,

179
00:10:17.515 --> 00:10:18.820
it just makes sense.

180
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:23.353
>> Exactly, and as you look at this list
of processes, some come from strategy,

181
00:10:23.353 --> 00:10:28.172
some come from design, some comes from
transition and some come from operations.

182
00:10:28.172 --> 00:10:32.800
And again, this is just a sample of
things, you could pick any process.

183
00:10:32.800 --> 00:10:37.054
No matter what the process is,
all 26 of them, including the CSI process,

184
00:10:37.054 --> 00:10:38.895
you could actually improve CSI.

185
00:10:38.895 --> 00:10:41.530
So CSI can be involved in
improving itself as well.

186
00:10:43.190 --> 00:10:44.410
>> Always be bettering yourself.

187
00:10:44.410 --> 00:10:45.945
>> That's right.

188
00:10:45.945 --> 00:10:47.630
>> Yeah.
>> So then playing out through what we

189
00:10:47.630 --> 00:10:51.840
described, I described a lot of this text,
I'm not gonna read these bullets to you.

190
00:10:51.840 --> 00:10:54.738
I described the fundamental
concepts as we go through here.

191
00:10:54.738 --> 00:10:57.860
I talked about its interaction
with service level management.

192
00:10:57.860 --> 00:11:01.340
I talked about its interaction with
availability and capacity management,

193
00:11:01.340 --> 00:11:04.720
right, looking at event management,
incident management, service desk.

194
00:11:04.720 --> 00:11:06.251
Let's take a look at this
just a little more deeply.

195
00:11:06.251 --> 00:11:10.472
Event management,
didn't call that one out specifically.

196
00:11:10.472 --> 00:11:12.680
How could you measure event management?

197
00:11:12.680 --> 00:11:17.477
Remember, event management is
there to detect events, right,

198
00:11:17.477 --> 00:11:21.764
and potentially that event
leads to an incident, right?

199
00:11:21.764 --> 00:11:26.187
Maybe it leads to an incident
that is preventative.

200
00:11:26.187 --> 00:11:31.464
Like I said, if you can automatically
detect that the disk is 75% full and

201
00:11:31.464 --> 00:11:36.087
perhaps automate the response to
send a ticket to the server team.

202
00:11:36.087 --> 00:11:39.803
And the server team goes and
adds more storage or deletes some files or

203
00:11:39.803 --> 00:11:43.021
whatever they need to do to
increase the storage capacity.

204
00:11:43.021 --> 00:11:47.780
Then you have forestalled
a potential failure, right?

205
00:11:47.780 --> 00:11:50.630
So event management can
lead to early detection,

206
00:11:50.630 --> 00:11:55.330
incident management can lead to quick
restoration or even quick prevention.

207
00:11:56.570 --> 00:11:59.898
So if you look at it
from a CSI perspective,

208
00:11:59.898 --> 00:12:03.139
if you're analyzing event management.

209
00:12:03.139 --> 00:12:05.396
And again, through problem management
as well, during the deep dive,

210
00:12:05.396 --> 00:12:06.693
that's where that analysis would come.

211
00:12:06.693 --> 00:12:11.419
You perhaps could connect the dots
between the number of storage

212
00:12:11.419 --> 00:12:15.897
incidents we had that were not
detected by that management.

213
00:12:15.897 --> 00:12:18.848
So maybe you're not
monitoring all the disks or

214
00:12:18.848 --> 00:12:23.298
maybe there is a slow down between
the detection and the actual action.

215
00:12:23.298 --> 00:12:28.545
So maybe you need to automate the steps in
between the event and incident management.

216
00:12:28.545 --> 00:12:32.647
So you see how CSI could just be paying
attention to the data coming from these

217
00:12:32.647 --> 00:12:34.330
different processes.

218
00:12:34.330 --> 00:12:35.832
And therefore streamline and

219
00:12:35.832 --> 00:12:38.905
improve the service as it's
being delivered to customers.

220
00:12:38.905 --> 00:12:43.752
So they don't experience the outages or
the disruption to begin with, right?

221
00:12:43.752 --> 00:12:51.048
Security management, we talked about
these earlier, financial management.

222
00:12:51.048 --> 00:12:54.925
All of them can be in play because they
get measurement, and if you measure,

223
00:12:54.925 --> 00:12:57.070
you have ability to improve.

224
00:12:57.070 --> 00:13:00.560
They also can be involved in
the seven step process and

225
00:13:00.560 --> 00:13:03.640
giving you the clues as to
what you should be working on.

226
00:13:03.640 --> 00:13:07.628
Perhaps what you're trying to
improve is cost containment, right?

227
00:13:07.628 --> 00:13:11.138
Spiraling cost, we keep spending more and
more and more on support,

228
00:13:11.138 --> 00:13:12.237
why is that, right?

229
00:13:12.237 --> 00:13:15.820
Financial management could be giving
you that financial data, right?

230
00:13:15.820 --> 00:13:20.607
And maybe you determine that that
financial, that all that's grind,

231
00:13:20.607 --> 00:13:24.691
all that spin is related to
maintenance tasks on databases.

232
00:13:24.691 --> 00:13:26.590
So now you got two different
things going here.

233
00:13:26.590 --> 00:13:31.150
You got the financial management
giving you the measurement of

234
00:13:31.150 --> 00:13:33.770
the data of money being spent.

235
00:13:33.770 --> 00:13:37.410
And you got problem management coming
in and doing a root cause to find out,

236
00:13:37.410 --> 00:13:39.290
where are we spending this stuff?

237
00:13:39.290 --> 00:13:41.220
And then you have a key candidate,

238
00:13:41.220 --> 00:13:44.050
we're spending too much money
on database maintenance.

239
00:13:44.050 --> 00:13:46.280
What should we do to improve that?

240
00:13:46.280 --> 00:13:51.743
Right, we get the idea how
these can interact, okay.

241
00:13:51.743 --> 00:13:54.505
As you get toward analyzing data,
the same we talked about before,

242
00:13:54.505 --> 00:13:57.450
this is the deep dive,
especially with problem management.

243
00:13:57.450 --> 00:14:01.290
Looking at the data, what does it tell you
about where your improvements might lie,

244
00:14:02.350 --> 00:14:03.960
as we talked about on that graphic before.

245
00:14:06.010 --> 00:14:07.830
Incident management can
give you data to analyze,

246
00:14:07.830 --> 00:14:09.870
problem management is doing the analysis.

247
00:14:09.870 --> 00:14:13.688
And of course, information security
can assist CSI in documenting and

248
00:14:13.688 --> 00:14:15.537
review your security incidents.

249
00:14:15.537 --> 00:14:18.350
And say, how many did you have, and what
was the impact of that security incident?

250
00:14:18.350 --> 00:14:21.565
We had a virus attack last week,
no data was corrupted.

251
00:14:21.565 --> 00:14:25.288
Or we had a virus attack last week,
we didn't notice it for three days,

252
00:14:25.288 --> 00:14:27.430
we lost 3 terabytes of data.

253
00:14:27.430 --> 00:14:31.120
You see the difference, information
security is to be monitoring and

254
00:14:31.120 --> 00:14:32.860
detecting those types of things.

255
00:14:32.860 --> 00:14:35.080
But what is the measurement
that could be acted on?

256
00:14:36.340 --> 00:14:38.293
So also helping out with
that additional thing.

257
00:14:38.293 --> 00:14:43.620
So we had a security incident,
it lasted three minutes, no damage done.

258
00:14:43.620 --> 00:14:48.250
Versus we had a security incident, it
lasted three days, we lost lots of data.

259
00:14:48.250 --> 00:14:52.210
CSI can be there to get that information
from information security and

260
00:14:52.210 --> 00:14:53.950
make appropriate recommendations for
improvement.

261
00:14:55.630 --> 00:14:58.870
So intrinsic to this understanding of CSI

262
00:14:58.870 --> 00:15:03.130
is the understanding of what the processes
are actually bringing, right?

263
00:15:03.130 --> 00:15:06.503
What do they do,
what is their scope of value?

264
00:15:06.503 --> 00:15:10.754
And if that value is not being fully
realized, then their CSI is to

265
00:15:10.754 --> 00:15:15.253
increase that value, right, and
reduce cost along the way, okay?

266
00:15:15.253 --> 00:15:19.708
And then ultimately what you need to
do in CSI is use this good data and

267
00:15:19.708 --> 00:15:23.240
make an appropriate response,
what are we gonna do?

268
00:15:23.240 --> 00:15:25.072
We have all this information,

269
00:15:25.072 --> 00:15:29.945
we realize that we had seven security
incidents with no data loss, that's good.

270
00:15:29.945 --> 00:15:36.030
We had five security incidents last month
with multiple terabytes of data lost.

271
00:15:37.230 --> 00:15:40.160
Do the compare and contrast,
make a recommendation.

272
00:15:40.160 --> 00:15:41.260
And the presenting and

273
00:15:41.260 --> 00:15:44.640
using the information really
just means making your plan.

274
00:15:44.640 --> 00:15:48.610
Here's what we think is happening,
here's what we think we can do to fix it.

275
00:15:48.610 --> 00:15:52.229
Make a presentation, basically make
a case for what action you need to take.

276
00:15:52.229 --> 00:15:55.720
Now, CSI could be for big things.

277
00:15:55.720 --> 00:15:58.684
It could be for let's say,
we're gonna adopt iTool.

278
00:15:58.684 --> 00:16:00.708
We're gonna adopt iTool
across the organization,

279
00:16:00.708 --> 00:16:02.710
we're gonna do this over
the next three years.

280
00:16:02.710 --> 00:16:06.950
It could be something big like that, it
could be something at the minutiae level,

281
00:16:06.950 --> 00:16:08.190
very down deep.

282
00:16:08.190 --> 00:16:12.259
CSI could be brought in to say,
let's improve our known error database so

283
00:16:12.259 --> 00:16:14.896
that we can improve
incident resolution time.

284
00:16:14.896 --> 00:16:17.718
Right, so it could be down in the weeds,

285
00:16:17.718 --> 00:16:22.290
it could be way up high,
CSI operates at both levels all the time.

286
00:16:23.750 --> 00:16:26.020
So the challenge on the exam and

287
00:16:26.020 --> 00:16:29.430
one way to take this on an exam,
there is a methodical approach,

288
00:16:29.430 --> 00:16:33.450
whether it's a minutiae type thing or
a big picture thing.

289
00:16:33.450 --> 00:16:38.290
You look before you leap, you analyze
before you come up with a plan, and

290
00:16:38.290 --> 00:16:39.500
you plan before you act.

291
00:16:40.510 --> 00:16:44.567
On any given test question, you might find
an answer that's not gonna be the five

292
00:16:44.567 --> 00:16:46.549
answer that will jump to a conclusion.

293
00:16:46.549 --> 00:16:51.489
Go buy that server, go buy that database,
implement ITSM right away instead of

294
00:16:51.489 --> 00:16:56.003
stepping back and getting stakeholder
feedback, analyze the vision.

295
00:16:56.003 --> 00:16:58.430
Where are we trying to go?

296
00:16:58.430 --> 00:17:03.380
Map that vision to a baseline of
where you are right now, measurement.

297
00:17:03.380 --> 00:17:06.985
And then move forward with a plan to move
that needle of measurement into the right

298
00:17:06.985 --> 00:17:07.578
direction.

299
00:17:07.578 --> 00:17:10.000
>> So taking that 5,000 foot view first.

300
00:17:10.000 --> 00:17:11.980
>> Absolutely, and consistently.

301
00:17:11.980 --> 00:17:16.763
So a lot of times,
your success on a question will be because

302
00:17:16.763 --> 00:17:20.400
you recognize a look
before you leap approach

303
00:17:20.400 --> 00:17:25.396
as a better approach than just
jumping to a solution, right?

304
00:17:25.396 --> 00:17:30.265
That's ITIL basically reinforcing
the idea that the principles of CSI,

305
00:17:30.265 --> 00:17:35.465
of looking before you leap, are embedded
in every decision you make, right?

306
00:17:35.465 --> 00:17:39.316
Have data-based decisions,
measurement-based decisions,

307
00:17:39.316 --> 00:17:41.070
look at those measurements.

308
00:17:41.070 --> 00:17:42.267
Know where you are now and

309
00:17:42.267 --> 00:17:45.409
why you care about moving the needle
into a different direction.

310
00:17:45.409 --> 00:17:50.387
Once you have that understand, then you
can go into the idea of planning in for

311
00:17:50.387 --> 00:17:52.190
that improvement.

312
00:17:52.190 --> 00:17:59.165
Okay, all right, that's it for CSI, and
the value of it throughout the life cycle.

313
00:17:59.165 --> 00:18:00.926
>> Fantastic, and you did it quickly too.

314
00:18:00.926 --> 00:18:07.158
So CSI, very important and it's throughout
the entire lifecycle, we got that.

315
00:18:07.158 --> 00:18:12.470
Now speaking of lifecycle, we have so
many episodes in the ITIL MALC series.

316
00:18:12.470 --> 00:18:14.316
Watch them all,
you'll be very glad you did.

317
00:18:14.316 --> 00:18:18.070
And thank you for
watching ITProTV, I'm Zach Memos.

318
00:18:18.070 --> 00:18:18.920
>> I'm Terry Decker.

319
00:18:18.920 --> 00:18:19.882
>> We'll see you very soon.

320
00:18:19.882 --> 00:18:27.556
[MUSIC]

321
00:18:27.556 --> 00:18:30.157
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.
