episodes.title: Service Design Across the Lifecycle
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:02.311
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.311 --> 00:00:06.294
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.294 --> 00:00:08.117
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.117 --> 00:00:11.718
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.718 --> 00:00:15.989
>> Hello and thank you for making
the intelligent choice to watch ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.989 --> 00:00:18.100
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:18.100 --> 00:00:21.855
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC, and

8
00:00:21.855 --> 00:00:25.890
this is service design across
the life cycle, with Terry Decker.

9
00:00:25.890 --> 00:00:28.700
Terry, good to see you again, I know
you've got a lot of information for us.

10
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:31.437
>> Absolutely, as always,
I'm happy to be here, Zach.

11
00:00:31.437 --> 00:00:35.217
The big challenge, what I'm focusing
on in these next several episodes,

12
00:00:35.217 --> 00:00:39.298
we've gone through processes, we've
looked at the big picture prior to that.

13
00:00:39.298 --> 00:00:42.098
And these next several ones
are gonna be looking at

14
00:00:42.098 --> 00:00:46.508
how each of the life cycle stages has its
tentacles in other life cycle stages.

15
00:00:46.508 --> 00:00:51.084
And how those tentacles from
other life cycle stages infect or

16
00:00:51.084 --> 00:00:52.940
affect service design.

17
00:00:52.940 --> 00:00:55.911
So it's about this integration,
the tentacles coming together, and

18
00:00:55.911 --> 00:00:58.299
looking at these things,
from a holistic point of view.

19
00:00:58.299 --> 00:01:02.976
Again, management across a life cycle is
trying to do that very strategic 5000 foot

20
00:01:02.976 --> 00:01:05.968
view of how these things
are intended to work together.

21
00:01:05.968 --> 00:01:09.452
It's strategically mis-minded,
you need to know the value,

22
00:01:09.452 --> 00:01:11.266
you need to know the activities.

23
00:01:11.266 --> 00:01:16.300
But actually you're looking at, how does
this equate to the value to the customers?

24
00:01:16.300 --> 00:01:20.351
So as we look at the design
considerations here on the graphics,

25
00:01:20.351 --> 00:01:22.082
I like the use of the scale.

26
00:01:22.082 --> 00:01:25.514
Because service design is
constantly trying to weigh

27
00:01:25.514 --> 00:01:29.416
the cost-benefit analysis of
different design elements.

28
00:01:29.416 --> 00:01:34.291
And remember, service design is a lot
more complicated than solution design.

29
00:01:34.291 --> 00:01:37.189
In that you still have
to design solutions, but

30
00:01:37.189 --> 00:01:41.247
you also have to design the policies,
the processes around them,

31
00:01:41.247 --> 00:01:44.950
to make sure that testing has
got the appropriate strategy.

32
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:50.005
All sorts of things have to be played
into, this game called service design.

33
00:01:50.005 --> 00:01:52.515
So getting the right balance,
how much money do we have,

34
00:01:52.515 --> 00:01:53.627
how much time do we have?

35
00:01:53.627 --> 00:01:58.040
What value proposition is actually being
delivered here, that sort of thing.

36
00:01:58.040 --> 00:01:59.791
Understanding the endgame,

37
00:01:59.791 --> 00:02:04.419
understanding your constraints is what
design policy is trying to consider.

38
00:02:04.419 --> 00:02:07.079
So as you move into
further analysis of this,

39
00:02:07.079 --> 00:02:10.930
what you're now trying to balance
is the idea of functionality.

40
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:16.685
What's it supposed to be doing, the
utility of it, also the warranty of it,

41
00:02:16.685 --> 00:02:21.300
how robust does it have to be,
and what resources do you have?

42
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:24.765
And I appreciate the resources
being identified here as people,

43
00:02:24.765 --> 00:02:26.030
technology and money.

44
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:28.747
That's really what you have,
what capabilities do you have,

45
00:02:28.747 --> 00:02:31.100
consider that one of
the resources as well.

46
00:02:31.100 --> 00:02:33.710
And then of course you
also have time scales,

47
00:02:33.710 --> 00:02:36.670
the resource of time is
also important aspect.

48
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:40.859
So, how many by when and by whom, and
how are they gonna get that done,

49
00:02:40.859 --> 00:02:43.997
is really what service design
is trying to get done.

50
00:02:43.997 --> 00:02:48.223
Now, service design necessarily is
gonna get a lot of their guidance and

51
00:02:48.223 --> 00:02:51.561
a lot of the constrains defined
by service strategists.

52
00:02:51.561 --> 00:02:55.922
Service strategists are gonna be the ones
that approve the charter that allows

53
00:02:55.922 --> 00:02:59.030
the service to come to life and
to be designed.

54
00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:02.620
They're providing the money,
they are setting the end goal,

55
00:03:02.620 --> 00:03:04.300
what time frame it is.

56
00:03:04.300 --> 00:03:07.970
So, service design already has this
interaction with service strategy,

57
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:10.330
because service strategy
is setting the direction.

58
00:03:10.330 --> 00:03:15.130
Is providing the resources, or as it
might be, not providing the resources.

59
00:03:15.130 --> 00:03:17.400
So operating within those
constraints as well.

60
00:03:19.040 --> 00:03:23.350
So, when you're considering how
design policy then, how you govern

61
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:27.950
service design, you really are considering
these three elements of resource,

62
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.420
schedule and functionality.

63
00:03:29.420 --> 00:03:34.130
And how they apply to strategy and
overarching governance, and

64
00:03:34.130 --> 00:03:37.170
by governance, in this context,
we're talking about strategic governance.

65
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:41.193
I mean, governance happens all the way
through the organization at all levels.

66
00:03:41.193 --> 00:03:44.438
But strategic governance is,
which direction are we going in and

67
00:03:44.438 --> 00:03:45.680
why we're going there?

68
00:03:45.680 --> 00:03:50.516
Are we trying to satisfy
regulators in a different way now?

69
00:03:50.516 --> 00:03:55.392
Imagine financial management organizations
before Sarbanes-Oxley years ago,

70
00:03:55.392 --> 00:03:59.360
and the impact that the passage of
that legislation had on financial

71
00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:04.350
organizations, or financial reporting,
or public companies at large.

72
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:08.873
So a major shift, governance through
regulations at a strategic level was

73
00:04:08.873 --> 00:04:10.897
changing that kind of behavior.

74
00:04:10.897 --> 00:04:15.462
If you work in other areas that are highly
regulated, the change in regulation

75
00:04:15.462 --> 00:04:19.267
is obviously gonna affect the way
you develop your strategies for

76
00:04:19.267 --> 00:04:23.718
improvement, the way you develop your
strategies for business outcomes.

77
00:04:23.718 --> 00:04:26.654
Certainly when you consider functionality
you're considering what the business is

78
00:04:26.654 --> 00:04:28.540
trying to do,
you can see in the lower quadrant there.

79
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:34.410
This all needs to be done in balance,
if you tip too heavily in one direction,

80
00:04:34.410 --> 00:04:36.440
you could upset the apple
cart in the other.

81
00:04:36.440 --> 00:04:40.325
So it's pretty picture, trying to show how
these things come together with a fine

82
00:04:40.325 --> 00:04:42.651
point at the top,
in this magic little pyramid.

83
00:04:42.651 --> 00:04:46.666
In effect, it's a very delicate balancing
act throughout the service design.

84
00:04:46.666 --> 00:04:50.097
And the overarching value that
these processes bring, and

85
00:04:50.097 --> 00:04:53.740
getting good at these processes
within service design.

86
00:04:53.740 --> 00:04:57.800
The overarching value is that you don't
have to reinvent the wheel every time

87
00:04:57.800 --> 00:04:59.054
to keep this balance.

88
00:04:59.054 --> 00:05:03.246
You have repeatable activities,
repeatable processes,

89
00:05:03.246 --> 00:05:06.439
repeatable points of sign off and
approval.

90
00:05:06.439 --> 00:05:09.702
That are well understood,
well practiced, and

91
00:05:09.702 --> 00:05:14.150
have known to be very good
predictors of actual delivery.

92
00:05:14.150 --> 00:05:17.560
So if you get good at this,
the balance becomes easier to maintain.

93
00:05:17.560 --> 00:05:20.316
That's really what service design
is trying to get done here.

94
00:05:20.316 --> 00:05:21.252
>> Wonderful.

95
00:05:22.737 --> 00:05:25.629
>> So again, keeping the good
communication open as you're trying

96
00:05:25.629 --> 00:05:27.790
to discern the particular requirements.

97
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:30.290
How else can you get stakeholders'
needs fully understood,

98
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:32.820
and the requirements fully documented?

99
00:05:32.820 --> 00:05:37.080
Now we realize that service strategy
is at the forefront of this.

100
00:05:37.080 --> 00:05:40.840
BRM is a process that's born
in service strategy, but

101
00:05:40.840 --> 00:05:44.820
BRM is going to be very high level,
service level requirements.

102
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:50.485
Just as an example, maybe the BRM process
discerns that this new service for

103
00:05:50.485 --> 00:05:54.307
this new customer needs
to be available 24/7.

104
00:05:54.307 --> 00:05:59.374
Well it's one thing to say 24/7/365,
that the service needs to be available.

105
00:05:59.374 --> 00:06:03.250
It's another thing to get into the details
about availability, for instance,

106
00:06:03.250 --> 00:06:06.273
to say, well, can we have
maintenance periods every Sunday?

107
00:06:06.273 --> 00:06:09.779
Can we have a maintenance period
every Tuesday for two hours, and

108
00:06:09.779 --> 00:06:11.450
four hours on Sunday?

109
00:06:11.450 --> 00:06:13.910
We need to maintain the system,
we gotta provide patches,

110
00:06:13.910 --> 00:06:16.610
we gotta upgrade this and fix that.

111
00:06:16.610 --> 00:06:20.703
Can we target some maintenance windows
that are acceptable to you, customer?

112
00:06:20.703 --> 00:06:22.958
And he says, yeah, you can do that.

113
00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:28.628
So now, instead of 24/7,
it's 24/7 minus six hours of maintenance,

114
00:06:28.628 --> 00:06:31.685
2 hours on Tuesday and 4 hours on Sunday.

115
00:06:31.685 --> 00:06:36.314
So you've changed the game and gotten to
the very details of just how a warranty,

116
00:06:36.314 --> 00:06:39.190
in this case availability,
need to be targeted.

117
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:43.783
You're expecting 2000 users,
is that demand accurate?

118
00:06:43.783 --> 00:06:47.790
Or are you going to be growing in the next
six months or the next three years?

119
00:06:47.790 --> 00:06:50.580
Are you anticipating a growth spurt

120
00:06:50.580 --> 00:06:53.890
where you expect maybe twice that
number three years from now?

121
00:06:53.890 --> 00:06:57.000
So while the initial service
level requirement may suggest

122
00:06:57.000 --> 00:07:01.390
that you need to only target for
the capacity for 2000 users.

123
00:07:01.390 --> 00:07:05.150
Maybe you realize the growth is going to
actually mean that we could triple that

124
00:07:05.150 --> 00:07:08.430
over the next three years,
that's a design consideration.

125
00:07:08.430 --> 00:07:14.550
So while these requirements begin to
be formulated at the strategic level.

126
00:07:14.550 --> 00:07:18.250
Service design is gonna be there to
really hone in on the actuals, and

127
00:07:18.250 --> 00:07:19.910
the predicted future.

128
00:07:19.910 --> 00:07:23.662
Trying to be a good forecaster
of future needs, future demand,

129
00:07:23.662 --> 00:07:26.656
future capacity,
security requirements, etc.

130
00:07:26.656 --> 00:07:31.460
So planning for growth is also part of the
balance the design needs to bring in too.

131
00:07:31.460 --> 00:07:34.240
What architecture's in place,
must we be on the mainframe,

132
00:07:34.240 --> 00:07:38.056
can we have a web service,
do you want it to be client-server?

133
00:07:38.056 --> 00:07:41.640
Sometimes the customers
have a predisposition, or

134
00:07:41.640 --> 00:07:46.340
strategists have a predisposition for what
the actual architectural style's gonna be.

135
00:07:47.650 --> 00:07:52.171
You need to be there in service design,
honing in on that architectural element,

136
00:07:52.171 --> 00:07:55.194
to make sure that it's fit for
purpose and fit for use.

137
00:07:55.194 --> 00:07:58.142
That sort of thing,
the high level view comes from strategy.

138
00:07:58.142 --> 00:08:01.277
Design's gonna be looking at
the devil in the details.

139
00:08:01.277 --> 00:08:04.720
So again, as you're identifying
these service requirements,

140
00:08:04.720 --> 00:08:07.450
you see some of the things
I just talked about.

141
00:08:07.450 --> 00:08:10.850
Scalability, how are you
affecting the business processes?

142
00:08:12.320 --> 00:08:15.580
I keep going back to this
oil company scenario,

143
00:08:15.580 --> 00:08:17.970
you don't have to be a geophysicist.

144
00:08:17.970 --> 00:08:20.440
But you need to know what
the geophysicist is trying to get done.

145
00:08:20.440 --> 00:08:21.940
You don't have to be a lawyer but

146
00:08:21.940 --> 00:08:24.260
you need to know what is that
lawyer trying to do, right?

147
00:08:24.260 --> 00:08:27.480
You need to understand what
the business processes are.

148
00:08:27.480 --> 00:08:31.120
If you're in financial management,
you don't have to be a financial guru, but

149
00:08:31.120 --> 00:08:34.780
you need to know what those financial
managers are trying to get done, etc.

150
00:08:34.780 --> 00:08:37.932
Hopefully that horse is sufficiently
beaten, you got that one down.

151
00:08:37.932 --> 00:08:38.784
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

152
00:08:38.784 --> 00:08:42.180
[LAUGH] So
agreeing to functional requirements.

153
00:08:42.180 --> 00:08:44.030
That's the utility piece of things.

154
00:08:44.030 --> 00:08:49.250
Agreeing to the warranty processes, making
sure you have agreements in place, right?

155
00:08:49.250 --> 00:08:52.090
Service level management is one of
those activities that plays out in

156
00:08:52.090 --> 00:08:53.210
service design.

157
00:08:53.210 --> 00:08:57.610
So quite holistically then, if you're
talking about agreements, you're gonna be

158
00:08:57.610 --> 00:09:01.060
using SLM for service level agreements and
operational level agreements.

159
00:09:01.060 --> 00:09:01.890
What about your suppliers?

160
00:09:01.890 --> 00:09:04.640
Are they gonna have to be coming
along on this journey as well?

161
00:09:04.640 --> 00:09:08.050
What's your supplier man's regime doing
to make sure the suppliers are coming

162
00:09:08.050 --> 00:09:09.160
on board?

163
00:09:09.160 --> 00:09:09.830
Are they ready?

164
00:09:09.830 --> 00:09:10.940
Do they have the right training?

165
00:09:10.940 --> 00:09:11.660
Do they have the right capacity?

166
00:09:11.660 --> 00:09:15.730
Can you trust them with this new service?

167
00:09:15.730 --> 00:09:16.690
That sort of thing.

168
00:09:16.690 --> 00:09:21.060
So service design is gonna be there not
only to ensure that the requirements

169
00:09:21.060 --> 00:09:25.850
are understood between the service
provider and the business, but

170
00:09:25.850 --> 00:09:29.920
these are also between the service
provider and the suppliers as well.

171
00:09:29.920 --> 00:09:31.530
So, very important.

172
00:09:31.530 --> 00:09:33.050
What about regulatory requirements?

173
00:09:33.050 --> 00:09:34.280
What about cost constraints?

174
00:09:34.280 --> 00:09:39.300
What about time constraints,
all these things in play all the time.

175
00:09:39.300 --> 00:09:42.320
So if you get good at this,
if you get good at service design,

176
00:09:42.320 --> 00:09:46.890
these questions become something
that you can easily answer.

177
00:09:46.890 --> 00:09:51.350
You have a methodology in place that
can easily approach these questions and

178
00:09:51.350 --> 00:09:52.880
come up with good answers.

179
00:09:52.880 --> 00:09:54.430
You are not reinventing
the wheel every time.

180
00:09:55.960 --> 00:10:00.100
So finding out your requirements,
in this particular case we're

181
00:10:00.100 --> 00:10:04.190
talking about business processes
across multiple business units.

182
00:10:04.190 --> 00:10:08.270
This graphic is also showing how
you need to filter this down into

183
00:10:08.270 --> 00:10:09.920
the requirements among the infrastructure.

184
00:10:10.980 --> 00:10:11.720
Right, so

185
00:10:11.720 --> 00:10:15.430
it's one thing to understand what the
targets are from the business perspective.

186
00:10:15.430 --> 00:10:18.810
It's another thing to understand
how these targets can be met

187
00:10:18.810 --> 00:10:22.220
from the infrastructure perspective or
from the application perspective.

188
00:10:22.220 --> 00:10:23.880
And here's design in the middle.

189
00:10:23.880 --> 00:10:25.480
Right, not a trivial matter.

190
00:10:26.530 --> 00:10:31.470
Beginning good at this means you have
fewer problems in operations later.

191
00:10:31.470 --> 00:10:36.490
Being bad at this means you may launch
a lot of services that fail often and

192
00:10:36.490 --> 00:10:39.480
fail to deliver on the quality
that they are intended to deliver,

193
00:10:39.480 --> 00:10:41.680
to deliver the value that
they are supposed to deliver.

194
00:10:41.680 --> 00:10:42.900
All right, all right.

195
00:10:44.500 --> 00:10:46.050
So, write this stuff down.

196
00:10:46.050 --> 00:10:48.990
Identifying and
Documenting Business Requirements.

197
00:10:48.990 --> 00:10:51.300
And becoming very methodical to it.

198
00:10:51.300 --> 00:10:54.480
If you have any experience in
the software development life cycle,

199
00:10:54.480 --> 00:10:57.480
you would have scraped your knuckles
on business requirements before.

200
00:10:57.480 --> 00:11:02.440
In a software development life cycle,
business requirements for solutions or

201
00:11:02.440 --> 00:11:07.440
for an application are often
translated into system requirements or

202
00:11:07.440 --> 00:11:08.980
functional requirements.

203
00:11:08.980 --> 00:11:12.680
So once you start with the baseline on
what the business is trying to do, you

204
00:11:12.680 --> 00:11:17.990
then start building on the system and or
functional requirements to satisfy those.

205
00:11:17.990 --> 00:11:20.960
So in the software development life cycle,

206
00:11:20.960 --> 00:11:25.650
you have a good analogy of what
happens in the service life cycle.

207
00:11:25.650 --> 00:11:28.980
Service design life cycle's a little
bit different than solution design,

208
00:11:28.980 --> 00:11:33.470
in that you can't just think about
the technology, which is also in play.

209
00:11:33.470 --> 00:11:35.480
You have to think about
all these other things.

210
00:11:35.480 --> 00:11:38.580
Process models, policies, governance,

211
00:11:38.580 --> 00:11:42.010
measurement, right, the people,
what training needs to be involved,

212
00:11:42.010 --> 00:11:45.500
testing, what testing needs to be
brought to bear, all sorts of things.

213
00:11:45.500 --> 00:11:47.920
And ultimately,
service acceptance criteria.

214
00:11:47.920 --> 00:11:51.490
Okay, now, service models.

215
00:11:52.810 --> 00:11:57.250
Service models are effectively
designed between

216
00:11:57.250 --> 00:12:00.500

service design.

217
00:12:00.500 --> 00:12:04.070
This is where you're trying to build
the right number of services and

218
00:12:04.070 --> 00:12:08.780
put them in play at the right amount of
time in the right amount of expensive to

219
00:12:08.780 --> 00:12:14.320
satisfy the business outcomes
that they that are being sought.

220
00:12:14.320 --> 00:12:16.080
This is an example.

221
00:12:16.080 --> 00:12:18.990
A service model for

222
00:12:18.990 --> 00:12:25.280
communications within an organisation
could include a blend of telephones,

223
00:12:25.280 --> 00:12:30.390
instant messaging, email,
maybe even hard copy mail.

224
00:12:30.390 --> 00:12:33.040
Hard copy things could also
be part of the service model.

225
00:12:34.190 --> 00:12:37.230
IT can help in all those, right?

226
00:12:37.230 --> 00:12:39.430
They could help in all those
types of environments.

227
00:12:39.430 --> 00:12:42.320
So your service model satisfying
the business process,

228
00:12:42.320 --> 00:12:45.150
communication could have
several moving pieces.

229
00:12:45.150 --> 00:12:46.970
Now, what's underneath those services?

230
00:12:48.040 --> 00:12:49.430
Email, instant messaging.

231
00:12:51.490 --> 00:12:52.670
What's underneath those?

232
00:12:52.670 --> 00:12:54.475
You have servers underneath those.

233
00:12:54.475 --> 00:12:57.970
You've got database systems underneath
those or services underneath those.

234
00:12:57.970 --> 00:12:59.160
You have network services.

235
00:12:59.160 --> 00:13:01.080
You have identity management services.

236
00:13:01.080 --> 00:13:04.340
So now, it's not just a first layer
of service modeling you have to

237
00:13:04.340 --> 00:13:08.800
be concerned with about how you create
the right types of services to satisfy

238
00:13:08.800 --> 00:13:11.300
that business process of communication.

239
00:13:11.300 --> 00:13:14.360
You also have to consider
the underlying services and

240
00:13:14.360 --> 00:13:18.520
how they are presented to
support this model of services.

241
00:13:18.520 --> 00:13:20.590
So, service modeling has layers.

242
00:13:20.590 --> 00:13:22.080
It's having the right mix of layers and

243
00:13:22.080 --> 00:13:24.030
the right amount of expense
at the right amount of time,

244
00:13:24.030 --> 00:13:27.650
the right amount of effort at the right
amount of time for the business outcomes.

245
00:13:27.650 --> 00:13:32.570
Now, email is one of those things I mean,
what's the value of email?

246
00:13:32.570 --> 00:13:37.700
How do you put a return on investment,

00:13:37.700 --> 00:13:41.070
Take email away for a week and
see what the value of email is, right?

248
00:13:41.070 --> 00:13:41.870
I mean, I think you'd get that.

249
00:13:41.870 --> 00:13:44.630
Maybe some people would say yea,
please take it away, take it away.

250
00:13:44.630 --> 00:13:46.590
I don't wanna see my inbox again, right?

251
00:13:46.590 --> 00:13:52.810
I totally get that as well, but,
my point there is, while it's easy in some

252
00:13:52.810 --> 00:13:58.170
cases to quantify the value of a given
service, some things are just expected.

253
00:13:58.170 --> 00:14:02.540
And that's one of the unfortunate
dichotomies of IT

254
00:14:02.540 --> 00:14:05.810
service management sometimes, is if you're
really good at delivering something,

255
00:14:05.810 --> 00:14:07.840
you don't get a pat on the back,
it's just expected.

256
00:14:07.840 --> 00:14:11.030
Right, and that's the case
with some of the commodity or

257
00:14:11.030 --> 00:14:13.320
baseline types of services.

258
00:14:13.320 --> 00:14:15.168
Everyone expects email.

259
00:14:15.168 --> 00:14:18.877
Everyone expects it to work,
expects us to be there every day and

260
00:14:18.877 --> 00:14:23.013
it could be an extraordinary effort
to invest in that type of delivery.

261
00:14:23.013 --> 00:14:25.950
99.9% availability.

262
00:14:25.950 --> 00:14:29.170
Plenty of space for all your email,
you never delete a thing,

263
00:14:29.170 --> 00:14:32.390
you got your email from eight years ago,
yeah, we got it covered for you,

00:14:32.390 --> 00:14:34.280
all that storage issues, right?

265
00:14:34.280 --> 00:14:37.210
Managing the storage,
managing the access, right?

266
00:14:37.210 --> 00:14:40.920
All sorts of things, and yet,
it just becomes an expectation.

267
00:14:40.920 --> 00:14:44.050
So service design is there to
understand those expectations and

268
00:14:44.050 --> 00:14:46.870
deliver on them in a delightful way,
basically.

269
00:14:46.870 --> 00:14:48.150
So, that's what a service model is.

270
00:14:48.150 --> 00:14:52.630
Getting the right things built to
satisfy those business processes.

271
00:14:52.630 --> 00:14:54.220
>> In the most delightful way.

272
00:14:54.220 --> 00:14:55.310
>> In the most delightful way as you can.

00:14:55.310 --> 00:14:56.740
That's right.
We can sing, right.

00:14:56.740 --> 00:14:58.040
>> I almost broke into it.

00:14:58.040 --> 00:14:58.600
>> You almost did.

00:14:58.600 --> 00:14:59.321
I can appreciate that.

00:14:59.321 --> 00:15:01.982
>> [LAUGH] Spoonful of sugar,

00:15:01.982 --> 00:15:03.534
>> Yeah, you're right, exactly right.

279
00:15:03.534 --> 00:15:04.034
>> Okay, good.

280
00:15:05.140 --> 00:15:10.080
Again, service modelling, just to recap on
this, service modelling is making sure you

00:15:10.080 --> 00:15:13.890

00:15:13.890 --> 00:15:19.150
Going back to the oil company, they want
to find the oil, they want to extract

00:15:19.150 --> 00:15:22.670
the oil, I mean this is high level, do you
have services that helps them find it?

00:15:22.670 --> 00:15:25.640
Do you have services that
help them attract it?

00:15:25.640 --> 00:15:27.690
Do you have services that
helps them distribute it?

00:15:27.690 --> 00:15:28.580
That sort of things.

287
00:15:28.580 --> 00:15:31.340
What does IT bring in their services

00:15:31.340 --> 00:15:34.520
that help the business get
that stuff done, right.

289
00:15:34.520 --> 00:15:37.640
Now in that stuff there's
also the sub categories.

00:15:37.640 --> 00:15:39.940
It's not just about extracting it or

00:15:39.940 --> 00:15:41.340
It's finding it quickly.

292
00:15:41.340 --> 00:15:43.560
It's finding it safely, right?

293
00:15:43.560 --> 00:15:46.910
Is finding it within
regulatory constrains, right?

294
00:15:46.910 --> 00:15:51.422
So, again, IT can help with those
subsets of business out comes or

295
00:15:51.422 --> 00:15:52.800
processes as well.

296
00:15:52.800 --> 00:15:56.598
Coming up with the right services, they
satisfy those business processes as well,

297
00:15:56.598 --> 00:15:58.427
this is what service modeling is about.

298
00:15:58.427 --> 00:16:01.050
A lot of these happens
in service strategy.

299
00:16:01.050 --> 00:16:03.433
But service design must be there,

300
00:16:03.433 --> 00:16:07.304
to understand what the models
are intended to deliver.

00:16:07.304 --> 00:16:10.429
And make sure that the right
balance of investment and

302
00:16:10.429 --> 00:16:14.767
resource utilization is brought to
bear on those service models, okay?

00:16:14.767 --> 00:16:15.881
>> Perfect.

304
00:16:15.881 --> 00:16:20.957
>> All right, now, doing all this work,
service design, getting all this done.

00:16:20.957 --> 00:16:24.489
Specifically through the process

00:16:30.140 --> 00:16:34.722

00:16:38.279 --> 00:16:41.514

00:16:41.514 --> 00:16:42.965

00:16:43.975 --> 00:16:49.205

00:16:49.205 --> 00:16:53.435
We started off with what amounted to

00:16:53.435 --> 00:16:59.165
Here's the 100 questions you should

00:16:59.165 --> 00:17:00.729

00:17:02.110 --> 00:17:04.750
And then we grew to 150,
to include a few things,

00:17:04.750 --> 00:17:08.920
it says, before you agree to

00:17:10.190 --> 00:17:13.640
Then it came up with a few more options,
it says before you agree to go to

00:17:13.640 --> 00:17:16.260
operations, right,
all these types of things.

00:17:16.260 --> 00:17:19.920
So all of these things, and what I mean

00:17:19.920 --> 00:17:22.840

00:17:22.840 --> 00:17:25.150

00:17:27.750 --> 00:17:32.160

00:17:32.160 --> 00:17:34.605
You document a service architecture.

00:17:34.605 --> 00:17:36.935
You document a system architecture.

00:17:36.935 --> 00:17:38.965

an organizational architecture,

00:17:38.965 --> 00:17:41.675

00:17:41.675 --> 00:17:44.195

management process.

330
00:17:44.195 --> 00:17:47.535
You might document a brand new
incident management process.

331
00:17:47.535 --> 00:17:51.915
You might document lots of things as
part of introducing a new service,

332
00:17:51.915 --> 00:17:55.050

333
00:17:55.050 --> 00:17:56.750
And all those things,
all those deliverables,

334
00:17:56.750 --> 00:18:01.070

00:18:01.070 --> 00:18:05.750
Now in terms of execution, you might get

00:18:07.890 --> 00:18:10.350

I know what my availability

Getting lost back at the operations,

00:18:37.460 --> 00:18:43.100

00:18:43.100 --> 00:18:45.980

the service design package.

00:18:45.980 --> 00:18:49.152
Understand that it's a big thing
that has lots of answers to

00:18:49.152 --> 00:18:50.809

351
00:18:50.809 --> 00:18:55.140
And that it's a deliverable that's done
early in a life cycle of a service.

00:18:55.140 --> 00:18:56.825
By early, I mean, in service design.

00:18:58.290 --> 00:19:00.990
Now, operationally speaking, when you

I can only give you some

In this regard,

package should start it off as a list.

357
00:19:08.480 --> 00:19:11.740
Just imagine an Excel spreadsheet
with a few lines on it.

358
00:19:11.740 --> 00:19:13.430
The lines kept getting,
we kept getting more and

359
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:16.760
more lines, right, but
they described it deliverable.

360
00:19:16.760 --> 00:19:19.200
Have business requirements been approved?

361
00:19:20.200 --> 00:19:25.290
Yes, just a simple check box, yes it has,
no it hasn't, no it's gonna be,

362
00:19:25.290 --> 00:19:27.870
maybe a comments section, all right?

363
00:19:27.870 --> 00:19:31.595
System requirements, functional
requirements, design spec, all those

364
00:19:31.595 --> 00:19:35.569
things, whatever it might be that you need
to answer ends up with a deliverable.

365
00:19:35.569 --> 00:19:39.870
And simply ask the question,
has it been delivered, right?

366
00:19:39.870 --> 00:19:43.380
And, if it has been delivered, how about
a column over here to the far right,

367
00:19:43.380 --> 00:19:45.820
that just links to it somewhere, right?

368
00:19:45.820 --> 00:19:50.610
Maybe to a document repository, or maybe
to a SharePoint list, for that matter.

369
00:19:50.610 --> 00:19:54.240
So, we created basically what
amounted to an electronic

370
00:19:54.240 --> 00:19:56.192
way to capture the service design package.

371
00:19:56.192 --> 00:20:00.490
It started off as a checklist,
it evolved to a way, from the checklist,

372
00:20:00.490 --> 00:20:02.402
get to the actual deliverable.

373
00:20:02.402 --> 00:20:06.810
And it ultimately became the touchstone
throughout the design process, and

374
00:20:06.810 --> 00:20:08.990
throughout the transition process.

375
00:20:08.990 --> 00:20:11.495
And even used in service operations,
to go and

376
00:20:11.495 --> 00:20:16.310
find the appropriate artifacts at
the appropriate time for troubleshooting.

377
00:20:16.310 --> 00:20:17.710
And what's the architectural diagram?

378
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:18.983
Well, I'll look at
the services design package,

379
00:20:18.983 --> 00:20:20.550
because I know they created one of those.

380
00:20:20.550 --> 00:20:23.175
I go to the architecture, okay,
here's what this server does,

381
00:20:23.175 --> 00:20:24.191
it hooks off to this one.

382
00:20:24.191 --> 00:20:27.080
Maybe we need to troubleshoot this
interface, that sort of thing.

383
00:20:27.080 --> 00:20:30.482
So they have a life cycle,
these deliverables,

384
00:20:30.482 --> 00:20:33.270
that serve the design process very well.

385
00:20:33.270 --> 00:20:37.185
They have a life cycle that serves
the transition life cycle very well.

386
00:20:37.185 --> 00:20:39.762
And these same deliverables
in the service design

387
00:20:39.762 --> 00:20:42.910
package can also serve
services operations well.

388
00:20:42.910 --> 00:20:47.910
So, that's how service design can impact
the entire life cycle of a service.

389
00:20:47.910 --> 00:20:50.320
>> All the pieces of that puzzle
fit very nicely, thank you.

390
00:20:50.320 --> 00:20:52.340
>> Good, glad to hear that.

391
00:20:52.340 --> 00:20:55.450
Now, policies, principles and basic
concepts with the service design package,

392
00:20:55.450 --> 00:20:57.090
that kind of got played out here.

393
00:20:57.090 --> 00:21:00.910
One of the earliest things you
can get Is a service charter.

394
00:21:00.910 --> 00:21:02.126
This is the decision and

395
00:21:02.126 --> 00:21:04.930
the announcement that the service
is gonna be brought to life.

396
00:21:04.930 --> 00:21:07.724
It describes the major role players,
the major stakeholders,

397
00:21:07.724 --> 00:21:10.219
the value that the service is
supposed to be delivering.

398
00:21:10.219 --> 00:21:13.790
The timeline for when the service
is gonna be brought to life,

399
00:21:13.790 --> 00:21:16.270
and perhaps even its intended lifecycle.

400
00:21:16.270 --> 00:21:19.086
It's a five-year plan to
have this service in place,

401
00:21:19.086 --> 00:21:22.590
it's gonna be replaced by a different
service five years from now.

402
00:21:22.590 --> 00:21:25.820
The service charter would have
that kind of detail in it.

403
00:21:25.820 --> 00:21:29.040
What is its strategic objective,
why are we doing this?

404
00:21:29.040 --> 00:21:32.785
Here are the major stakeholders,
have a nice design day, basically.

405
00:21:32.785 --> 00:21:34.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> The service charter is doing that.

406
00:21:35.670 --> 00:21:39.940
All right, it's a public assessment
of why we're doing the service.

407
00:21:40.950 --> 00:21:43.290
This also includes the expected
utility and warranty.

408
00:21:43.290 --> 00:21:46.120
And then you get into those other things,
the service specifications,

409
00:21:46.120 --> 00:21:48.220
the service model,
the architectural diagrams.

410
00:21:48.220 --> 00:21:51.610
All those things that may be
a meaningful deliverable.

411
00:21:51.610 --> 00:21:55.140
What's the availability management plan,
what's the security plan look like?

412
00:21:55.140 --> 00:21:58.931
Do we need a new process for incident
management, because the one we have now is

413
00:21:58.931 --> 00:22:01.754
not gonna be scalable enough
to this particular service?

414
00:22:01.754 --> 00:22:08.334
Do we need a request fulfillment model,
to satisfy the demand for headsets, right?

415
00:22:08.334 --> 00:22:11.077
I'll give you an example
from my own experience,

416
00:22:11.077 --> 00:22:14.700
we had introduced a learning
management service.

417
00:22:14.700 --> 00:22:18.990
In effect, what we had done is we
introduced a learning management system.

418
00:22:18.990 --> 00:22:22.797
We didn't really think the holistic
approach to service, to be quite honest.

419
00:22:22.797 --> 00:22:26.829
And as we launched this new
learning management system,

420
00:22:26.829 --> 00:22:33.110
one of the business propositions was,
you can convert PowerPoints to eLearning.

421
00:22:33.110 --> 00:22:37.510
So when you people were getting people in
a classroom, and showing a PowerPoint,

422
00:22:37.510 --> 00:22:42.760
we can make that easier to deliver
by converting it to eLearning.

423
00:22:42.760 --> 00:22:44.700
But we didn't build that service,

424
00:22:44.700 --> 00:22:46.770
we didn't build the Powerpoint
conversion service.

425
00:22:46.770 --> 00:22:49.880
We just said the system can support it,
right?

426
00:22:49.880 --> 00:22:53.684
So then the business, all these many
practitioners in the business in the large

427
00:22:53.684 --> 00:22:55.750
organization, they started calling IT.

428
00:22:55.750 --> 00:22:59.633
Saying, hey, we like this new
learning management system, and

429
00:22:59.633 --> 00:23:03.736
we heard we could convert PowerPoints
to e-learning, I want that.

430
00:23:03.736 --> 00:23:06.595
Good, have a nice day.

431
00:23:06.595 --> 00:23:08.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> We weren't ready for it, right?

432
00:23:08.310 --> 00:23:10.540
So when you consider request models,

433
00:23:10.540 --> 00:23:13.350
that could be part of service design,
be ready for that.

434
00:23:13.350 --> 00:23:17.134
If you're promising that
the value proposition for

435
00:23:17.134 --> 00:23:21.183
a given service is X, and
part of delivering X is Y and Z?

436
00:23:21.183 --> 00:23:24.164
Then you'd better have Y and
Z in the backroom, ready to go,

437
00:23:24.164 --> 00:23:26.040
is what this is talking about.

438
00:23:26.040 --> 00:23:27.960
So coming up with those various things,

439
00:23:27.960 --> 00:23:31.800
those various deliverables, is what
service design package is geared to do.

440
00:23:31.800 --> 00:23:33.760
And that could go many
different directions.

441
00:23:33.760 --> 00:23:37.160
Maybe there's not a need to have
a request fulfillment model for

442
00:23:37.160 --> 00:23:39.780
the service you're introducing,
maybe there is.

443
00:23:39.780 --> 00:23:41.420
Answer the question, right?

444
00:23:41.420 --> 00:23:44.508
If there's not a need for
a request fulfillment model, check no,

445
00:23:44.508 --> 00:23:45.620
you're good, right?

446
00:23:45.620 --> 00:23:48.592
If there is a need for one,
then who's delivering it?

447
00:23:48.592 --> 00:23:52.466
Let's sign it out, right, make sure it's
delivered on time and ready to go, and

448
00:23:52.466 --> 00:23:54.336
it's fully tested before you launch.

449
00:23:56.879 --> 00:23:59.108
All right, big important thing
here at the bottom here,

450
00:23:59.108 --> 00:24:02.090
the service acceptance criteria,
let me get my laser pointer right quick.

451
00:24:04.080 --> 00:24:07.930
The service acceptance criteria,
not a trivial matter,

452
00:24:07.930 --> 00:24:09.220
it's one bullet I wanna highlight.

453
00:24:09.220 --> 00:24:13.530
There's lots of deliverables, but service
design is gonna be very explicit about

454
00:24:13.530 --> 00:24:17.020
what success looks like
before you go live, right?

455
00:24:18.380 --> 00:24:22.350
So before we accept this into
the production live environment,

456
00:24:22.350 --> 00:24:24.320
what does success look like?

457
00:24:24.320 --> 00:24:26.750
All tests have passed, right?

458
00:24:26.750 --> 00:24:30.560
All risks have been mitigated to
a satisfactory level as approved by

459
00:24:31.640 --> 00:24:36.760
Joe Blow and Mary Market,
whoever it might be, right?

460
00:24:36.760 --> 00:24:39.620
You're accepting the criteria,
you're stating what the criteria is.

461
00:24:39.620 --> 00:24:44.290
When Joe and Mary say that the risks
have been mitigated effectively enough,

462
00:24:44.290 --> 00:24:47.290
we'll consider that good enough for
us, that type of thing.

463
00:24:47.290 --> 00:24:52.530
When all the tests have passed,
when the load balancing tests,

464
00:24:52.530 --> 00:24:55.400
the service integration tests,
the system integration tests,

465
00:24:55.400 --> 00:24:59.720
when the processes have been completed,
when training has been completed.

466
00:24:59.720 --> 00:25:02.260
Whatever the acceptance criteria is,
write them down,

467
00:25:02.260 --> 00:25:08.350
and we'll consider ourselves ready to go
when these things have been accomplished.

468
00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:13.473
And then you use that as your checklist
there in service transition to say,

469
00:25:13.473 --> 00:25:17.885
I gotta satisfy this criteria
before I go live, simple as that.

470
00:25:17.885 --> 00:25:19.903
Notice when this is happening,

471
00:25:19.903 --> 00:25:23.573
service acceptance criteria
is not figured out later on.

472
00:25:23.573 --> 00:25:26.966
It's figured out early in the life cycle,
so

473
00:25:26.966 --> 00:25:33.052
you know what success looks like before
you launch, simple as that, all right.

474
00:25:33.052 --> 00:25:34.480
>> Covering all your bases.

475
00:25:34.480 --> 00:25:38.540
>> That's right, now service design
interaction with service transition

476
00:25:38.540 --> 00:25:41.180
is gonna be highly influenced by policies.

477
00:25:41.180 --> 00:25:45.790
Well one thing I just mentioned, service
acceptance criteria, you will not go live

478
00:25:45.790 --> 00:25:51.380
unless all service acceptance
criteria has been satisfied, right?

479
00:25:51.380 --> 00:25:56.220
Exceptions to this policy must be
reviewed by senior vice president, or

480
00:25:56.220 --> 00:25:56.990
something like that.

481
00:25:56.990 --> 00:26:01.644
So if you have a policy that backs
up this interaction of discipline

482
00:26:01.644 --> 00:26:03.400
between the two stages.

483
00:26:03.400 --> 00:26:07.981
If you have a policy that says thou shalt
do this, and not just a process that

484
00:26:07.981 --> 00:26:11.979
describes how to do it, then you
have a bit more meat on that bone,

485
00:26:11.979 --> 00:26:17.270
a little bit more driving, buy-in, if you
will, from the executives, all right.

486
00:26:17.270 --> 00:26:20.160
So in my own experience,
that was a challenge.

487
00:26:20.160 --> 00:26:24.580
I guess it always is, to make sure that
if you create a process, some people will

488
00:26:24.580 --> 00:26:28.120
embrace it, other peoples will scoff at
it and say it's just another process.

489
00:26:28.120 --> 00:26:31.910
I've been doing it this way for years,
I don't need to change my behavior, right?

490
00:26:31.910 --> 00:26:35.290
So you get in the varying range,
I just refuse to follow a process

491
00:26:35.290 --> 00:26:39.750
all the way up to thank you very much for
process and all points in-between.

492
00:26:39.750 --> 00:26:44.475
Well, the way you can kinda drive some
adherence to process is through policy,

493
00:26:44.475 --> 00:26:46.200
it's just part of governance.

494
00:26:46.200 --> 00:26:48.979
So if you're trying to
drive from service design

495
00:26:48.979 --> 00:26:53.740
into service transition some certain
behaviors, then policy can come into play.

496
00:26:53.740 --> 00:26:56.804
We're gonna have a good lesson
a little bit later on on governance,

497
00:26:56.804 --> 00:26:58.930
an episode on governance a bit later on.

498
00:26:58.930 --> 00:27:02.950
And we'll remind ourselves then, or
re-energize our learning then just how

499
00:27:02.950 --> 00:27:07.879
important governance is to this
fabric of IT service management.

500
00:27:09.460 --> 00:27:13.640
Okay, so now as you're in service
transition, you'd be looking at policies.

501
00:27:13.640 --> 00:27:18.539
Now this is where we kinda get in
a transitions phase from service design to

502
00:27:18.539 --> 00:27:21.470
service transition, to mix the language.

503
00:27:21.470 --> 00:27:25.455
As you move from service
design to service transition,

504
00:27:25.455 --> 00:27:30.840
policy can help and you also consider
what kind of activity this is.

505
00:27:30.840 --> 00:27:34.868
Now, if it's a major release,
a minor release or an emergency release.

506
00:27:34.868 --> 00:27:38.370
I mean, obviously emergency releases
are things you gotta do right now.

507
00:27:38.370 --> 00:27:41.890
Minor releases could be like
break fix things along the way.

508
00:27:41.890 --> 00:27:44.280
Major releases could be something as

509
00:27:45.620 --> 00:27:50.560
big as replacing your Lotus Notes
platform with Exchange.

510
00:27:50.560 --> 00:27:52.630
That's a big change, right?

511
00:27:52.630 --> 00:27:58.055
So what is a major, what is a minor,
what is an emergency change or a release?

512
00:27:58.055 --> 00:28:01.965
All those factors affect some decisions
being made at the design level as you're

513
00:28:01.965 --> 00:28:04.435
trying to design these solutions.

514
00:28:04.435 --> 00:28:07.835
So that's kind of a point of
interface between design and

515
00:28:07.835 --> 00:28:11.895
transition is how big a deal is this,
right?

516
00:28:11.895 --> 00:28:13.075
Another way to put this is,

517
00:28:13.075 --> 00:28:18.640
not all design decisions have to follow
the same amount of rigor, right?

518
00:28:18.640 --> 00:28:21.230
A major release is gonna
get a bit more concerns and

519
00:28:21.230 --> 00:28:23.710
have a bit more rigor
than a minor release.

520
00:28:23.710 --> 00:28:26.593
Emergency releases obviously have
a sense of urgency that the other ones

521
00:28:26.593 --> 00:28:27.620
don't as well.

522
00:28:27.620 --> 00:28:30.720
So how does that play in
to design considerations?

523
00:28:30.720 --> 00:28:34.898
So we'll be looking at service transition
processes in a bit more detail in the next

524
00:28:34.898 --> 00:28:35.445
episode.

525
00:28:35.445 --> 00:28:37.870
But that's all we have now for
service design.

526
00:28:38.910 --> 00:28:43.039
>> Service Design Across the Lifecycle,
this is ITIL MALC,

527
00:28:43.039 --> 00:28:47.110
there's lots of episodes
in the ITIL MALC series.

528
00:28:47.110 --> 00:28:48.900
Watch them all,
you'll be very glad you did.

529
00:28:48.900 --> 00:28:50.448
Terry, awesome job as usual.

530
00:28:50.448 --> 00:28:52.930
>> Thank you.
>> And thank you for watching ITProTV.

531
00:28:53.950 --> 00:28:57.320
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

532
00:28:57.320 --> 00:28:58.090
I'm Zach Memos.

533
00:28:58.090 --> 00:28:58.850
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

534
00:28:58.850 --> 00:29:00.080
>> And we will see you soon.

535
00:29:00.080 --> 00:29:07.595
[MUSIC]

536
00:29:07.595 --> 00:29:09.968
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:04.100
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:04.100 --> 00:00:07.627
I'm your host Don Pezet coming at you
live from San Francisco [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.627 --> 00:00:10.600
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.090 --> 00:00:13.520
>> Hello again and thank you for

5
00:00:13.520 --> 00:00:17.770
joining us on ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:21.060
I'm your host Zack Memos as we
continue on with ITIL MALC,

7
00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:24.640
this is a service transition
across the life cycle.

8
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:27.830
And bringing us all that information,
is Terry Decker or

9
00:00:27.830 --> 00:00:29.180
as I call him Sherlock Terry.

10
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:32.370
>> [LAUGH] Thank you,
Doctor Watson as always.

11
00:00:32.370 --> 00:00:32.960
>> As always.

12
00:00:32.960 --> 00:00:37.140
>> So, here we are moving through the past

13
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:40.630
the value propositions of each of
the processes in each of the stages.

14
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:44.120
And now moving into how these
stages interact with each other.

15
00:00:44.120 --> 00:00:47.650
They get their tentacles wrapped
around each other somewhat.

16
00:00:47.650 --> 00:00:50.980
So these feedback loops between design and
transition,

17
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:53.660
between transition and strategy,
between operations and

18
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:58.690
design, all these feedback loops is what
we're trying to build out and understand.

19
00:00:58.690 --> 00:01:02.350
Academically speaking, what I mean
by that, as you're taking the exam,

20
00:01:02.350 --> 00:01:07.410
understanding or
recognizing potential fault lines

21
00:01:07.410 --> 00:01:12.040
among the communication loops, or
the feedback loops between the stages,

22
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:16.000
is an important aspect of MALC, or
management across the life cycle.

23
00:01:16.000 --> 00:01:17.880
In each of the other intermediate exams,

24
00:01:17.880 --> 00:01:22.030
you're always operating within that
little silo of that intermediate exam.

25
00:01:22.030 --> 00:01:26.190
MALC is not in a silo, it's got
the entire lifecycle in front of you and

26
00:01:26.190 --> 00:01:27.600
you have to manage across it, right?

27
00:01:27.600 --> 00:01:28.980
That's the challenge here.

28
00:01:28.980 --> 00:01:33.355
So you can expect on the exam that
you're going to get some questions

29
00:01:33.355 --> 00:01:37.375
that kind of dissect
the interactions among the processes

30
00:01:37.375 --> 00:01:40.875
across stages as well the interaction
across stages themselves.

31
00:01:40.875 --> 00:01:45.620
So that's what we're exploring now is how
these stages interact across other ones.

32
00:01:45.620 --> 00:01:48.260
We had an episode just now on design, and

33
00:01:48.260 --> 00:01:49.900
now we're talking about
service transition.

34
00:01:51.010 --> 00:01:54.035
And as we look at the graphic here then,
you'll see, again,

35
00:01:54.035 --> 00:01:58.810
linking back to design or straightaway,
is a Service Design Package.

36
00:01:58.810 --> 00:02:03.280
We talked about how it's answering all
the questions that service transition

37
00:02:03.280 --> 00:02:07.450
needs to successfully bring
this service to life, right?

38
00:02:07.450 --> 00:02:10.870
So it's actually asking
questions about exit and

39
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:15.240
entry criteria and
where are the quality gates along the way.

40
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:17.389
So have we signed off on
business requirements?

41
00:02:17.389 --> 00:02:20.360
That's one of the quality
gates particularly, right?

42
00:02:20.360 --> 00:02:24.910
There could be many different gates
as you go through the process.

43
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:28.090
This also could affect
project management gates,

44
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:30.090
like when do you get your approvals?

45
00:02:30.090 --> 00:02:32.210
When do you get additional funding?

46
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:36.900
Maybe you have a particular service that
you want to design under one project and

47
00:02:36.900 --> 00:02:40.199
do a review, and
then approve the transition project.

48
00:02:40.199 --> 00:02:44.337
I mean, that's possible, I wouldn't say
that was common, but it's also possible

of delivering the wrong things.

285

286

291

Just straight up.

292

>> Customer, value, service.

>> That's right, customer, value, service.

So self study is very important you're

learning opportunity,

that reinforcement opportunity.

at all about these things,

join the forum, ask some questions there.

Experts will be there to

other peers will be there to

So remember the forum's there for

00:17:43.480 --> 00:17:45.985

ITIL MALC, service transition

it is pretty indicative

of a lot of churn here between operation

17

That has been my experience is that
when you are actually delivering

00:01:05.360 --> 00:01:09.300
the service where you see plenty
of opportunities to improve.

00:01:09.300 --> 00:01:10.450
Right.

20
00:01:10.450 --> 00:01:12.680
It's certainly visible to

21
00:01:12.680 --> 00:01:14.220
You're delivering the service and
operation, so

the customer's going to be
perhaps knocking on your door.

23
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:18.050
They're using the service,

24
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:22.310
they might be complaining, they might
be hitting the service desk every day.

25
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:25.030
With not complaints, but with an incident.

26
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:26.860
I can't find the submit button.

27
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:28.350
The printer's not working.

28
00:01:28.350 --> 00:01:29.750
How come my headsets didn't arrive?

29
00:01:29.750 --> 00:01:31.720
I mean,
there could be some complaints involved.

30
00:01:31.720 --> 00:01:35.350
But also could be, I don't know how to
do this, I don't know how to do that.

31
00:01:35.350 --> 00:01:41.230
There could be some help issues involved
in these calls to the service desk.

32
00:01:41.230 --> 00:01:45.590
So, when your in operation, they're
going to have an opportunity to start.

33
00:01:45.590 --> 00:01:49.590
Keeping your finger on the pulse
of customer satisfaction as well.

34
00:01:49.590 --> 00:01:56.670
So, there are certainly a lot of churn for
CSI that comes out of service operations.

35
00:01:56.670 --> 00:01:58.770
That's a very appropriate
little graphic here.

36
00:01:58.770 --> 00:02:03.110
Lots of things happening in
between service operation and CSI.

37
00:02:03.110 --> 00:02:04.500
>> It's a good graphic too,
it makes sense.

38
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:07.340
>> All right, and we saw this earlier,
it shows up at all the courses.

39
00:02:07.340 --> 00:02:11.240
And we saw this earlier even in this
course, where it's got the downhill

40
00:02:11.240 --> 00:02:14.880
flow from service strategy to design,
or transition to operations.

41
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:18.260
