waiting for something to do.

42
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:20.080
Now, I don't want you to get that idea.

43
00:02:20.080 --> 00:02:23.040
Remember, CSI is alive and
well everywhere.

44
00:02:23.040 --> 00:02:27.420
But certainly it's possible that
service operations could churn up

45
00:02:27.420 --> 00:02:31.590
some issues that actually
could be improved upstream.

46
00:02:31.590 --> 00:02:34.590
Now, while we might need to
improve service operation itself.

47
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:35.190
Right.
And

48
00:02:35.190 --> 00:02:37.680
that's where the improvement idea lies,

49
00:02:37.680 --> 00:02:41.570
it could be that the improvement
idea actually is upstream.

50
00:02:41.570 --> 00:02:45.260
I know in my own experience we regularly
found, we were bringing on services that

51
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:48.530
already existed, but fires were burning
on them, I mean, there was something,

52
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:51.830
there were architectural problems,
there was outage issues,

53
00:02:51.830 --> 00:02:56.980
there weren't request models, or incident
models in place, that sort of thing.

54
00:02:56.980 --> 00:03:00.773
And when we took these on we found
a recurring theme that, you know what?,

55
00:03:00.773 --> 00:03:03.906
they could have asked this
question up in service design, and

56
00:03:03.906 --> 00:03:06.890
we wouldn't be facing this question now,
right?

57
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:11.500
So, we understood kind of the whole
lifecycle approach to service management.

58
00:03:12.590 --> 00:03:15.730
We hadn't been practicing that in
this organization very long at all,

59
00:03:15.730 --> 00:03:17.660
in fac,t in some cases.

60
00:03:17.660 --> 00:03:22.370
So, if we discern that the problems are
actually existing upstream, then by golly,

61
00:03:22.370 --> 00:03:24.230
let's go change things upstream.

62
00:03:24.230 --> 00:03:26.290
So, while there is a lot of churn here,

63
00:03:26.290 --> 00:03:29.700
I recognize the churn here
between operations and CSI.

64
00:03:29.700 --> 00:03:33.850
Remember, CSI is alive and
well throughout the life cycle stages.

65
00:03:33.850 --> 00:03:37.720
And operations is just showing
the symptoms of those issues.

66
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:43.460
So, that's the theme of the rest
of this particular episode,

67
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:47.710
is that CSI is there to improve things,
absolutely.

68
00:03:47.710 --> 00:03:51.925
And, because operations is where
the blemishes are often exposed.

69
00:03:51.925 --> 00:03:56.845
Service operations is key
component to improving, all right.

70
00:03:56.845 --> 00:03:58.265
So, as we continue to go.

71
00:03:58.265 --> 00:04:00.195
You should have service reviews.

72
00:04:00.195 --> 00:04:01.375
The way to expose and

73
00:04:01.375 --> 00:04:06.350
be very transparent about how you're
doing is to review your services.

74
00:04:06.350 --> 00:04:08.020
Now, remember, service level management,

75
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:12.370
way back up in service design,
defined what success looks like.

76
00:04:12.370 --> 00:04:14.960
Incidents will be resolved
within two hours.

77
00:04:14.960 --> 00:04:17.580
Availability will be 99.9%.

78
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:22.110
Changes will be delivered on time and
not cause any problems.

79
00:04:22.110 --> 00:04:25.970
I mean, all of these things could be
built into a service level agreement.

80
00:04:25.970 --> 00:04:28.830
And you're also promising within
that service-level agreement

81
00:04:28.830 --> 00:04:30.770
that you're going to review things.

82
00:04:30.770 --> 00:04:34.820
So, what you're actually reviewing is
the operational effectiveness, right?

83
00:04:34.820 --> 00:04:36.480
Of service operations.

84
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:38.160
So, have these reviews.

85
00:04:38.160 --> 00:04:42.230
Look at how well you're doing, or
conversely, how well you're not doing.

86
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:47.480
And if you're not doing well, highlight
your commitment to improving, all right?

87
00:04:48.760 --> 00:04:50.530
Obviously playing through there.

88
00:04:50.530 --> 00:04:52.140
So, there's that connection to SLM, right?

89
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:57.250
Becoming a true service provider means,
you're gonna keep score, right?

90
00:04:57.250 --> 00:05:02.580
If you want to improve your performance,
the first

91
00:05:02.580 --> 00:05:07.960
step is to measure your performance,
agree to what success looks like, right?

92
00:05:07.960 --> 00:05:12.350
So, if the client says, or the customer
says, it's slow, define what slow is.

93
00:05:12.350 --> 00:05:16.090
If they say, it's always down,
define availability, right?

94
00:05:16.090 --> 00:05:20.110
If they say, the service desk is slow,
define slow, right?

95
00:05:20.110 --> 00:05:22.000
Come up with measurable targets.

96
00:05:22.000 --> 00:05:23.850
Commit to those targets and

97
00:05:23.850 --> 00:05:28.380
transparently reveal your
performance versus those targets.

98
00:05:28.380 --> 00:05:31.020
SLM provides the basis for that, okay?

99
00:05:32.200 --> 00:05:34.770
So, SLM has a play in service operations,
right.

100
00:05:35.860 --> 00:05:36.850
Customer satisfaction.

101
00:05:38.020 --> 00:05:43.210
Now, BRM is there to handle complaints,
and to deal with unsatisfied customers.

102
00:05:43.210 --> 00:05:46.960
That's what the process called business
relationship management is about.

103
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:50.540
And what your trying to do is to
ensure they use the word secure here.

104
00:05:50.540 --> 00:05:53.520
How can we secure customer satisfaction

105
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:57.390
through our service offerings is
really what you're trying to get done.

106
00:05:57.390 --> 00:06:01.360
You do this by designing the right
services through an appropriate strategy.

107
00:06:02.470 --> 00:06:04.630
You design them to satisfy that strategy.

108
00:06:05.940 --> 00:06:10.560
You make sure that the service-accepted
criteria is fully vetted, and

109
00:06:10.560 --> 00:06:13.360
then validated in service transition.

110
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:16.200
And of course, continual service
improvement is going to be there

111
00:06:16.200 --> 00:06:20.350
to highlight when you have a shortfall,
when you are not meeting that commitment.

112
00:06:20.350 --> 00:06:23.400
I want to challenge you to
something else to consider as well.

113
00:06:24.570 --> 00:06:26.620
Integration with the business means,

114
00:06:26.620 --> 00:06:29.360
certainly you are going to understand
what they're trying to get done.

115
00:06:30.420 --> 00:06:35.590
Measuring your performance is going to
help give you indications of whether,

116
00:06:35.590 --> 00:06:37.480
or not you're satisfying the customer.

117
00:06:37.480 --> 00:06:42.090
But, being very explicit, and
specific about customer satisfaction.

118
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:46.140
And by explicit and specific,
I mean, you know, ask them often.

119
00:06:46.140 --> 00:06:49.630
Don't just take the anecdotal complaints,
right?

120
00:06:49.630 --> 00:06:52.960
Formalize your feedback
mechanisms with the customer, so

121
00:06:52.960 --> 00:06:56.040
you know if you're on the right track,
or not, formalize that.

122
00:06:56.040 --> 00:06:57.680
That's what I mean by explicit, and

123
00:06:57.680 --> 00:07:02.320
by specific, I mean,
focus on their business outcomes.

124
00:07:02.320 --> 00:07:08.210
Be very specific to that, now, that's not
an easy grab, but it's a worthy grab.

125
00:07:08.210 --> 00:07:12.260
If you have promised that your
IT service will help the lawyer

126
00:07:12.260 --> 00:07:16.190
get cases filed more timely and
more accurately.

127
00:07:16.190 --> 00:07:21.010
Then measured speed and
measure accuracy of court filings, right.

128
00:07:21.010 --> 00:07:23.870
If you promise your service is
going to help the oil company

129
00:07:23.870 --> 00:07:27.460
find the oil more quickly,
measure the speed.

130
00:07:27.460 --> 00:07:28.730
To find oil.

131
00:07:28.730 --> 00:07:31.943
Now, you're giving here the business
is business there and they say, no!

132
00:07:31.943 --> 00:07:34.850
Stay away IT I get that, right?

133
00:07:34.850 --> 00:07:37.180
You can measure the availability
of your services, and

134
00:07:37.180 --> 00:07:42.330
be a proxy measurement to their business
outcomes that maybe the best you can do.

135
00:07:42.330 --> 00:07:44.270
But how valuable would it be?

136
00:07:44.270 --> 00:07:46.220
How strategic would it be for

137
00:07:46.220 --> 00:07:51.590
you to integrate with the business so
much that they can see direct pay off.

138
00:07:51.590 --> 00:07:54.840
Of your services to
their business outcomes.

139
00:07:54.840 --> 00:07:56.960
You're not going to get
that without measurement.

140
00:07:56.960 --> 00:08:00.150
So, this idea of measuring your
own performance is important.

141
00:08:00.150 --> 00:08:02.240
I'm not degrading that in any way.

142
00:08:02.240 --> 00:08:04.210
It's right up there as a gold standard.

143
00:08:04.210 --> 00:08:06.090
Measure your performance.

144
00:08:06.090 --> 00:08:10.990
But measure how your performance affects
their business outcomes is a next step of

145
00:08:10.990 --> 00:08:15.360
integration with the business that can't
be overstated how important that is, okay.

146
00:08:16.520 --> 00:08:19.600
And look for
that opportunities back at work.

147
00:08:19.600 --> 00:08:22.910
Look for those opportunities to
squeeze that value proposition

148
00:08:22.910 --> 00:08:24.570
on the MALC exam as well.

149
00:08:24.570 --> 00:08:28.620
Get as much value as you can, so
the difference between a five answer, and

150
00:08:28.620 --> 00:08:32.160
a three answer regarding improvements

151
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:36.520
might be the difference between
just focusing on IT performance.

152
00:08:36.520 --> 00:08:38.300
And focusing on business outcomes.

153
00:08:38.300 --> 00:08:39.670
The five answer that looks for

154
00:08:39.670 --> 00:08:43.690
that business value proposition
is probably gonna be there, okay.

155
00:08:44.860 --> 00:08:47.620
Now, so you're gonna measure,
you're gonna grab.

156
00:08:47.620 --> 00:08:50.680
The SLM is gonna do a lot of measurement,
gonna get all the stuff,

157
00:08:50.680 --> 00:08:55.680
the collating part is putting it
into a digestible report, right.

158
00:08:55.680 --> 00:08:58.540
Collate that information maybe
they're dissatisfied with service desk

159
00:08:58.540 --> 00:08:59.040
performance.

160
00:08:59.040 --> 00:09:01.080
Maybe they're dissatisfied
with availability.

161
00:09:01.080 --> 00:09:02.890
Maybe they hate the functionality.

162
00:09:02.890 --> 00:09:05.090
It's clunky, it doesn't work,
it's not intuitive.

163
00:09:05.090 --> 00:09:07.690
I can never find the submit button,
whatever it might be,

164
00:09:07.690 --> 00:09:11.300
they might be up there complaining
about lot's of things.

165
00:09:11.300 --> 00:09:15.260
Collate those things and
understand where you need to go.

166
00:09:15.260 --> 00:09:17.310
I like these little equation here,

167
00:09:17.310 --> 00:09:22.950
Satisfaction = Perception- Expectation,
right?

168
00:09:22.950 --> 00:09:25.970
Expectation management is
very important here, right?

169
00:09:28.360 --> 00:09:31.220
What is slow for a login?

170
00:09:31.220 --> 00:09:33.570
Ask one person, they may ten seconds.

171
00:09:33.570 --> 00:09:36.790
Ask another, they'll say, if it takes
more than five seconds, I'm giving up.

172
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:42.000
Ask another person, and they are quite
fine waiting 15 seconds, right?

173
00:09:42.000 --> 00:09:43.210
What is slow?

174
00:09:43.210 --> 00:09:47.360
So, if their expectation
is that speed means logins

175
00:09:47.360 --> 00:09:51.640
are less than five seconds, you might
need to change your expectations.

176
00:09:52.660 --> 00:09:53.360
Right?

177
00:09:53.360 --> 00:09:59.720
So, that their satisfaction level goes up,
because their perceptions have been reset.

178
00:09:59.720 --> 00:10:03.350
>> Yeah, there's an old saying that says,
that you'll be happier,

179
00:10:03.350 --> 00:10:06.135
if you accept rather than expect.

180
00:10:06.135 --> 00:10:07.660
[LAUGH]
>> Good point.

181
00:10:07.660 --> 00:10:08.750
Accept rather than expect.

182
00:10:08.750 --> 00:10:10.420
Yeah, that's pretty good, yeah.

183
00:10:10.420 --> 00:10:15.220
I remember taking a leadership course
that talked about this idea of happiness

184
00:10:15.220 --> 00:10:16.220
as a choice.

185
00:10:16.220 --> 00:10:21.760
A pastor at my church years ago told us
a little story that when he was a little

186
00:10:21.760 --> 00:10:25.710
boy, he was scraping some paint off
the eave of a house in the summertime in

187
00:10:25.710 --> 00:10:29.120
Florida, grew up down in Florida, and
just sweaty, and it's in his face,

188
00:10:29.120 --> 00:10:30.310
it's sticking on his skin.

189
00:10:30.310 --> 00:10:33.560
And he's a 12-year-old boy that much be
rather playing baseball down the street,

190
00:10:33.560 --> 00:10:36.055
and he's just mad going through this.

191
00:10:36.055 --> 00:10:36.870
>> [LAUGH].
>> And

192
00:10:36.870 --> 00:10:42.500
his father said, you have a choice,
you're going to be doing this today.

193
00:10:42.500 --> 00:10:45.310
You can either choose to be mad,
or you can choose to be happy.

194
00:10:45.310 --> 00:10:45.940
Right.
So,

195
00:10:45.940 --> 00:10:47.802
just a little philosophical
question there.

196
00:10:47.802 --> 00:10:49.757
>> Accept, not expected.

197
00:10:49.757 --> 00:10:51.190
>> Exactly, very good.

198
00:10:51.190 --> 00:10:55.700
So, in this expectation management,
you need to allow your

199
00:10:55.700 --> 00:10:59.310
customers to understand appropriately
what they can't expect, so

200
00:10:59.310 --> 00:11:02.210
that they can accept-
>> There it is, yeah.

201
00:11:02.210 --> 00:11:05.550
>> More appropriately
what you're providing.

202
00:11:05.550 --> 00:11:09.820
Now, that doesn't mean you lie, or you
cheat, or you say, don't worry about it.

203
00:11:09.820 --> 00:11:10.960
15 seconds is fast enough.

204
00:11:10.960 --> 00:11:11.860
Go away.

205
00:11:11.860 --> 00:11:15.510
I'm not saying that you
discount it in any way.

206
00:11:15.510 --> 00:11:19.640
Be aware that their expectations are going
to affect their perceptions, and

207
00:11:19.640 --> 00:11:21.100
you need to manage both, right.

208
00:11:21.100 --> 00:11:22.460
You need to manage those things.

209
00:11:22.460 --> 00:11:25.800
And then, you have a better chance of
management of satisfaction, right?

210
00:11:25.800 --> 00:11:30.405
All right, so we've churned up a bunch of
ideas potentially from service operations.

211
00:11:30.405 --> 00:11:32.335
CSI looks at those opportunities and

212
00:11:32.335 --> 00:11:36.290
makes the appropriate judgment as
where we need to go to improve.

213
00:11:36.290 --> 00:11:39.150
Maybe it is just simply
improving operations.

214
00:11:39.150 --> 00:11:42.980
Maybe it's improving
something more holistically,

215
00:11:42.980 --> 00:11:47.160
like up at service design, or
at service trans, even service strategy.

216
00:11:47.160 --> 00:11:51.810
Wherever the dog may sniff out
the opportunity, follow that dog there,

217
00:11:51.810 --> 00:11:53.380
and enjoy the prey.

218
00:11:53.380 --> 00:11:55.625
>> Hopefully not my dog,
because my dog doesn't smell very well.

219
00:11:55.625 --> 00:11:57.825
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

220
00:11:57.825 --> 00:11:59.772
All right.
The last shows us how CSI, and

221
00:11:59.772 --> 00:12:03.349
operations kind of interact to
improve things across the life cycle,

222
00:12:03.349 --> 00:12:05.260
not just between themselves.

223
00:12:05.260 --> 00:12:06.220
How about some homework?

224
00:12:06.220 --> 00:12:07.650
I know, you love homework.

225
00:12:07.650 --> 00:12:09.870
So, there's options available,

226
00:12:09.870 --> 00:12:12.920
many options available to
reinforce these many topics here.

227
00:12:12.920 --> 00:12:14.720
There's one called customer satisfaction.

228
00:12:14.720 --> 00:12:16.340
You see that highlighted here.

229
00:12:16.340 --> 00:12:20.440
There's yet another one called
Service Desk Survey Techniques.

230
00:12:20.440 --> 00:12:22.330
Another exercise there.

231
00:12:22.330 --> 00:12:25.100
And yet another one called,
strategic assessment.

232
00:12:25.100 --> 00:12:28.160
All three of these knowledge checks, or

233
00:12:28.160 --> 00:12:31.450
self study opportunities
are available in episode files.

234
00:12:31.450 --> 00:12:36.210
So, finally, link the episode files,
download these and enjoy them.

235
00:12:36.210 --> 00:12:38.000
If you have any questions about them.

236
00:12:38.000 --> 00:12:42.570
Or any other subject matter, come to the
forum and interact there with the experts,

237
00:12:42.570 --> 00:12:46.450
or the peers taking this learning and
enjoy it.

238
00:12:46.450 --> 00:12:50.100
>> Awesome job as usual
Terry ITIL MALC service operation and

239
00:12:50.100 --> 00:12:55.500
CSI across the life cycle, and there is so
much more content in the ITIL MALC series.

240
00:12:55.500 --> 00:12:56.950
Make sure you watch every single video.

241
00:12:56.950 --> 00:12:58.429
You will be glad you did.

242
00:12:58.429 --> 00:13:01.060
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

243
00:13:01.060 --> 00:13:03.840
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

244
00:13:03.840 --> 00:13:04.720
I'm Zach Memos.

245
00:13:04.720 --> 00:13:05.500
>> I'm Terry Decker.

246
00:13:05.500 --> 00:13:08.126
>> We will see you very soon.

247
00:13:08.126 --> 00:13:14.156
[MUSIC]

248
00:13:14.156 --> 00:13:16.160
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review considerations of challenges and risks for each lifecycle stage.
episodes.title: Managing Success Across the Lifecycle
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.185
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.185 --> 00:00:08.143
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.143 --> 00:00:12.440
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.440 --> 00:00:13.750
>> Hello again and thank you for

5
00:00:13.750 --> 00:00:17.530
choosing ITPro.TV helping
you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.530 --> 00:00:22.680
I'm Zach Memos, your host,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC.

7
00:00:22.680 --> 00:00:27.340
And this is Managing Success Across a Life
Cycle with, you know him, you love him,

8
00:00:27.340 --> 00:00:30.800
you can't live without him,
Terry Decker right here.

9
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:31.970
Terry, good to see you again.

10
00:00:31.970 --> 00:00:33.290
>> Glad to be here Zack.

11
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:36.460
And yes, we're gonna dive into
some critical success factors and

12
00:00:36.460 --> 00:00:39.800
challenges associated with
managing across a life cycle.

13
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:45.270
The discussion of the challenges
related to service management

14
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:50.140
focus on the customer,
as you would expect from ITIL.

15
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:53.654
It also focuses on
resistance to change and

16
00:00:53.654 --> 00:00:56.815
when you talk about a culture
of continuous improvement,

17
00:00:56.815 --> 00:01:01.220
you' re also talking about
a culture of continuous change.

18
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:03.710
And change is not necessarily
embraced by everyone equally.

19
00:01:03.710 --> 00:01:05.660
Some people like it,
some people will hate it.

20
00:01:05.660 --> 00:01:08.760
Some people resist it, some people
don't like it, but get along with it.

21
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:12.280
Some people just can't wait for
the next newest flavor.

22
00:01:12.280 --> 00:01:17.240
So that is the dynamic generally in play
as we discuss these various challenges and

23
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:19.880
critical success factors
of service strategy.

24
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:21.280
So let's have a look.

25
00:01:21.280 --> 00:01:22.760
Looking here at service strategy and

26
00:01:22.760 --> 00:01:24.830
some of the challenges,
I mentioned the complexity.

27
00:01:24.830 --> 00:01:30.380
Organizational complexity, these
varying degrees of attitudes and goals.

28
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:33.990
You might have folks that are just
trying to keep the lights on and

29
00:01:33.990 --> 00:01:35.290
keep things stable.

30
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:36.770
They've been working their several years.

31
00:01:36.770 --> 00:01:38.970
They don't want anything new.

32
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:42.120
I like the old system, don't give me
the new system, that sort of thing.

33
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:45.460
And again the type of folks that says we
need something new, something better.

34
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:49.360
Let's make it snappier, easier to use etc.

35
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:55.820
So that means from a strategic level,
you have some complexity in coordinating

36
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:58.610
toward these common goals,
or common outcomes.

37
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:00.640
Getting a common understanding
of where you're going and

38
00:02:00.640 --> 00:02:03.750
how you're going to get
there is somewhat difficult.

39
00:02:03.750 --> 00:02:07.890
Again, not really providing any
expert guidance here, just giving you

40
00:02:07.890 --> 00:02:11.160
the context of the challenges
associated with server strategy.

41
00:02:12.170 --> 00:02:15.340
If you consider some other ones,
I wanna hone in on this one a little bit.

42
00:02:15.340 --> 00:02:19.400
So if you go for screen, I wanna specially
look at the first column here and

43
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:20.645
really focus on this things.

44
00:02:21.700 --> 00:02:25.835
Begin on the outside not the inside
of the service organization.

45
00:02:25.835 --> 00:02:32.035
Begin on the outside, meaning don't
focus on IT, focus on the customer.

46
00:02:32.035 --> 00:02:36.725
I've reinforced this in various ways
throughout the various episodes.

47
00:02:36.725 --> 00:02:39.265
It even includes
the challenge of measurement.

48
00:02:40.355 --> 00:02:43.595
If you want to measure your performance,
sure, measure IT performance,

49
00:02:43.595 --> 00:02:45.695
that's important to the customers.

50
00:02:45.695 --> 00:02:49.450
It should be, but
what is the business doing?

51
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:51.500
How are they performing?

52
00:02:51.500 --> 00:02:53.600
If they are trying to
find something faster, or

53
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:57.690
do something with more accuracy,
then measure speed, measure accuracy.

54
00:02:57.690 --> 00:03:02.560
Be part of the business metrics
discussion, and make sure your

55
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:07.570
IT services are aligned with those
specific outcomes that are measurable.

56
00:03:07.570 --> 00:03:10.740
Another aspect of measurements
is that you need to be

57
00:03:10.740 --> 00:03:14.120
responsive to the customer's
changing needs.

58
00:03:14.120 --> 00:03:17.670
And focusing on what the customer's
trying to do is gonna beat

59
00:03:17.670 --> 00:03:19.030
all your other measurements.

60
00:03:19.030 --> 00:03:24.560
Let me put it this way, is it possible for
you to go to a service meeting and have

61
00:03:24.560 --> 00:03:29.970
all pretty shiny green metrics they're all
really good and have an upset customer?

62
00:03:31.290 --> 00:03:34.140
All your measurements are good,
but the customer is unhappy.

63
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:35.820
Is that possible?

64
00:03:35.820 --> 00:03:36.370
>> Absolutely.

65
00:03:36.370 --> 00:03:40.340
>> Yep, so that either means you need
to set a different framework for

66
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:43.400
your measurements have a more
balanced approach to your scorecard.

67
00:03:43.400 --> 00:03:46.320
For instance, or
you certainly need to recognize, and

68
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:47.840
keep your finger on
the pulse of the customer.

69
00:03:47.840 --> 00:03:49.160
You're not paying attention.

70
00:03:49.160 --> 00:03:52.150
If you're all green, and
have a dissatisfied customer, and

71
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:55.780
you're unaware of that, then you're
obviously, you're found lacking.

72
00:03:55.780 --> 00:03:57.260
So, focus on the customer.

73
00:03:57.260 --> 00:03:59.760
That's also part of
the outside in approach.

74
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:00.670
What do they need?

75
00:04:00.670 --> 00:04:03.327
What are they trying to get done?

76
00:04:03.327 --> 00:04:04.590
I like this next one too.

77
00:04:04.590 --> 00:04:08.510
Think of process and service as equals.

78
00:04:08.510 --> 00:04:11.490
Now I know this is a tough nut for
some people to crack.

79
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:14.770
I know some folks that find
process to just mean bureaucracy.

80
00:04:16.010 --> 00:04:17.390
We've always done it this way before,

81
00:04:17.390 --> 00:04:21.150
we never needed a process before,
why do we have to follow a process now?

82
00:04:21.150 --> 00:04:22.250
If you get that kind of feedback.

83
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:26.500
Or, the process is too cumbersome.

84
00:04:26.500 --> 00:04:28.700
I have to get to many
approvals along the way.

85
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:31.160
Now, I'm not saying you
ignore that feedback.

86
00:04:31.160 --> 00:04:32.990
You'd listen to that feedback and,
perhaps,

87
00:04:32.990 --> 00:04:35.710
you do need to tweak your processes some.

88
00:04:35.710 --> 00:04:40.070
Maybe there are too many steps for some
types of activities, and other activities

89
00:04:40.070 --> 00:04:44.940
could be more streamlined with, automatic
approvals or something like that.

90
00:04:44.940 --> 00:04:49.570
So when you are considering processes
on equal footing with services,

91
00:04:49.570 --> 00:04:51.310
you pay attention to them.

92
00:04:51.310 --> 00:04:53.680
It's not that you throw them out and
ignore them.

93
00:04:53.680 --> 00:04:56.310
Is that you tailor them
to particular needs.

94
00:04:56.310 --> 00:04:59.940
Now, ITIL talks about in

95
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:04.450
rather casual terms sometimes
about just follow the process.

96
00:05:04.450 --> 00:05:06.630
And if you are casual about it,

97
00:05:06.630 --> 00:05:10.900
then you'll have a casual
approach to your success as well.

98
00:05:10.900 --> 00:05:14.370
Formalizing our steps,
formalizing your activities allows for

99
00:05:14.370 --> 00:05:19.280
measurement, it allows for consistency
across different organizational, elements.

100
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:23.950
It also allows for
a regime of methodical improvement

101
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:27.600
instead of just trying to throw something
on the wall and see if it sticks.

102
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:30.375
Considering process as an important

103
00:05:30.375 --> 00:05:34.795
valuable asset instead of a bureaucratic
asset would be a big help.

104
00:05:34.795 --> 00:05:37.845
Now, academically speaking,
I've been talking about operations, there.

105
00:05:37.845 --> 00:05:38.965
Academically speaking,

106
00:05:38.965 --> 00:05:43.415
absolutely ITIL's going to have
a predisposition that processes are good.

107
00:05:43.415 --> 00:05:46.298
So as you're looking at
your exam questions and

108
00:05:46.298 --> 00:05:50.841
trying to figure out how to best apply
the right answer the given scenario,

109
00:05:50.841 --> 00:05:55.384
based on this case study, you're going
to be looking at opportunities for

110
00:05:55.384 --> 00:05:58.651
processes, to fill the gaps
where value is missing.

111
00:05:58.651 --> 00:06:03.257
This is the regular theme that plays out
through this [INAUDIBLE] across the life

112
00:06:03.257 --> 00:06:04.060
cycle exam.

113
00:06:04.060 --> 00:06:05.920
Things are going wrong,

114
00:06:05.920 --> 00:06:09.300
the way you can try to forestall these
things is get stakeholders involved.

115
00:06:09.300 --> 00:06:11.370
Get their feedback, measure and

116
00:06:11.370 --> 00:06:14.560
perhaps introduce new
processes is they are missing.

117
00:06:15.970 --> 00:06:18.670
All right, numbers matter,
making measurements.

118
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:21.290
This is all about
the measurements framework here.

119
00:06:21.290 --> 00:06:26.020
Numbers matter, and numbers can be
volume numbers, how many in a certain

120
00:06:26.020 --> 00:06:31.300
amount of time, what percentage of this
was good, what percentage was bad.

121
00:06:31.300 --> 00:06:34.710
Working through the measurements,
coming up with actual numbers and

122
00:06:34.710 --> 00:06:37.080
putting a time box around them as well.

123
00:06:37.080 --> 00:06:43.200
You know, 60% of our tickets from
January were resolved within two hours.

124
00:06:43.200 --> 00:06:46.030
In February, 80% of them were.

125
00:06:46.030 --> 00:06:48.230
You got these time elements involved here.

126
00:06:48.230 --> 00:06:51.270
So what's so
different about February than January?

127
00:06:51.270 --> 00:06:53.790
Was there something that
was assignable to January?

128
00:06:53.790 --> 00:06:56.030
Yeah, that's when the data
center melted down.

129
00:06:56.030 --> 00:06:59.190
The data center melted down in January and
we were going crazy at the service desk.

130
00:06:59.190 --> 00:07:02.450
So yeah,
we definitely got behind in January.

131
00:07:02.450 --> 00:07:04.420
But you have an assignable cost for that.

132
00:07:04.420 --> 00:07:07.860
So having time scales
associated with your actual

133
00:07:07.860 --> 00:07:11.500
numbers is also a valuable asset
when you consider measurement.

134
00:07:11.500 --> 00:07:15.690
And then finally the last one here,
compete as an organization.

135
00:07:15.690 --> 00:07:18.690
You have competition with
potential outside organizations.

136
00:07:18.690 --> 00:07:20.480
Compete within your organization.

137
00:07:20.480 --> 00:07:22.640
A good, friendly competition.

138
00:07:22.640 --> 00:07:25.680
Setting these measurements
in play against each other.

139
00:07:25.680 --> 00:07:29.130
Say, but the server team gets 80%
of their tickets resolved on time.

140
00:07:29.130 --> 00:07:32.170
The database team only gets 60% of theirs.

141
00:07:32.170 --> 00:07:36.690
Just by expressing the performance you're
kinda building in the competition because

142
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:38.810
it becomes transparent,
it becomes visible.

143
00:07:38.810 --> 00:07:41.550
And it doesn't need to be a blame culture,

144
00:07:41.550 --> 00:07:43.830
it just needs to be
a motivational culture.

145
00:07:43.830 --> 00:07:46.610
Not assigning blame,
just assigning accountability and

146
00:07:46.610 --> 00:07:49.560
moving toward improvement
with the actual numbers.

147
00:07:49.560 --> 00:07:51.764
Okay?
>> Yeah, in fact, they did a study once.

148
00:07:51.764 --> 00:07:55.454
They were sending fish across the United
States and they would get to the other

149
00:07:55.454 --> 00:07:58.944
side of the States, like from the west
to the east, and they'd be dead.

150
00:07:58.944 --> 00:08:01.415
They just they couldn't keep them
alive until they put catfish in there.

151
00:08:01.415 --> 00:08:05.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> The catfish kind of kept them alive.

152
00:08:05.090 --> 00:08:06.463
It was that motivation.

153
00:08:06.463 --> 00:08:07.410
>> I got you.

154
00:08:07.410 --> 00:08:10.126
>> Motivation.
>> They were sort of just swimming around.

155
00:08:10.126 --> 00:08:11.004
>> They were motivated to stay alive.

156
00:08:11.004 --> 00:08:11.620
>> Motivation to stay alive.

157
00:08:11.620 --> 00:08:12.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> How about that?

158
00:08:12.760 --> 00:08:14.160
That's pretty interesting.

159
00:08:14.160 --> 00:08:15.170
Staying active.

160
00:08:15.170 --> 00:08:15.810
Interesting approach.

161
00:08:16.820 --> 00:08:17.340
All right.

162
00:08:17.340 --> 00:08:18.420
Further looking at the risk.

163
00:08:18.420 --> 00:08:19.640
Now this we're looking
at service strategy.

164
00:08:19.640 --> 00:08:23.790
The risk would be failing on
these opportunities to measure,

165
00:08:23.790 --> 00:08:29.006
not having sufficient measurement in
place, or making the wrong guesses, right?

166
00:08:29.006 --> 00:08:31.630
So to speak, you shouldn't be guessing but

167
00:08:31.630 --> 00:08:34.190
you're gonna make some
calculated risks along the way.

168
00:08:34.190 --> 00:08:37.870
What if you kind of miss
on that risk assessment and

169
00:08:37.870 --> 00:08:41.290
you deliver a service that's not
really satisfying to the customers or

170
00:08:41.290 --> 00:08:45.130
you over build or over spend on stuff
that the customer didn't really need?

171
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:49.780
I've certainly seen that happen too where
we responded to the flashy object as an IT

172
00:08:49.780 --> 00:08:53.880
organization, the nice shiny object in the
distance because it really looked good.

173
00:08:53.880 --> 00:08:57.130
It was in our wheelhouse,
we really are good at this.

174
00:08:57.130 --> 00:09:00.500
So give me one of those again and I'll do
it again for you, customer, kind of thing.

175
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:04.030
Give you an example of this challenge of
strategy ongoing through an organization.

176
00:09:04.030 --> 00:09:06.880
I'll use a little quaint
military example for this one.

177
00:09:08.220 --> 00:09:13.825
If the strategy is to keep the enemy from
moving north, one of the tactics might be

178
00:09:13.825 --> 00:09:19.260
let's take out the bridges 40 kilometers
from here, from here, 40 kilometers out,

179
00:09:19.260 --> 00:09:23.330
let's wipe out all the bridges, so
that they can't easily move north.

180
00:09:23.330 --> 00:09:28.750
Now, if later you learn that the enemy
has actually moved 100 clicks away,

181
00:09:28.750 --> 00:09:30.640
or 200 kilometers away,

182
00:09:30.640 --> 00:09:34.849
then taking out bridges 40 miles from
here is no longer a viable tactic.

183
00:09:36.200 --> 00:09:41.240
If you understand the strategy,
keep the enemy from moving north.

184
00:09:41.240 --> 00:09:44.380
And you can reorient yourself
to that strategy all the time.

time, a commitment to this idea of

not understanding how the impacts of your

potential ideas can be articulated

00:28:14.410 --> 00:28:17.070

00:29:15.620 --> 00:29:17.870

00:29:17.870 --> 00:29:22.480

activities you need to go, right?

525
00:27:44.920 --> 00:27:50.500
So as an example in change management,
you could build in the workflow for

526
00:27:50.500 --> 00:27:53.710
who can request it and
who can approve it, right?

527
00:27:53.710 --> 00:27:58.780
So if I am registered as an approver of
changes, then when it gets to that part of

528
00:27:58.780 --> 00:28:03.780
the workflow, I'm able to go in there and
click the lever that says, yes, I approve.

529
00:28:03.780 --> 00:28:05.380
If I don't have that permission,

530
00:28:05.380 --> 00:28:09.500
if I don't have that role, I'm not able
to click that lever to say it's approved.

531
00:28:09.500 --> 00:28:13.360
So you can kinda build in governance even
within your tool sets which is a great

532
00:28:13.360 --> 00:28:14.660
trick to have.

533
00:28:14.660 --> 00:28:16.310
If you can pull that one off,
it's awesome.

534
00:28:17.360 --> 00:28:18.530
All right.

535
00:28:20.940 --> 00:28:26.390
Quality as a means of
Governance is pretty darn cool.

536
00:28:26.390 --> 00:28:27.050
Right?

537
00:28:27.050 --> 00:28:31.540
If you're promising deliver at 99.9% and
you are only delivering

538
00:28:31.540 --> 00:28:36.150
at 96%,
you are governing some behaviors there.

539
00:28:36.150 --> 00:28:40.490
You are pointing out very transparently,
you are not meeting the grade.

540
00:28:40.490 --> 00:28:41.070
Right?

541
00:28:41.070 --> 00:28:44.830
So it's a way, again, to keep people
motivated in the right direction

542
00:28:44.830 --> 00:28:47.170
to govern the way they
are going to behave.

543
00:28:47.170 --> 00:28:50.180
Measurement itself in
the improvement cycle itself

544
00:28:50.180 --> 00:28:52.240
is a means of governance, right?

545
00:28:52.240 --> 00:28:55.920
So quality governance can be done
through this constant cycle of

546
00:28:55.920 --> 00:28:56.970
continual improvement.

547
00:28:56.970 --> 00:29:01.390
And that's what's shown here, the Deming
cycle, the plan, do, check, act.

548
00:29:01.390 --> 00:29:03.740
As relates to governance,
that's what you're doing.

549
00:29:03.740 --> 00:29:06.350
You're planning for appropriate behavior.

550
00:29:06.350 --> 00:29:07.740
People behave.

551
00:29:07.740 --> 00:29:09.430
You check on their behavior.

552
00:29:09.430 --> 00:29:11.010
If it's good, great.

553
00:29:11.010 --> 00:29:13.130
If it's not, you act, right.

554
00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:17.220
So, even as it relates to governments,
the plan do check

555
00:29:18.620 --> 00:29:23.380
act cycle otherwise known as
the Deming cycle is a key motivator,

556
00:29:23.380 --> 00:29:27.410
a key methodology, if you will,
just to make sure you're going right.

557
00:29:27.410 --> 00:29:33.010
Again, consider again acceptable use
policy for people using a laptop.

558
00:29:33.010 --> 00:29:36.120
Depending on the organization,
maybe you can't have a thumb drive.

559
00:29:36.120 --> 00:29:39.420
So acceptable use policy is don't
bring your thumb drive to work.

560
00:29:39.420 --> 00:29:42.750
Don't even put a thumb
drive in that USB port.

561
00:29:42.750 --> 00:29:43.430
Don't even do it.

562
00:29:43.430 --> 00:29:44.030
Alright.

563
00:29:44.030 --> 00:29:45.540
Other company's are a bit more lax.

564
00:29:45.540 --> 00:29:47.580
Right.
You can do that.

565
00:29:47.580 --> 00:29:49.150
That's governance behavior.

566
00:29:49.150 --> 00:29:52.010
Now how would you monitor that behavior?

567
00:29:52.010 --> 00:29:53.540
Well maybe you'd do it electronically.

568
00:29:53.540 --> 00:29:55.190
Maybe its scouts honor.

569
00:29:55.190 --> 00:29:58.720
Maybe you'd search people with
a wand when they come in.

570
00:29:58.720 --> 00:30:01.560
They have USB drive you'd confiscate it,
and they'd lose it.

571
00:30:02.800 --> 00:30:06.500
Again, you see the behaviors
here are advertised.

572
00:30:07.540 --> 00:30:09.250
They are monitored, and

573
00:30:09.250 --> 00:30:12.870
perhaps consequences in that
particular cycle of work.

574
00:30:12.870 --> 00:30:17.285
>> I had a manager once, he used to say
all the time, under promise, over deliver.

575
00:30:17.285 --> 00:30:19.486
Over-promise, under-deliver.

576
00:30:19.486 --> 00:30:22.140
Under-promise, then over-deliver.

577
00:30:22.140 --> 00:30:23.190
>> I'm sorry.
Good points.

578
00:30:23.190 --> 00:30:24.168
>> How do you react to that?

579
00:30:24.168 --> 00:30:26.864
>> Under-promise, over-deliver.

580
00:30:26.864 --> 00:30:28.900
Yeah, I understand that tactic.

581
00:30:28.900 --> 00:30:30.070
I do.
I appreciate that.

582
00:30:30.070 --> 00:30:32.640
I think it's often so

583
00:30:32.640 --> 00:30:37.460
dangerous to do it the other way,
where you over promised and under deliver.

584
00:30:37.460 --> 00:30:40.260
Because that's so slippery of a slope and

585
00:30:40.260 --> 00:30:44.360
so disappointing, your expectations
are high, the approvals are low.

586
00:30:44.360 --> 00:30:47.570
That there's so
much danger in over promising

587
00:30:47.570 --> 00:30:51.700
that I would go to the other side of that
ball myself, under promise a little bit.

588
00:30:51.700 --> 00:30:56.190
In the optimum, straight up world,
you always predict where you're going and

589
00:30:56.190 --> 00:30:58.480
you deliver just as you promised.

590
00:30:58.480 --> 00:31:00.030
That's the best place to move.

591
00:31:00.030 --> 00:31:01.660
I think if you under promise and

592
00:31:01.660 --> 00:31:06.090
over deliver, that's awesome in
terms of expectation management.

593
00:31:06.090 --> 00:31:07.438
But they could also get used to that.

594
00:31:07.438 --> 00:31:08.500
>> Mm-hm, Mm-hm, Mm-hm.

595
00:31:08.500 --> 00:31:09.690
>> Right?
And they realize,

596
00:31:09.690 --> 00:31:10.860
well that's what you do every time.

597
00:31:10.860 --> 00:31:14.020
So then they start squeezing you even
more the next requirements round.

598
00:31:14.020 --> 00:31:15.670
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I guess.
>> I guess there's a payoff either

599
00:31:15.670 --> 00:31:16.260
way you go.

600
00:31:16.260 --> 00:31:16.790
>> Yeah, there is.

601
00:31:16.790 --> 00:31:19.450
>> I think in the perfect world,
you're just completely transparent and

602
00:31:19.450 --> 00:31:22.390
completely aware of what
you're capable of doing.

603
00:31:22.390 --> 00:31:22.980
Right?

604
00:31:22.980 --> 00:31:26.840
And you're willing to adjust if those
capabilities are falling short and

605
00:31:26.840 --> 00:31:29.650
you're transparent about falling short.

606
00:31:29.650 --> 00:31:30.740
So I think an honest approach.

607
00:31:30.740 --> 00:31:35.704
I think generally speaking, and
certainly preaches this as well,

608
00:31:35.704 --> 00:31:41.120
that being transparent Is in of
itself in improvement, right?

609
00:31:41.120 --> 00:31:43.990
Being transparent in another
word you are not afraid to show

610
00:31:43.990 --> 00:31:47.820
that we are monitoring ourselves and
by the way we fell short this month.

611
00:31:47.820 --> 00:31:52.900
We are only at 96%, you wouldn't have even
known that customer if we hadn't told you,

612
00:31:52.900 --> 00:31:55.470
so that's building trust even integrity.

613
00:31:55.470 --> 00:31:56.500
>> It is, it's integrity.

614
00:31:56.500 --> 00:32:00.180
You're building trust and integrity just
by being transparent about it, right?

615
00:32:00.180 --> 00:32:04.340
So I think in the end, I think in the end
what you'll wanna do is be as clearly

616
00:32:04.340 --> 00:32:07.050
articulate as you can be
about your capabilities and

617
00:32:07.050 --> 00:32:10.240
what you want to deliver and what
the constraints are for delivering that.

618
00:32:10.240 --> 00:32:11.850
Identify the risks.

619
00:32:11.850 --> 00:32:14.220
Do that transparently and
when you get there and

620
00:32:14.220 --> 00:32:18.460
you have fallen short of the goals, be
transparent about that, fallen or short,

621
00:32:18.460 --> 00:32:20.140
say yup we're gonna try and
do more better.

622
00:32:20.140 --> 00:32:22.600
And therefore building the integrity,
building the trust and

623
00:32:22.600 --> 00:32:25.320
have an ongoing relationship
is probably better.

624
00:32:25.320 --> 00:32:28.210
So that's a whole lot about governance,
I'll get a little piece

625
00:32:28.210 --> 00:32:31.360
about some organizational structures
to help with this governance but

626
00:32:31.360 --> 00:32:33.640
we need to take that
up in another episode.

627
00:32:33.640 --> 00:32:38.300
Terry, once again, fantastic, so
much information and it's great.

628
00:32:38.300 --> 00:32:41.890
And this is ITIL MALC,
governance across the life cycle.

629
00:32:41.890 --> 00:32:45.140
Make sure you watch it as many times as
you need to, repetition's good for you.

630
00:32:45.140 --> 00:32:49.530
And also there's all kinds of
content in the ITIL MALC series.

631
00:32:49.530 --> 00:32:51.370
Watch them all, you'll be glad you did.

632
00:32:51.370 --> 00:32:54.870
And thank you for
watching ITProTV Remember,

633
00:32:54.870 --> 00:32:56.500
a good IT pro is always learning.

634
00:32:56.500 --> 00:32:57.300
I'm Zach Memis.

635
00:32:57.300 --> 00:32:58.120
>> I'm Terry Decker.

636
00:32:58.120 --> 00:32:59.110
>> And we'll see you soon.

637
00:32:59.110 --> 00:33:06.374
[MUSIC]

638
00:33:06.374 --> 00:33:13.760
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide focus on how organizational structure can help support IT Service Management.
episodes.title: Organization Across the Lifecycle
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:03.495
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.495 --> 00:00:06.047
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.047 --> 00:00:08.462
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.462 --> 00:00:12.160
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.160 --> 00:00:17.260
>> Hello again and thank you for choosing
ITProTV helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.260 --> 00:00:19.680
I'm your host Zach Memos
as we continue on.

7
00:00:19.680 --> 00:00:25.440
With ITIL Malc and this is gonna be
organization across the lifecycle and

8
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:29.180
we're gonna learn more about that from
Mr Terry Decker, who's right here.

9
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:29.905
Good, good guy.

10
00:00:29.905 --> 00:00:32.110
>> [LAUGH] Thank you very much Zach.

11
00:00:32.110 --> 00:00:34.590
Happy to be here as always,
appreciate the enthusiasm and

12
00:00:34.590 --> 00:00:37.165
endorsement of my expert credentials here.

13
00:00:37.165 --> 00:00:39.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> Looking at

14
00:00:39.020 --> 00:00:40.320
organization across the lifecycle.

15
00:00:40.320 --> 00:00:45.030
First of all, to set the stage here,
ITIL is not a best practice for

16
00:00:45.030 --> 00:00:46.870
organizational development.

17
00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:52.500
Okay, now that said, organization
development could play a very key

18
00:00:52.500 --> 00:00:55.810
success factor in your adopting and

19
00:00:55.810 --> 00:00:59.790
implementing IT service management
capabilities across your organization.

20
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:01.120
We need to look at it.

21
00:01:01.120 --> 00:01:04.850
It's not that ITIL is telling you, you
must organize your organization this way.

22
00:01:04.850 --> 00:01:07.690
Or here's the best practice for
how to set up your organization.

23
00:01:07.690 --> 00:01:11.330
Organizations vary in size,
complexity all the time.

24
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:15.550
So ITIL really couldn't get
into under the hood in details

25
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:16.870
of organizational structure.

26
00:01:16.870 --> 00:01:19.040
So we're gonna keep it
to 5,000 foot view and

27
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:21.230
have a look at organizational
structures and

28
00:01:21.230 --> 00:01:26.240
how they could impact, either positively
or negatively, your implementation

29
00:01:26.240 --> 00:01:29.420
of IT service management across
the organization or across the life cycle.

30
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:30.030
So let's have a look.

31
00:01:30.030 --> 00:01:32.510
I want to focus on these
bullets a little bit.

32
00:01:32.510 --> 00:01:33.980
I tend not to read the bullets, but

33
00:01:33.980 --> 00:01:36.240
there's some really good
ones here worth focusing on.

34
00:01:36.240 --> 00:01:40.390
This first one, adoption of service
management to service delivery.

35
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:46.050
So adopting a service management approach
instead of a solutions design approach,

36
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:48.480
or a system delivery approach.

37
00:01:48.480 --> 00:01:51.140
Designing a service management approach

38
00:01:51.140 --> 00:01:55.630
to service delivery could mean
a new vision for your organization.

39
00:01:55.630 --> 00:01:57.160
All right,
let me put this a different way.

40
00:01:57.160 --> 00:02:00.180
Are you practicing ITIL now
anywhere in your organization?

41
00:02:00.180 --> 00:02:02.240
Is it just an idea in someone's head?

42
00:02:02.240 --> 00:02:03.495
They think it might be a good idea.

43
00:02:03.495 --> 00:02:07.860
Right, depending where you are on this
development model or this maturity model

44
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:11.840
toward IT service management,
you might be at the very beginning.

45
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:14.850
And if you're at the very beginning,
then obviously it's a sea change, right.

46
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:19.000
It's a big change to move toward the
adoption of a service management approach.

47
00:02:20.340 --> 00:02:26.470
If it is a sea change or a new vision,
you're probably gonna get some

48
00:02:26.470 --> 00:02:30.720
resistance, or it's gonna require
some organizational change.

49
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:36.510
You got to reorient people towards the new
behaviors that you're trying to do.

50
00:02:36.510 --> 00:02:40.200
Related to governess which we just
talked about in the previous episode is

51
00:02:40.200 --> 00:02:45.130
this organizational aspect of getting
the right people in the right roles.

52
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:48.240
And putting them in the right amount
of tension with each other and

53
00:02:48.240 --> 00:02:49.790
by tension I mean positive tension.

54
00:02:49.790 --> 00:02:51.860
They work well against each other.

55
00:02:51.860 --> 00:02:54.420
They work well with each other, right.

56
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:56.820
Have change management,
release management built.

57
00:02:56.820 --> 00:02:58.120
Have incident and problem.

58
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:01.330
They work with each other and
they have tension between each other.

59
00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:04.640
It's a positive tension, a right kind
of friction between them, right?

60
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:08.950
So the introduction of IT service
management is necessarily introduction

61
00:03:08.950 --> 00:03:10.530
of new processes.

62
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:14.410
The introduction, the processes is
necessarily a change in behavior,

63
00:03:14.410 --> 00:03:17.280
people are gonna have to
follow the processes, right?

64
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:21.490
So in that going to the bullets,
high performance organizations.

65
00:03:21.490 --> 00:03:24.330
This is a blanket statement,
a very generic statement.

66
00:03:24.330 --> 00:03:29.580
High performance organizations tend to
drift toward decentralized management.

67
00:03:29.580 --> 00:03:35.200
What they're trying to say there is that
ample sampling of delegation of authority.

68
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:38.510
Allowing the right people to make
the right decision at the right level

69
00:03:38.510 --> 00:03:41.630
tends to be a more high
performing organization.

70
00:03:41.630 --> 00:03:44.290
I believe it's called right the ship.

71
00:03:45.440 --> 00:03:50.270
A Navy commander of a nuclear
submarine wrote a book and

72
00:03:50.270 --> 00:03:53.520
his approach, and you might think
the Navy very hierarchical.

73
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:56.430
The commander says jump,
everyone says how high, right?

74
00:03:56.430 --> 00:04:00.260
That's the typical way maybe
a stereotypical way to consider

75
00:04:00.260 --> 00:04:05.020
a military regime, if you will or and
obviously there is a top down command

76
00:04:05.020 --> 00:04:09.400
structure where it does flow downstream
when the orders are passed down.

77
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:13.070
But what this commander did even
within that structure of hierarchy,

78
00:04:13.070 --> 00:04:16.400
he delegated a lot of
authority throughout the ship.

79
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:20.770
And expected people to be able to think
on their feet in certain situations, and

80
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:24.590
he authorized them to think on
their feet in certain situations.

81
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:30.060
So he gave the rules of engagement and
allow them to be decisive, right?

82
00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:31.410
So how empowering is that?

83
00:04:31.410 --> 00:04:33.810
The user or
the person I should say the user,

84
00:04:33.810 --> 00:04:37.550
the person feels like they have
more at stake in this game.

85
00:04:37.550 --> 00:04:39.600
They feel like they're valued more.

86
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:43.850
They're part of the solution,
not just being, not just following orders.

87
00:04:43.850 --> 00:04:47.420
Now again, this commander didn't
break down the command structure.

88
00:04:47.420 --> 00:04:49.230
He just opened it up in a way,

89
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:52.340
where authority was given
at the appropriate levels.

90
00:04:52.340 --> 00:04:55.710
And over and over again,
in the various exercises they had,

91
00:04:55.710 --> 00:05:01.120
in competitions with other
submarine commanders and whatnot.

92
00:05:01.120 --> 00:05:04.720
They continually outperformed
everyone in the Navy, right?

93
00:05:04.720 --> 00:05:08.030
So just an example, again,
not one that ITIL cites.

94
00:05:08.030 --> 00:05:11.690
But this idea that a high performance
organization tends to be one

95
00:05:11.690 --> 00:05:15.080
that decentralizes the authority matrix,
right?

96
00:05:15.080 --> 00:05:17.850
It's not all just top-driven and down.

97
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:19.290
So it resonates with me.

98
00:05:19.290 --> 00:05:22.520
I know I work in those
environments more effectively

99
00:05:22.520 --> 00:05:24.340
than I do in the top-down approach.

100
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:27.690
Again, you're not destroying
the structure of hierarchy,

101
00:05:27.690 --> 00:05:31.880
you're just expanding the authority matrix
in a way to make it more effective and

102
00:05:31.880 --> 00:05:36.210
get more buy-in and more, and actually,
better performance on the ground.

103
00:05:36.210 --> 00:05:38.100
>> Delegation of duties
to the right people.

104
00:05:38.100 --> 00:05:39.440
>> That's right.

105
00:05:39.440 --> 00:05:42.550
The following, as we look at this
following slide we're gonna look at

106
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:45.750
some of these organizational
dynamics that could play out.

107
00:05:45.750 --> 00:05:50.920
Again, I don't want even now I don't want
to think that this is stage of evolution.

108
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:54.080
That you're a better organization if
you get to the top, cuz different

109
00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:57.280
organizations operate in different ways
and ITIL is certainly not saying that

110
00:05:57.280 --> 00:06:02.580
either that you must evolve toward
service through collaboration, right.

111
00:06:02.580 --> 00:06:06.300
They're not saying that, directly.

112
00:06:06.300 --> 00:06:07.220
They're suggesting it.

113
00:06:07.220 --> 00:06:10.220
And highly suggestive that,
the more decentralized you are,

114
00:06:10.220 --> 00:06:13.160
potentially the higher
performing you will become.

115
00:06:13.160 --> 00:06:15.000
Again, not prescribing.

116
00:06:15.000 --> 00:06:18.000
But as you're looking on the exam,
I think if you look on the exam.

117
00:06:18.000 --> 00:06:22.749
You're gonna find instances
where this dysfunction of

118
00:06:22.749 --> 00:06:27.440
having not enough control,
is causing problems.

119
00:06:27.440 --> 00:06:29.950
And then the dysfunction of
having too much control and

120
00:06:29.950 --> 00:06:32.130
not delegating enough is causing problems.

Functions, we had service desk as
a function, we had technical management,

354
00:17:57.020 --> 00:18:02.498
application management, and IT operations
management as the four primary functions.

355
00:18:02.498 --> 00:18:07.080
And we described the functions as a group
of people with special skills and tools.

356
00:18:07.080 --> 00:18:09.908
And as I described functions, I also said,

357
00:18:09.908 --> 00:18:14.504
remember ITIL is not an organizational
design best practice, right?

358
00:18:14.504 --> 00:18:18.498
They're not, but they have described that
you need these four skill sets working in

359
00:18:18.498 --> 00:18:20.000
your organization.

360
00:18:20.000 --> 00:18:21.560
These are the kind of people you need.

361
00:18:21.560 --> 00:18:23.099
Now, let's say you work in
a real small organization.

362
00:18:24.130 --> 00:18:28.090
Maybe you are a person that
exists in all four functions.

363
00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:30.610
You are the help desk technician.

364
00:18:30.610 --> 00:18:33.540
You are the technical manager that knows
everything there is to know about all

365
00:18:33.540 --> 00:18:34.900
the servers in your environment.

366
00:18:34.900 --> 00:18:36.350
You are also the application manager,

367
00:18:36.350 --> 00:18:39.150
knows everything about
the application your business uses.

368
00:18:39.150 --> 00:18:42.070
And you manage the backups and
restores for these things everyday.

369
00:18:43.100 --> 00:18:44.040
>> Many hats.

370
00:18:44.040 --> 00:18:44.930
>> Many hats.

371
00:18:44.930 --> 00:18:47.870
So you, okay, so
you maybe only wear two of those hats and

372
00:18:47.870 --> 00:18:51.890
you have you know an IT
department of 15 people, right?

373
00:18:51.890 --> 00:18:54.060
So you see how this can scale up.

374
00:18:54.060 --> 00:18:58.560
Ultimately, you're going to scale
out of these functional areas and

375
00:18:58.560 --> 00:19:01.220
may have to departmentalize things, right?

376
00:19:01.220 --> 00:19:04.990
In a large organization you might be able
to definitely have the structure where

377
00:19:04.990 --> 00:19:06.820
there's the technical management team.

378
00:19:06.820 --> 00:19:11.240
They have 40 people in the technical
management team, they do infrastructure.

379
00:19:11.240 --> 00:19:13.920
We have the application team,
the application management team,

380
00:19:13.920 --> 00:19:16.460
they have 20 people and
they work over in applications.

381
00:19:16.460 --> 00:19:19.820
We have the IT operations team,
there's 60 people there.

382
00:19:19.820 --> 00:19:23.240
And we have 28 people on the service desk,
right?

383
00:19:23.240 --> 00:19:24.380
That sort of thing.

384
00:19:24.380 --> 00:19:30.340
And you actually name the functions
by the way ITIL calls them out.

385
00:19:30.340 --> 00:19:32.720
You have organizational departments,
if you will.

386
00:19:32.720 --> 00:19:36.900
So this departmentalization,
this idea of departmentalization

387
00:19:36.900 --> 00:19:41.090
is a method of governance as we
talked about in the previous episode.

388
00:19:41.090 --> 00:19:45.410
It's also a method of just understanding
how you build in these interfaces.

389
00:19:45.410 --> 00:19:48.850
So if you're marching toward a pretty
picture, if you look at the graphic here,

390
00:19:50.050 --> 00:19:54.770
if you're marching toward a pretty picture
with the pretty organizational silos

391
00:19:54.770 --> 00:20:00.030
completely interfaced horizontally
in a matrix type of organization,

392
00:20:00.030 --> 00:20:01.520
if that's what your goal is,

393
00:20:01.520 --> 00:20:04.580
then a necessary step is probably
gonna be some departmentalization.

394
00:20:05.660 --> 00:20:08.130
Again, not gonna belabor this deeply.

395
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:12.750
ITIL does not position itself as
an organizational design best practice.

396
00:20:12.750 --> 00:20:17.580
But as you take the exam, be looking for
those opportunities to identify

397
00:20:17.580 --> 00:20:23.430
are these functions represented, and
are they represented authoritatively?

398
00:20:23.430 --> 00:20:27.990
So even if it's a small organization where
you have one person who is the director of

399
00:20:27.990 --> 00:20:31.190
everything in IT, and he has to make
all the decisions about technical,

400
00:20:31.190 --> 00:20:36.150
applications, day to day operations,
and service desk, he manages it all.

401
00:20:36.150 --> 00:20:40.480
If that particularly scenario plays
out that way and there are things

402
00:20:40.480 --> 00:20:45.210
falling over, it might be an opportunity
to delegate and get more resources.

403
00:20:45.210 --> 00:20:46.290
That's what we're looking at.

404
00:20:46.290 --> 00:20:48.818
Is it scalable enough?

405
00:20:48.818 --> 00:20:54.480
All right, so as we look at the graphic
here regarding organizational design.

406
00:20:54.480 --> 00:20:57.900
Again, ITIL is not a best practice for
organizational design.

407
00:20:57.900 --> 00:20:59.460
As you're trying to consider the question,

408
00:20:59.460 --> 00:21:03.090
the departmentalization,
functions can be part of that.

409
00:21:03.090 --> 00:21:07.260
You might decide to divide and
conquer by product, right?

410
00:21:07.260 --> 00:21:09.860
Maybe you offer three core products.

411
00:21:09.860 --> 00:21:10.860
Imagine a bank.
I am not sure

412
00:21:10.860 --> 00:21:14.270
banks structure themselves this way,
I am totally making this up, all right?

413
00:21:14.270 --> 00:21:16.390
But this kind of resonates
with me as an example.

414
00:21:16.390 --> 00:21:18.650
You might have a commercial
loan department,

415
00:21:20.060 --> 00:21:22.580
you might have a consumer loan department.

416
00:21:22.580 --> 00:21:27.380
Maybe both of those loan departments
report to a single person for loans.

417
00:21:28.540 --> 00:21:30.670
So, I can kinda see that
organizational structure.

418
00:21:30.670 --> 00:21:32.960
Imagine organizational chart
looks like that, right?

419
00:21:32.960 --> 00:21:36.240
And then you have the consumer
banking piece, not the loans, but

420
00:21:36.240 --> 00:21:38.440
the consumer banking side of it.

421
00:21:38.440 --> 00:21:41.300
And then you might have the financial
management side of it as different

422
00:21:41.300 --> 00:21:43.250
business concerns.

423
00:21:43.250 --> 00:21:48.270
So that's breaking it down by the market
space that you're playing in.

424
00:21:48.270 --> 00:21:51.690
You're playing in the load department,
you're playing in the banking department,

425
00:21:51.690 --> 00:21:54.380
you're playing in financial
services department, right?

426
00:21:54.380 --> 00:21:58.290
That could be one way to departmentalize,
right?

427
00:21:58.290 --> 00:22:01.350
So, as IT would respond to that,

428
00:22:01.350 --> 00:22:06.380
does IT respond to that with
a separate IT department for each one?

429
00:22:06.380 --> 00:22:10.070
Does IT respond to that with a single
IT department that serves them all?

430
00:22:11.100 --> 00:22:13.230
Some hybrid of that?

431
00:22:13.230 --> 00:22:15.910
Again, ITIL is not answering
that question, and, honestly,

432
00:22:15.910 --> 00:22:21.320
they're not going to be diving into on
an exam the intricacies of such questions.

433
00:22:21.320 --> 00:22:24.720
They don't pretend to be
an organizational best practice.

434
00:22:24.720 --> 00:22:29.163
But can you get a sense for how the lack
of organizational sign could affect

435
00:22:29.163 --> 00:22:31.705
your success in delivering IT services?

436
00:22:31.705 --> 00:22:33.880
That' s where you try to connect the dots.

437
00:22:33.880 --> 00:22:37.539
As this happens on the exam,
they will be more explicit,

438
00:22:37.539 --> 00:22:40.070
not trying to ferret out some nuances.

439
00:22:40.070 --> 00:22:44.170
They will be explicit about the effects
of organizational design on any given

440
00:22:44.170 --> 00:22:47.409
scenario and ask you to say
what would you do differently.

441
00:22:47.409 --> 00:22:51.020
And the primary difference you
would make would be beginning with

442
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:52.960
the delegation of responsibilities.

443
00:22:52.960 --> 00:22:55.410
Assigning an ownership to a process.

444
00:22:55.410 --> 00:22:58.606
Assigning an ownership to
the entire stage, potentially.

445
00:22:58.606 --> 00:23:02.480
Okay, all right, good.

446
00:23:03.850 --> 00:23:06.480
So moving forward through some more
organizational design factors.

447
00:23:06.480 --> 00:23:08.880
You see here what is
the appropriate design?

448
00:23:08.880 --> 00:23:12.280
This is suggesting,
we saw these five stages earlier,

449
00:23:12.280 --> 00:23:16.130
the network, directive, delegation,
coordination, and collaboration.

450
00:23:16.130 --> 00:23:17.950
You see them on the right side here.

451
00:23:21.150 --> 00:23:23.870
Make it a process design.

452
00:23:25.320 --> 00:23:29.078
If you delegate processes
to appropriate owners, and

453
00:23:29.078 --> 00:23:34.144
then attach the ownership of those
processes to the appropriate stages in

454
00:23:34.144 --> 00:23:39.209
the organization, you'll tend to find,
again, you'll tend to find,

455
00:23:39.209 --> 00:23:44.137
that strategy decisions are gonna
be upper management and executive.

456
00:23:44.137 --> 00:23:48.063
So, more technical management and
application management are gonna be

457
00:23:48.063 --> 00:23:52.261
the functions that provide the people
that can show up at strategy meetings.

458
00:23:52.261 --> 00:23:55.829
Whereas IT operations management
is more The day to day grind,

459
00:23:55.829 --> 00:23:59.127
turn the crane get this thing out,
back up those servers,

460
00:23:59.127 --> 00:24:02.490
restore those servers,
fix the printer queue, right?

461
00:24:02.490 --> 00:24:04.210
That day to day maintenance of things,

462
00:24:04.210 --> 00:24:08.140
the fill the generators up, keep the
lights on in the data center, etc, right?

463
00:24:10.490 --> 00:24:13.620
It could be that geographic
factor affect this,

464
00:24:13.620 --> 00:24:16.800
that you have distinct
geographic locations.

465
00:24:16.800 --> 00:24:19.870
There each different business unit and
they are different geographically

466
00:24:21.480 --> 00:24:25.340
provided a appropriate level of
collaboration across those multiple

467
00:24:25.340 --> 00:24:29.500
geographies to make it work, okay.

468
00:24:29.500 --> 00:24:33.389
Now again, how this is equate to at
overall structure you see here that

469
00:24:34.480 --> 00:24:36.560
you have your strategy.

470
00:24:36.560 --> 00:24:39.800
What you're trying to get done,
you have a departmental structure.

471
00:24:39.800 --> 00:24:43.520
This is happening outside the business,
I'm sorry, outside of IT.

472
00:24:43.520 --> 00:24:47.770
The business is making these
decisions to a large part, right?

473
00:24:47.770 --> 00:24:50.850
And you have your key processes,
these are key business processes.

474
00:24:52.100 --> 00:24:57.685
And then you associate the organizational
structure with those processes, right.

475
00:24:57.685 --> 00:25:01.805
Of course, identifying the right people,
that's where the delegation comes,

476
00:25:01.805 --> 00:25:05.950
giving them the right roles and
responsibilities, and then keep score.

477
00:25:05.950 --> 00:25:06.450
How you doing, right?

478
00:25:07.750 --> 00:25:10.280
I'm supposed to design
the change management process or

479
00:25:10.280 --> 00:25:13.780
instant management process, Zach's over
there designing the problem management

480
00:25:13.780 --> 00:25:16.780
process, how good's the problem
answering process going, Zach?

481
00:25:16.780 --> 00:25:19.640
I look at the measurements,
doesn't look like you're doing too good.

482
00:25:19.640 --> 00:25:21.790
Zach calls to me,
hey I saw your instant management metrics,

483
00:25:21.790 --> 00:25:23.390
they're not looking too good,
either, right.

484
00:25:23.390 --> 00:25:28.930
So measurement can be a way
to govern the success of me,

485
00:25:28.930 --> 00:25:30.380
as an instant management process owner.

486
00:25:30.380 --> 00:25:33.710
It could be a way to measure Zach
as a problem management owner.

487
00:25:33.710 --> 00:25:35.750
Are we going to get these measurements up?

488
00:25:35.750 --> 00:25:36.520
Get the idea there.

489
00:25:36.520 --> 00:25:40.350
So, ultimately measurement and
performance are gonna play in.

490
00:25:40.350 --> 00:25:44.110
And, hopefully, you come up with
an appropriate improvement scheme.

491
00:25:44.110 --> 00:25:49.660
And training and orientation scheme to
lift up theses processes from the ground.

492
00:25:49.660 --> 00:25:52.860
And make them effective across
the organization, okay.

493
00:25:52.860 --> 00:25:54.430
>> Checks and balances.

494
00:25:54.430 --> 00:25:58.240
That's organizational considerations
in a nutshell regarding ITIL.

495
00:25:59.330 --> 00:26:04.310
I highly recommend that as you
look at the sample papers look

496
00:26:04.310 --> 00:26:09.550
at how they focus on organizational,
and validate that it's important,

497
00:26:09.550 --> 00:26:13.580
it's not to be scoffed at but
it's not deep, either.

498
00:26:13.580 --> 00:26:18.560
You're not gonna go deep diving into
the organizational aspects of design.

499
00:26:18.560 --> 00:26:23.030
If you want to implement ITEL, if you
want to adopt ITEL into an organization,

500
00:26:23.030 --> 00:26:26.830
also understand that
it's not a trivial thing.

501
00:26:26.830 --> 00:26:30.250
That's the real key thing
that will show up on an exam.

502
00:26:30.250 --> 00:26:34.390
If you wanna adopt Itil,
it's not a two month project.

503
00:26:34.390 --> 00:26:38.240
It's not, okay, get back to me in three
months and we'll be an ITIL shop, right?

504
00:26:38.240 --> 00:26:40.020
It's not that kind of deal.

505
00:26:40.020 --> 00:26:43.930
It's the kind of deal that requires
a lot of thought, a lot of delegation,

506
00:26:43.930 --> 00:26:47.020
a lot of organizational considerations.

507
00:26:47.020 --> 00:26:49.560
Potentially even organizational changes.

508
00:26:49.560 --> 00:26:51.380
That's what the overarching themes of,

509
00:26:51.380 --> 00:26:54.830
how you would approach the organizational
challenges of IT service management.

510
00:26:54.830 --> 00:26:58.170
So in addition to following these
episodes along from my lecture,

511
00:26:58.170 --> 00:27:00.960
the importance of self-study
cannot be overstated.

512
00:27:00.960 --> 00:27:05.170
So please take a look at the exercises and
activities that are available for you.

513
00:27:05.170 --> 00:27:09.690
In the episode files link up above, click
on that, and you'll find various things

514
00:27:09.690 --> 00:27:13.100
that will reinforce the learning
objectives that we just went through.

515
00:27:13.100 --> 00:27:16.950
One of them is called Service Strategy,
the Logical Organization Structure for

516
00:27:16.950 --> 00:27:18.220
an IT Service Provider, right.

517
00:27:18.220 --> 00:27:22.430
And then there's another one called
Service Operational Functions,

518
00:27:22.430 --> 00:27:24.000
Service Operations Functions.

519
00:27:24.000 --> 00:27:27.940
So it'll look into those functions and
describe them meaningfully.

520
00:27:27.940 --> 00:27:31.718
And then there's another one
called selecting service delivery,

521
00:27:31.718 --> 00:27:37.870
right strategies, is how we go about
appropriating the appropriate strategy for

522
00:27:37.870 --> 00:27:40.380
the given service delivery
module that we're talking about.

523
00:27:40.380 --> 00:27:42.410
So, have a look at those exercises.

524
00:27:42.410 --> 00:27:43.730
Reinforce that learning.

525
00:27:43.730 --> 00:27:47.520
Come visit the forum, ask your questions
there, about that subject matter,

526
00:27:47.520 --> 00:27:49.770
or any subject matter related to ITIL.

527
00:27:49.770 --> 00:27:51.590
You'll find experts there to respond.

528
00:27:51.590 --> 00:27:54.190
Other peers, other students learning this.

529
00:27:54.190 --> 00:27:56.100
Come to the forum, interact.

530
00:27:56.100 --> 00:27:57.000
And enjoy your studies.

531
00:27:57.000 --> 00:27:59.020
>> Come to the ITIL island and
stay a while.

532
00:27:59.020 --> 00:28:01.040
>> That's right.
>> Terry, great job, great job.

533
00:28:01.040 --> 00:28:03.640
ITIL MALC,
organization across the life cycle.

534
00:28:03.640 --> 00:28:06.470
There is so
much content in the ITIL MALC library, so

535
00:28:06.470 --> 00:28:07.980
many videos to watch, watch them all.

536
00:28:07.980 --> 00:28:09.860
You'll be glad you did.

537
00:28:09.860 --> 00:28:11.600
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

538
00:28:11.600 --> 00:28:14.390
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

539
00:28:14.390 --> 00:28:15.450
I'm Zack Memos.

540
00:28:15.450 --> 00:28:16.230
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

541
00:28:16.230 --> 00:28:18.857
>> And we will see you very soon.

542
00:28:18.857 --> 00:28:24.833
[MUSIC]

543
00:28:24.833 --> 00:28:32.030
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.title: The Importance of Measurement
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.508
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.508 --> 00:00:08.276
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.276 --> 00:00:11.902
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:11.902 --> 00:00:13.720
>> Hello again and thank you for

5
00:00:13.720 --> 00:00:17.380
joining us ITProTV helping
you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.380 --> 00:00:21.410
I'm you host Zack Memos,
as we continue on with ITIL MALC.

7
00:00:21.410 --> 00:00:24.230
This is the importance of measurement.

8
00:00:24.230 --> 00:00:27.250
And I know a guy who can tell us all

9
00:00:27.250 --> 00:00:30.901
about this because he's an ITIL
expert Terry Decker right over here.

10
00:00:30.901 --> 00:00:31.407
Hi Terry?
>> You know what?

11
00:00:31.407 --> 00:00:34.110
And I know a guy who's listened to enough

12
00:00:34.110 --> 00:00:37.490
lectures for me that he can answer some
of these questions about the importance

13
00:00:37.490 --> 00:00:38.080
of measurements.

14
00:00:38.080 --> 00:00:39.810
So I'm gonna pick on Zach a little bit.

15
00:00:39.810 --> 00:00:42.100
Zack why measure?

16
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:48.450
>> So you have an exact,
your using data as opposed to conjecture.

17
00:00:48.450 --> 00:00:49.230
>> That's right.

18
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:50.800
It's not an opinion anymore.

19
00:00:50.800 --> 00:00:57.550
If someone says it's slow and you don't
have a measurement, they're whining.

20
00:00:57.550 --> 00:00:59.840
It's just a complaint, it's anecdotal.

21
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:00.920
It's just a story to tell.

22
00:01:00.920 --> 00:01:02.059
Now I'm not saying they're wrong.

23
00:01:03.290 --> 00:01:05.660
I'm just saying it's a rumor,
it could be slow.

24
00:01:05.660 --> 00:01:07.480
>> Right, without data it's just whining.

25
00:01:07.480 --> 00:01:10.621
>> Exactly, without data it's just
whining, you can quote me on that.

26
00:01:10.621 --> 00:01:12.157
[CROSSTALK] itiL book, but
without data it's just whining.

27
00:01:12.157 --> 00:01:13.659
I think I'll try that with my wife.

28
00:01:13.659 --> 00:01:14.704
>> That was it, that was.

29
00:01:14.704 --> 00:01:18.529
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so the importance
of measurement is just that,

30
00:01:18.529 --> 00:01:21.730
now, I've said this in earlier episodes.

31
00:01:21.730 --> 00:01:23.360
And I want to reinforce it here,

32
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:26.080
that measuring IT performance
itself is important.

33
00:01:26.080 --> 00:01:30.660
And I'm not degrading it in any
way by stating this next factoid.

34
00:01:30.660 --> 00:01:34.760
It's also important to
measure business outcomes.

35
00:01:34.760 --> 00:01:38.100
So if you look at this first graphic,
this first little slide of bullets.

36
00:01:38.100 --> 00:01:39.770
I'm not going to read
these bullets to you.

37
00:01:39.770 --> 00:01:45.130
But as you read these bullets, please note
that they are all focused on the business.

38
00:01:45.130 --> 00:01:49.210
The only one that's maybe slightly
not focused on the business

39
00:01:49.210 --> 00:01:52.300
is improving service quality.

40
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:56.080
There's not a direct line to the business
necessarily but of course, if your service

41
00:01:56.080 --> 00:02:00.610
is better probably the business is doing
better too, so I kinda get that one.

42
00:02:00.610 --> 00:02:04.580
So it's okay to measure your own
performance as a server provider,

43
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:05.640

The advantage of benchmarking,
as with other types of assessments,

725
00:41:17.245 --> 00:41:21.380
is it gives you a way to evaluate or

726
00:41:21.380 --> 00:41:25.980
assess where you are, right,
in comparison to something else.

727
00:41:25.980 --> 00:41:29.570

you could then make recommendations for

728
00:41:29.570 --> 00:41:31.940
where to move forward and
how to move forward.

729
00:41:33.620 --> 00:41:35.920
>> Great, all right.

730
00:41:35.920 --> 00:41:40.370
>> The CSI register, another important
aspect is that when you come up with

00:41:40.370 --> 00:41:45.300
improvement ideas log them,
keep them visible, keep them moving.

732
00:41:45.300 --> 00:41:49.874
Crack the whip, beat the drum,
make sure that you are aware of what

00:41:49.874 --> 00:41:54.295
improvements are in play,
which one's might be in play later.

734
00:41:54.295 --> 00:42:00.690
And use that as a mechanism for on going
transparency and progress, all right?

735
00:42:00.690 --> 00:42:03.363
And then full circle back
here to the CSI approach,

736
00:42:03.363 --> 00:42:06.795
reinforcing this is also the seven step,
improvement process.

737
00:42:06.795 --> 00:42:07.659
>> The cycle again.

738
00:42:07.659 --> 00:42:09.010
>> There's that cycle again.

739
00:42:09.010 --> 00:42:12.420

plan, do, check, act, right?

740
00:42:12.420 --> 00:42:15.020
So making sure those
things are well in play.

741
00:42:15.020 --> 00:42:19.440

where you understand the vision

742
00:42:19.440 --> 00:42:22.310
before you move forward with planning.

743
00:42:22.310 --> 00:42:26.130

the overall objectives and

744
00:42:26.130 --> 00:42:27.470

to be delivering.

745
00:42:27.470 --> 00:42:30.820

assessment of where you are right now,

746
00:42:30.820 --> 00:42:32.270
as we talked about before.

747
00:42:32.270 --> 00:42:36.020
Once you know where you are, you can
then assess, well, where should we be?

748
00:42:36.020 --> 00:42:38.610
That's where that gap analysis begins and

00:42:38.610 --> 00:42:42.570

start planning for improvement.

750
00:42:42.570 --> 00:42:45.330

find out did you get there.

751
00:42:45.330 --> 00:42:46.920
Did you move the deal

752
00:42:48.270 --> 00:42:49.580
Rinse and repeat

00:42:49.580 --> 00:42:50.150

00:42:51.050 --> 00:42:57.250

00:42:57.250 --> 00:42:58.980

00:42:58.980 --> 00:43:01.740

759
00:43:06.530 --> 00:43:08.200
